DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Announce Settlement of Families' Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: Drake Memorial Hospital has paid $2.3 million to settle all lawsuits filed by families of 26 patients that former nurse's aide Donald Harvey confessed to killing, lawyers announced Friday. Lawyers for the hospital and the families will ask county Common Pleas Judge William Morrissey to dismiss the lawsuits, said James Burke, a lawyer asked by Hamilton County commissioners to help negotiate the settlement. The lawsuits were filed after Harvey pleaded guilty, beginning in August 1987, to 37 murders in Ohio and Kentucky. The victims also included patients at Marymount Hospital in London, Ky., where Harvey worked in 1970 and 1971. Harvey, who said he killed his victims by poisoning them or suffocating them with plastic bags, is serving three consecutive life sentences in an Ohio prison. The hospital did not admit any wrongdoing in the deaths. Lawyers said Drake officials reached the settlement to avert a trial. ``The plaintiffs continue to believe in their position, and the defendants continue to deny that they are legally responsible for Harvey's actions,'' lawyers for both sides said in a joint statement. At the time of the murders to which Harvey confessed, Drake Hospital was owned by Hamilton County. The hospital sold its assets to the University of Cincinnati in July 1989 and is now known as Drake Center Inc. The settlement does not affect Drake Center, Burke said. A lawyer for the families of eight of Harvey's victims, Paul Martins, said of the settlement, ``I think it's fair, in weighing everything. It certainly doesn't compensate for all of the loss. The reason to settle is, from a practical standpoint, not putting these poor people through a trial.'' Martins said the families also obtained an agreement through which they could collect damages of as much as $11 million from Harvey should he ever earn money from movies or books about the murders.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis To Be Visible Along East Coast
With Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Atlantis should be visible along much of the East Coast, provided the skies are clear, as it hurtles into the highest inclination orbit ever traveled by a shuttle. The shuttle will be carrying a spy satellite that will venture 300 miles farther north and 300 miles farther south than any other shutle-lanched payload, according to sources who asked not to be identified. After three postponements, Atlantis is scheduled to lift off about 1 a.m. Sunday. The shuttle is expected to take a northeasterly course that will fly east of Cape Hatteras in North Carolina and hug the coast. The three main engines should burn out just east of New Jersey, with the shuttle flying over Newfoundland on a 62-degree inclination. If it is a clear morning, the fiery launch should be visible to many Floridians. The shuttle will resemble a shooting star to onlookers up the coast from Jacksonville.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Jazz Vocalist Undergoes Cancer Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Legendary jazz singer Sarah Vaughn is undergoing treatment for cancer at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. Cedars-Sinai spokesman Ron Wise said Friday that the 65-year-old singer entered the hospital last week for additional treatment of a previously diagnosed tumor in her right hand. ``She's been here at least two other times for treatment,'' Wise said, adding that Miss Vaughn will be released within a few days. Miss Vaughn is best known for her emotional renditions of ``The Lord's Prayer'' and ``Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child.'' She rose to fame as an associate of the pioneer bop musicians.

DOC.HEAD: Two Die in Collision of Navy Training Planes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with identities of pilots, pilots in 2nd plane uninjured, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two Navy training planes collided in the air Friday, killing an instructor and student pilot in one of the aircraft, said a spokesman at Whiting Field, Fla., where the planes were based. Those killed were aboard a T-34C Turbo Mentor that crashed into the edge of a Navy training field here at about 11:30 a.m., said Petty Officer 1st Class Jon Gagne. The second plane, also a T-34C, made an emergency landing at another outlying field near Silverhill about five miles northwest of this small South Alabama town. The pilots were uninjured. The dead men were identified as an instructor, Navy Lt. Gordon Bruce Wulf, 29, a Wichita, Kan., native who resides in Cantonment, Fla., and a student, Marine 1st Lt. Cary K. Smith, 25, of Columbia, S.C. It was not immediately known whether Wulf or Smith was flying the plane during the routine training flight, Gagne said. The Summerdale field is used to practice takeoffs and landings, Gagne said, but details of the crash and what the planes were doing when the collision occurred were not immediately available. The T-34Cs are two-seat, single-engine, turboprop planes used for primary flight training at Whiting, about 35 miles northeast of Pensacola, Fla. The Navy has several outlying fields in the Florida Panhandle and Southwest Alabama where students practice taking off and landing. The planes and crews were from Training Squadron 6, which is part of Training Air Wing 5. Only two days before the crash, a national television audience had a chance to see a T-34C in action during the ABC program ``Good Morning America,'' which was telecast Wednesday from the Pensacola Naval Air Station. A camera was trained on host Charlie Gibson in the back seat of a T-34.

DOC.HEAD: Carol's Brother: Family's Faith in People Restored by Donations
DOC.TEXT: The brother of Carol Stuart said his parents are still devastated over her death, but their faith in people has been restored by the donations that continue to arrive for a foundation established in her name. But in the nearly two months since 37-year-old Carl DiMaiti and his parents learned that Charles Stuart probably plotted his wife's death and told some family members before committing suicide, they have yet to receive an apology from the Stuarts. ``Nothing, there's been nothing,'' said DiMaiti in the first formal interview he has given since Charles Stuart apparently jumped off Boston's Tobin Bridge to his death Jan. 4. DiMaiti spoke Friday, the day after the FBI began a preliminary inquiry into the Boston Police Department investigation surrounding the slaying of Carol Stuart. The investigation focuses on allegations that police intimidated and coerced several people into implicating William Bennett in the Oct. 23 crime. The Suffolk County grand jury met Friday for the fourth time since Charles Stuart's death. Reportedly appearing before the panel were three of Stuart's siblings _ Neysa Porter, Shelley Yandoli and Michael Stuart. Carl DiMaiti, a former high school teacher who now runs the family pizza dough business, said the family still is angry about the slaying of his sister and the Stuart family's silence. But DiMaiti said the family has found new hope in the Carol DiMaiti Stuart Foundation formed last month. The foundation was established to award scholarships to residents of the Mission Hill neighborhood where Charles Stuart had told police that a black gunman shot him and critically wounded his pregnant wife. Carol Stuart died shortly after the shooting and the couple's son, delivered by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Contributions totaling $253,000 have poured in from around the country, the latest a check for $5,122.40 from New England Baptist Hospital. Many letters are addressed simply to ``DiMaiti Family, Medford, Mass.,'' DiMaiti said. And many are from people who also experienced the loss of a loved one, he said. ``They said the pain will ease,'' DiMaiti said. ``They say it's something you never get over but it does get better.'' DiMaiti described his mother as still devastated by the death of her daughter but said the letters and contributions from as far away as California and overseas have helped restore her faith in people. Giusto, 64, and Evelyn DiMaiti, 58, have declined to speak publicly about the case except for a speech the elder DiMaiti made during a press conference last month announcing that the foundation would be set up. Representatives of a public relations company hired by the families monitored Friday's interview and tried to prevent DiMaiti from answering questions other than general comments about the foundation. DiMaiti declined to comment on the FBI's inquiry into the manner in which Boston police handled the case.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Wins Two More Weeks at Armory for Overflow Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: A county sheriff who shocked state officials when he seized a National Guard armory to house prisoners from his overcrowded jail has won the right to keep them there for at least two more weeks. The decision came at a hearing Friday that followed a weeklong standoff between the state and the sheriff, who argued that he had a choice between seizing the armory or turning prisoners out on the streets. ``I just felt I couldn't take it any more and it was important to take a strong step,'' Hampden County Sheriff Michael Ashe said after Friday's hearing. Ashe agreed to allow the National Guard to keep operating from the building. Superior Court Judge George Keady set a March 12 court date for both sides to report back with a permanent solution. If they don't, Keady will hold a hearing on Ashe's earlier request for a preliminary injunction to stay at the armory. ``I think what we wanted to do is keep it on the front burner but turn down the heat,'' said Lawrence Fletcher-Hill, assistant attorney general. ``We're putting the issue of the sheriff's actions to the side. It's more important that we find a solution,'' he said. The sheriff shocked state officials Feb. 16, when he moved on the armory, informing National Guardsmen he was seizing the building under a 17th century statute ordering him to keep the peace. State officials at first reacted angrily. Secretary of Public Safety Charles V. Barry, who has jurisdiction over armories in the state, issued a statement saying he would pursue criminal trespass charges against Ashe. The state had argued that Ashe is a county official and does not have the right to take state property. After Ashe won a temporary restraining order allowing him to stay at the armory, along with widespread support from residents, local officials and even prisoners, the focus turned to trying to work out a compromise location for the prisoners. Officials would not specify what locations they are considering for overflow prisoners. A new jail to replace the county's 102-year-old jail is scheduled to be built in nearby Ludlow, but completion is at least two years away. Nineteen inmates are currently housed in the armory, in a large room with a concrete floor and a volleyball net stretched between two walls. Previously it was used for drill exercises by the National Guard. Inmates have said the armory is an improvement over the Hampden County Jail, which was built to hold 279 inmates and is under a federal court order to hold no more than 500 inmates. Ashe said he's pleased at his initial success in finding at least a temporary solution to his problem. ``I really feel good that we're able to keep on fighting,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `New Class' Published in Yugoslavia For The First Time
DOC.TEXT: ``The New Class,'' a 1957 indictment of Communist elites that was popular in the West but earned its Yugoslav author seven years in prison, has gone on sale for the first time in Yugoslavia. Milovan Djilas' book was printed by a state publishing house and was presented to the public Friday in a Belgrade bookshop. Djilas, 78, a protege of Yugoslavia's founder and former president, Josip Broz Tito, broke with the Communist leadership in 1954 after he publicly criticized the Communist Party for not allowing more Western-style democracy in Yugoslavia. After ``The New Class'' was smuggled out of the country and printed in the West, the state press accused of being a Western spy and a traitor to his country and to Communism. He was jailed for seven years. ``The New Class,'' which describes the flamboyant lifestyles of ruling Communist elites, reflected Djilas' disillusionment with the Communist system. Later works, including ``Conversations with Stalin,'' also were sharply critical of Communist doctrine and practices and banned in Yugoslavia during Tito's lifetime. Three years ago, several of his less-controversial literary works were published in this country. Numerous interviews with him have also been printed by the press since then and he has frequently appeared on television. Earlir this month, Djilas figured prominently at the nationally televised founding congress in Belgrade of the reconstituted Democratic Party. As a senior Communist leader in charge of propaganda, Djilas had helped run the Democrats out of Parliament in 1946.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actor John Cusack was arrested for driving under the influence of alcohol after crashing a rented vehicle, authorities said. Cusack, 23, star of the movie ``Say Anything,'' was arrested early Friday after his rented Jeep broadsided another car, Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy George Moak said. His blood-alcohol level was measured above the legal limit of .08 percent, said Moak, who declined to say what the exact level was. The Chicago native was released later Friday with a citation to appear in court. Moak said Cusack's car made a left turn into another car, and a sheriff's deputy driving directly behind Cusack witnessed the crash. When the deputy stopped to assist the accident victims he smelled alcohol on Cusack's breath, he said. Moak said Cusack was ``very cooperative.'' The driver of the car Cusack hit wasn't injured. In ``Say Anything,'' Cusack played a young man in love with a girl from the better side of the tracks. He was featured first in Rob Reiner's 1985 comedy ``The Sure Thing.''

Country singer Willie Nelson, who helped raise money for needy farmers with his Farm Aid concerts, is drumming up funds for Texas Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower's re-election campaign. Hightower, a two-term populist Democrat, has sent out a four-page fund-raising letter from Nelson to 20,000 people. It asks for money to combat campaigning by the Texas Farm Bureau, a private coalition of major agricultural organizations and chemical companies. ``The Farm Bureau and the chemical lobby are determined to knock him off and replace him with someone who is indebted to them,'' said Nelson, who last year testified for Hightower when the Legislature considered turning the commissioner's elected job into an appointed post. Texas Gov. Bill Clements is a Republican.

Paul Warhola, older brother of late pop artist Andy Warhol, said he wants to establish a family art museum in their ancestral home of Czechoslovakia. Warhola, 67, said he plans to approach Shirley Temple Black, the U.S. ambassador to Czechoslovakia, for assistance with the project. Warhola said the idea for the museum has been rejected by Fred Hughes, director of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, but he is undeterred. ``We could give the things I have of Andy's, some of my paintings and the art of my sons, James and Marty,'' he said. ``We don't need the foundation.'' Paul and Andy Warhola's parents emigrated to the United States from Czechoslovakia. Andy Warhol, who dropped the last letter of his name, grew up in Pittsburgh. He died three years ago Thursday in New York.

Joseph Ricapito, a Louisiana State University professor of foreign languages and literature who was knighted last year by Italy, has received a second knighthood from Spain. King Juan Carlos named Ricapito a Knight of the Order of Queen Isabella for his contributions to the understanding in other countries of Spanish literature, culture and civilization. Spanish Consul General Pablo Sanchez-Teran presented the knighthood award in a ceremony Friday at LSU. Ricapito is a specialist in 16th- and 17th-century Spanish literature and the cultural crossovers between Italy and Spain.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Versions of the following item moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Calgary Flames defenseman Al MacInnis was acquitted of five assault charges stemming from a brawl outside a Calgary bar last summer. But his brother, Robert, was convicted Friday of one count of common assault. The MacInnis bothers each faced five charges _ two of assault causing bodily harm and three of common assault. A friend of the brothers testified during the trial that the two received more blows than they delivered in a July 3 fight outside the Old Scotch Restaurant and Bar. Darryl MacDonald testified that the fight began when a woman started yelling at the MacInnis party as they were leaving the restaurant. Al MacInnis won the Conn Smythe Trophy last spring as the most valuable player as the Flames won their first Stanley Cup.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Versions of the following item moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta Falcons linebacker Aundray Bruce, the first player selected in the 1988 NFL draft, has been named in two paternity lawsuits. The lawsuits filed Thursday in Fulton County Superior Court charge that Bruce is the father of Tamirah Davis, born June 1 in Atlanta to Varian Denise Davis, and of Aciona Aundraya Johnson, whose mother, Machille Johnson, gave birth July 5 in Jacksonville, Fla. Attorney William K. Travis filed both lawsuits, which claim that Bruce has refused to assist in the support of the children. Bruce's attorney, Donald J. Ellis, said he had not seen the lawsuits and declined to comment. Bruce, whose telephone has been disconnected, could not be reached for comment. A hearing on the Davis suit is scheduled for March 16. The Johnson suit is scheduled for a hearing March 9. Bruce, a former Auburn star, signed a $4.1 million, five-year contract with the Falcons in 1988 that included a $1.6 million signing bonus.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Candidate Hopes to Lead No. 2 Party
With PM-Nicaragua-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eric Ramirez knows he's bound to lose in Sunday's presidential elections, but the Social Christian Party candidate hopes to become an important factor in political developments following the election. Ramirez, the candidate of the Social Christian party, believes President Daniel Ortega of the governing leftist Sandinistas will win with about 50 percent of the vote. He thinks Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's United National Opposition, a broad coalition known as UNO, will come in second with about 35 percent. There are seven other candidates in the election. Ramirez is the only one expected to draw a significant percentage of the vote. Ramirez, 43, sees the election as a landmark in the history of Nicaragua ``with changes coming no matter who wins.'' ``The opposition made a serious mistake when it didn't run six years ago. We could have exercised a lot of pressure through the Assembly all these years,'' he said in an interview. Many opposition parties, including the Social Christians and an earlier broad coalition like UNO, refused to take part in a vote overwhelmingly won by the Sandinistas. This time around, the UNO coalition wanted Ramirez to join, but he refused to go along. He said the 14-party coalition, an odd mixture ranging from the Communist Party to conservative elements of the Private Business Council, will fall apart under the pressure of specific political decisions. ``Some of those people, especially the Communists and the Socialists, if they get someone elected to the Assembly, will vote with the FSLN (Sandinistas), not with the Private Business people.'' Losing presidential candidates who get a certain number of votes _ the number is set by a complicated formula but will probably be about 15,000 _ get a seat in the National Assembly. Ramirez hopes to lead six or seven other Social Christians in what would be a 99-member Assembly if all presidential losers gain seats. That could make the Social Christians an important party, because Ramirez and some others see UNO splitting into its many political components to seek temporary alliances. ``You have the United States providing money to the UNO that will probably elect two members of the Communist party, who already are talking to the FSLN,'' Ramirez said, using initials of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. He was referring to U.S. economic aid to the UNO. ``We can become the second largest single political party in the Assembly,'' after the Sandinistas, he said. Bayardo Arce, Ortega's campaign manager, said he agreed with Ramirez on both points: the Social Christians will win six to seven seats and end up as the second largest party. Ramirez calls himself a centrist who believes the United States should stop sponsoring Contra guerrillas who have fought a war to topple the government. ``Reality will force both the United States and the Sandinistas to become pragmatic and seek an accommodation,'' Ramirez said.

DOC.HEAD: Observers Say Nicaragua Poised For Clean Election
With PM-Nicaragua-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Key international observers say they expect Sunday's national elections to be free and fair, despite problems during the often bitter campaign. ``I've given a lot of thought to how the system could be beat,'' said former U.S. attorney general Elliott Richardson, who heads a U.N. observer mission. ``I haven't yet been able to come up with a good scheme.'' A U.N. report he released Friday concludes that Nicaragua's 1.75 million registered voters ``are in a position to decide between alternatives which have been given a reasonable chance to be aired.'' The campaign was not without problems, it said, but it ``has changed the way elections are perceived ... by redefining and considerably broadening the limits of political action in Nicaragua.'' The Organization of American States reached similar conclusions about the possibility of a fair election on Sunday, as did former President Jimmy Carter. Carter is heading up a group of international observers that includes five U.S. senators and seven House members, three former state governors, a prime minister and five former presidents. Carter, who cried foul in the Panamanian election last year while the votes were still being counted, is regarded as one of the most influential observers. His delegation is working closely with both the Organization of American States and the United Nations, which among them are fielding more than 700 observers. ``We will monitor every step of the process and do parallel tabulations of the vote to guarantee that the final results reflect the will of the people,'' Carter said after arriving in Nicaragua on Friday. The governing leftist Sandinistas expect to win the election, and they hope an internationally recognized victory will lead to an end to the U.S. economic embargo and U.S. support for the Contra rebels. The verdict of the observers from Carter's Atlanta-based Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government is considered crucial to a change in attitude by the Bush administration. Rep. Jim Slattery, a Kansas Democrat, said an honest election could pave the way to a new U.S. policy on Nicaragua. ``If the election is free and fair and if the Nicaraguan government ceases any further attempt to export revolution and stir up trouble in El Salvador, then I think the American government should honor the will of the Nicaraguan people and move toward improving economic relations and diplomatic relations,'' said Slattery, one of the observers. The Nicaraguan government has previously said it is not supplying weapons to the Salvadoran guerrillas. President Daniel Ortega has signed a regional accord pledging not to provide such aid. In today's editions of the New York Times, he was quoted as saying he would not provide arms to them after the elections if he is re-elected, and he called El Salvador's rightist government ``legitimate.'' Ortega's main challenger is publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition or UNO, a coalition of 14 parties and one native Indian group. Despite their generally optimistic conclusions, the key observers all concede there have been problems, including violence in the early days of the campaign, intimidation, limited opposition access to the state-controlled media, and the control of other resources by the Sandinistas. The U.N. report says the problems have diminished in the final days of the campaign even though ``the question of free electoral competition will no doubt be the subject of controversy.'' Virgilio Godoy, UNO's vice presidential candidate, said Friday the coalition would recognize a Sandinista victory if it is honest.

DOC.HEAD: Economist: Lawyers a `Black Hole' in Economy
DOC.TEXT: Each lawyer in the United States costs the economy an average of $1 million per year, according to a finance professor who believes the country's economy weakens as the number of attorneys increases. Steven Magee, a University of Texas-Austin professor who was an economist in the Nixon administration, said Friday the country's 500,000 lawyers are dampening the gross national product by $500 billion, or about 10 percent. Magee theorizes that the effect is caused by wealthy corporations and individuals who hire lawyers to ``get their hands into each others pockets.'' These findings are part of a book Magee co-authored titled ``Black Hole Tariffs and Endogenous Policy Theory.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress, Administration Square Off Over Dropped Pentagon Projects
DOC.TEXT: Congress may be headed toward a legislative or legal confrontation with the Bush administration over $1.25 billion in Pentagon projects the administration wants to put on hold. Armed with a new General Accounting Office opinion, several members of Congress urged the Bush administration Friday to reconsider its postponement of the 15 projects, which had been previously approved for 1990 funding. The administration's reasoning in announcing the delays earlier this month was too vague to meet legal requirements, Milton J. Soccolar, the special assistant to the head of the GAO, said in an opinion. ``The administration's entire explanation of the deferrals is that they are necessary because of `changes in requirements in view of the promising developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe,'' Soccolar wrote Wednesday to Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee. The GAO is an investigative arm of Congress. ``This is not the detailed, reasoned explanation for the deferrals which section 1013 (of the relevant law) requires. It is no more than a generalized assertion,'' he wrote. The postponed projects include aircraft modifications, Navy ship conversions expected to be a boon to many coastal states, defense software research and Army, Army Reserve and Air National Guard construction projects. The appropriations panel released a letter Friday in which Byrd and the panel's ranking Republican, Sen. Mark Hatfield of Oregon, asked budget director Richard Darman to reconsider the postponements. ``In light of these findings by the GAO, we urge the administration to withdraw immediately any and all deferrals, other than those that involve the routine withholding of funds in connection with the normal and orderly operation of the government,'' Byrd and Hatfield said. Among the postponed projects was a $3.2 million access road for the Tobyhanna Army Depot in northeastern Pennsylvania. Reps. Paul Kanjorski, D-Pa., and Joseph McDade, R-Pa., wrote Bush on Friday saying such projects should not be written off in the drive for budget savings as a result of emerging democracy in Eastern Europe. ``We fail to see the relationship and linkage between recent international events and a pressing public works project that has been planned for several years,'' they said. The Office of Management and Budget said Friday it would have no immediate comment on the issue. Presidents routinely ask Congress to delay billions of dollars of planned spending each year. By law, those requests _ called deferrals _ are permissible because of unexpected contingencies or a chance to save money through better management. But delays are not allowable for policy reasons. They can be blocked by a majority vote of either chamber, or by a civil suit filed by the head of the GAO. Senate appropriations officials said they hoped the issue could be resolved without court action. The GAO said its study showed $1.25 billion was being improperly deferred by the administration.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Say Jackson Won't Run for D.C. Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, facing signs city voters are wary that he will run for mayor in the wake of Mayor Marion Barry's drug arrest, has told supporters he won't seek Barry's job, associates say. ``He's not going to run for mayor of Washington. We talked about it yesterday,'' Joel Ferguson, who managed Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign in Michigan, told a Lansing, Mich., television station Friday. Jackson, a two-time Democratic presidential contender, was en route to Chicago on Friday evening. There was no answer at his Chicago home. Jackson's political plans have been the subject of speculation since he moved to the nation's capital in April. That speculation intensified with Barry's arrest last month on a cocaine possession charge. Jackson has said his recent campaign to gain statehood for the District of Columbia will remain his priority. He has said he will formally announce next week he will not run for mayor, associates said. A top Jackson aide, Frank Watkins, refused Friday to discuss Jackson's decision on the mayoral race. ``One of the reasons Jesse would run for anything, like mayor of a major city, is to come in as a healer,'' Ferguson told station WKAR. ``In a way, his candidacy would be viewed as divisive.'' Ferguson estimated the chance that Jackson would run at only 10 percent, but another supporter said Jackson told him flatly that he would not run. ``Jesse is out,'' said the supporter, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He has decided that it would be wrong for him to get into the race at this time, or at all.'' Barry is at a South Carolina hospital for treatment for what aides as called an alcohol problem. City Administrator Carol Thompson is running the city in Barry's absence. Jackson's apparent decision comes amid growing signs that voters _ and politicians _ are wary of a Jackson mayoral bid. A Washington Post poll released Thursday reported Jackson would trail Barry if both were candidates in the September Democratic primary. Jackson has repeatedly refused to rule out a run for Barry's job, saying he would only seek the office if Barry, a colleague in the civil rights battle, did not run for a fourth term. Jeffrey N. Gildenhorn, a Barry fund-raiser, said Jackson associates told him that a mayoral candidacy was extremely unlikely. ``There were strong indications from his people that (Jackson's decision not to run) was just a formality that needed to be announced,'' Gildenhorn said. ``I started hearing that last week.'' Barry has been silent since his arrest on his plans for re-election. Aides close to the mayor have said Barry acknowledged privately the weekend after his arrest that he would not run again. The Washington Post poll of 800 District residents found that Barry was preferred by 25 percent of those surveyed, while 19 percent said they would vote for Jackson. If Barry weren't in the race, Jackson would receive support from 26 percent of those questioned compared with 19 percent for city Councilman John Ray. The poll had a margin of error of 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Final Charges Dropped Against Three Men in Contra Case
DOC.TEXT: The remaining federal indictments against three men who were already cleared of charges that they illegally armed and trained the Contras have been dismissed, a defense attorney said. Charges involving weapons or passport violations were dropped against former mercenery Jack Terrell, former Civilian Materiel Assistance activist Jose Coutin and Rene Corvo, an opponent of Cuba's Fidel Castro. ``It's the first clear victory for the whistleblowers in this whole affair,'' said Terrell's attorney, John Mattes, describing the decision to drop the charges. The three and 10 other people were indicted by a federal grand jury in 1988 on charges of violating the U.S. Neutrality Act for allegedly assisting the Nicaraguan Contras in 1984 and 1985. Two Fort Lauderdale federal judges dismissed those charges, agreeing with defense attorneys that the U.S. government waged war against Nicaragua despite congressional votes to cut off funds to the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The Neutrality Act allows prosecution of anyone making war from U.S. soil against a nation with which the United States is at peace. The U.S. attorney's office said Friday the lesser charges had been dropped against Terrell, Coutin and Corvo, said Mattes. The rest of the defendants already had been cleared completely. ``Obviously, the government felt the charges of harassment and selective prosecution were too sensitive,'' Mattes said. ``And I think they were fearful of disclosing illegal wiretaps in this case.'' The U.S. attorney's office did not return telephone calls Friday from The Associated Press. Terrell had become disenchanted with the Contras in 1986, and his information helped lead to the two indictments. Terrell's revelations to the FBI angered then-National Security Agency aide Oliver North, and North ordered the former mercenary investigated, according to later congressional investigations into the Iran-Contra scandal. Mattes said it was ironic that Terrell faced the strongest charges _ a possible 40-year prison sentence _ in a case which he had helped bring about. The last of the charges dropped against Terrell were two counts of illegally transporting weapons. A charge of allowing someone else to use his passport was dropped against Coutin. The dismissed charges against Corvo accused him of shipping a 20mm cannon, a mortar and other weapons from Fort Lauderdale to Contra bases in Costa Rica under the guise of humanitarian aid.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats to Push Own Bill
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell says Democrats are impatient with the slow progress of a bipartisan House task force on campaign finance reform and will push a vote in the Senate next month on their own legislation. Mitchell, D-Maine, said the Senate Rules Committee will approve a bill in early March and the full Senate will take it up later in the month. Mitchell, joined at a news conference by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., cast doubt on prospects for a bipartisan bill that includes spending ceilings. ``As public demand for reform rises, we ought to be able to come together and bridge our differences,'' Mitchell said. ``If we cannot do so, then we will proceed to attempt to enact a bill in any event ... over whatever opposition exists.'' Foley said the 21-member House task force of members from both parties that was created last year will continue its work. But he acknowledged the task force is not going to find a package agreeable to both parties. ``We hope there will be some of the bill at least that could be bipartisan,'' he said. ``We will clearly have differences.'' Democrats had hoped to see what the task force produced before tackling the campaign finance issue again in the Senate, where the last effort to toughen the law died in 1988 under a GOP filibuster. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole has remained noncommittal on the issue. And Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska, the senior Republican on the Senate Rules Committee, said at a hearing Thursday, ``I don't think our side of the aisle is going to change.'' Mitchell acknowledged allegations against six senators accused of intervening with federal thrift regulators or housing officials on behalf of campaign contributors is the driving force behind the legislation. ``Many Americans believe that their elected representatives are more responsive to campaign contributors than to constituents,'' he said. ``The perception is that fundraising has overtaken the election process (and) it is demeaning this institution.'' Mitchell and Democratic Sens. Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia and David Boren of Oklahoma are cosponsoring a bill limiting contributions by political action committees or PACs and individuals to national and state party organizations. As an incentive to comply with voluntary spending ceilings, one draft provides that candidates who remain under the limit would be entitled to discount mail and TV advertising rates. The Democratic bill also would require more disclosure of so-called ``soft money'' contributions from labor unions, trade associations and individuals to party organizations and for other campaign causes. Mitchell said he still favors public financing of political campaigns but conceded there is not enough support to get it enacted.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Arthur Fletcher to Head Civil Rights Commission
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants Arthur A. Fletcher to restore the Civil Rights Commission as ``an effective institution'' after years in which civil rights groups said the commission wasn't doing its job. ``We think they can do a better job,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Friday in announcing Fletcher's selection. Fletcher, 65, is a moderate black Republican who has served in three previous GOP administrations. Bush sought to give him the post nearly a year ago, but the chairman of the commission, William B. Allen, wouldn't resign at the time. Civil rights groups and members of Congress have criticized the commission for its positions during the Reagan administration, including opposition to affirmative action programs. Fletcher was assistant secretary of labor under President Nixon, deputy assistant for urban affairs under President Ford and an adviser to President Reagan. He also served with Bush at the United Nations in 1971. In announcing Fletcher's nomination on Friday, Fitzwater said, ``We wanted to name a new chairman and reinvigorate the commission, but we had to have a vacancy to do it.'' Allen, the former chairman, indicated that he would not voluntarily step aside when reports first surfaced that Bush wanted to select Fletcher as the commission chairman. But he did resign late last year with a blast at Bush, calling his administration ``too reticent ... to contribute to the debate on civil rights.'' Fitzwater said Bush wants to see the commission restored as ``an effective institution.'' ``We have felt that it could be stronger and more forceful in representing the concerns of minorities and others. We expect it to operate in that fashion,'' the spokesman said. Fitzwater said another vacancy on the eight-member commission will be filled soon. The president and Congress each appoint four members. The commission was established in 1957. It evaluates federal laws and the effectiveness of the government's equal-opportunity programs and serves as a clearinghouse for civil rights information. Allen's tenure at the agency was marked by controversy and confrontation with other commissioners. A speech he delivered last year titled ``Blacks? Animals? Homosexuals? What is a Minority?'' was formally condemned as ``thoughtless, disgusting and unnecessarily inflammatory'' on a 6-1 vote of the commission. An Arizona native, Fletcher was executive director of the United Negro College Fund in 1972-73. In 1971, he was alternate delegate to the General Assembly of the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern European Countries May Link Up With Common Market
DOC.TEXT: The European Economic Community is considering granting the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe associate membership to encourage their economic reforms. Frans Andriessen, vice president for external affairs and trade policy of the European Community, said the western democracies needed to do everything possible to encourage the dramatic pace of reforms under way in the former Communist bloc. ``If in the West, we persevere in our efforts to assist them, then an economic revolution will succeed the political ones,'' Andriessen said Friday. The 12-nation community has already expanded its economic help beyond the original targets of Poland and Hungary to include East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and Yugoslavia. But Andriessen said the community is also studying going beyond grants ``to anchor these new Eastern democracies to the Free World through a form of association with the European Community if they want to.'' Andriessen's comments came in a speech to a business conference. Afterwards, he told reporters that the proposal would be reviewed further before being taken up by the community's policy-making body in late June or July. In a fact sheet, the community said associate membership could be granted to countries to recognize their ``geographic proximity, shared political, economic and cultural values and increased interdependence.'' It suggested that one model for such association would be the existing European Free Trade Association _ Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland _ who are not members of the European Economic Community but who enjoy certain economic ties with the EEC. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, who also addressed the conference, said that though the United States is negotiating trade agreements with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, completely normal trade relations would not occur until those countries became full members in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 96-country organization that regulates world trade. To join GATT, she said, these countries will have to clear the major hurdle of making their currencies convertible into other currencies and base their economies on market pricing rather than pricing by government decree.

DOC.HEAD: Backers of Legal Abortions Pleased With Victories in Indiana, Michigan
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of legal abortions say the defeat of anti-abortion bills in Indiana and a veto of one in Michigan show lawmakers are proving reluctant to impose new restrictions. Pro-choice leaders also hailed the defeat of bills this week in the Virginia and Kansas legislatures, and the adjournment of Utah's legislature without passing any anti-abortion bill. ``This week's events are irrefutable proof that the pro-choice majority will mount significant opposition to the serious threat to choice that still exists in America's statehouses,'' Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said Friday. Nancy Myers, spokeswoman for the anti-abortion National Right to Life Committee, acknowledged her group had suffered setbacks in several states this week. But she said it succeeded in winning passage in South Carolina of a bill requiring a parent's permission for a minor woman to receive an abortion. ``It's tremendously exciting,'' Myers said. ``Things are happening everywhere. It's only February. State legislatures are still in session. We've got a long time before we see how the chips are going to fall.'' Much of the political fight over abortion is being waged in the statehouses this winter as anti-abortion forces try to take advantage of an opening given them by the Supreme Court's Webster decision last year. It gave states new authority to impose limits on a woman's right to an abortion by upholding a Missouri law. Michelman plans to travel to Minnesota next week, where her side expects a legislative showdown over a bill that would prohibit abortions as a means of birth control _ a provision that would prevent most abortions. Both sides say Alabama's legislature may be a key battleground next week, with floor action possible on similar anti-abortion legislation. In Indianapolis, the state Senate defeated legislation Thursday to ban abortions in public hospitals. ``We're not going to be debating this issue again in the Indiana Senate during this session,'' said Dinah Farrington, a lobbyist for Planned Parenthood Inc., which supports legal abortions. In Michigan, Democratic Gov. Jim Blanchard on Friday vetoed a bill that would have required minors to get permission either from their parents or a court before having an abortion. His veto had been expected. Blanchard said he supported parental involvement in such decisions but that the bill ``takes a woman's right to help herself away from her.'' Myers, spokeswoman for the national anti-abortion group, said it had assurances that South Carolina's Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell would sign a similar bill passed in his state. Officials at NARAL, the national abortion-rights lobbying group in Washington, also cited the defeat in Virginia's state Senate of a similar parental-consent bill and the Kansas legislature's defeat of abortion restrictions. They pointed to the adjournment of the legislature in Utah, saying it represented a victory for them in a state where only two months ago odds had looked good for the imposition of abortion restrictions. ``We have not won the war by any stretch,'' Michelman said. ``We have a long way to go, ... but we are making gains and politicians are feeling our strength.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Survivors' Claims Spur Custody Fight Over Orphan
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: As an 8-month-old boy cuts his teeth and makes new gurgling sounds, a judge is deciding who the baby will call ``Mommy'' and ``Daddy'' in place of parents who died on an earthquake-smashed freeway. The baby's parents dropped Jimmy Brown off at his great-grandmother's home on Oct. 17 as they headed to a Berkeley pier to go fishing with friends. They never saw the baby again. Michelle Richard, 18, and 21-year-old James Brown III, a high school student and her unemployed lover, died when the 7.1-magnitude quake twisted an elevated portion of freeway on which they traveled into a mangled mess of collapsed concrete and steel. A total of 67 people lost their lives in the temblor, most of them on the freeway. The quake left their baby at the center of an intense emotional and legal tug-of-war. Several bereaved relatives stepped forward seeking custody of Jimmy, who stands to collect at least $100,000 from a state-controlled account compensating relatives of the freeway victims. The state Board of Control has delayed awarding the claim until Alameda County Superior Judge Roderic Duncan decides which relative, set of relatives or outsiders will care for Jimmy. Hearings are set for April 13 and 22. Walnut Creek attorney Peter Hinton, one of two lawyers representing maternal grandmother Anita Williams, complained that ``bigoted'' media coverage of the family squabbles has been ``almost like a rape case; they're being subjected to a public scrutiny in a very unfair way.'' ``The tragedy is being overlooked,'' he said. In making his decision, Duncan will have to sift through allegations of drug and alcohol abuse, fingerpointing about criminal records, teen-age sex and cycles of poverty. The parties seeking custody are: _Maternal grandmother Williams, 35, who has three other children, a three-bedroom townhouse and income derived solely from welfare; Jimmy's been staying primarily with her since the earthquake. ``She's being portrayed as welfare trash,'' said Hinton, who added that the only time Williams accepted welfare is when she was unable to collect support money from her children's father. _Jimmy's paternal grandfather and his wife, who have a hauling and landscape business in Oakland. James Brown II served a recent prison term for theft. His son also did time in jail for possession last April of crack cocaine for sale. _Great-grandmother Louise Brown, a 65-year-old family matriarch who said she raised Jimmy's father almost like one of her own sons, and probably spent more time looking after the baby than did either one of his parents. ``I thought that eventually they would get hurt or something bad would happen to them,'' Mrs. Brown said of Jimmy's parents, who she said had hung around with ``nothing but bad actors.'' Although critical of Michelle's family for what she called lack of discipline and other problems, Mrs. Brown said she favors Anita Williams adopting Jimmy if she takes good care of him and allows other relatives to visit. The court also could place Jimmy with a foster family or unrelated adoptive parents. Two county family service counselors are investigating the situation. S. Simone Campbell, a state-appointed attorney representing Jimmy, said, ``We're hoping that another family member surfaces. ``Everything's wide open at this point,'' said Campbell, a Catholic nun. ``Every one of the parties have their strengths and weaknesses, but enough weaknesses that I have some concerns.'' Campbell said applications for the state compensation apparently led the family reluctantly into court, unable any more to pass Jimmy around between homes of various relatives without serious disputes. She said Jimmy showed no apparent ``dramatic problems'' and described him as ``laughing and giggly and doing things that 8-month-old kids seem to do.'' ``This much pain hopefully will give rise to something good eventually,'' Campbell said.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Say Ortega Will Win; Exiles Unlikely To Return
With PM-Nicaragua-US, Bjt
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Nicaragua's rebel military forces predicts the nation's Sandinista government will remain in control no matter what the outcome of Sunday's elections. The United National Opposition coalition is given little hope of ousting the 11-year-old Sandinista government, but even an upset victory would face difficulty overcoming ``an armed party,'' as Israel Galeano called the Sandinistas. ``It is one thing for UNO to win _ it's another for them to succeed in their objectives,'' said the commander, who has led the rebel movement since the old civilian directorate was abolished and rival Enrique Bermudez was pushed aside. Galeano, who used the name Commander Franklin, noted that the Sandinistas have refused to give absentee votes to an estimated 700,000 exiled Nicaraguans _ more than 20 percent of the Central American nation's population _ or the 7,000 Contra troops he said are still camped inside Nicaragua. The Contras' skepticism toward the elections is mirrored by many exiles in Miami, where few of the 50,000 exiles are making plans to return home. ``The goal of these people is to get their family out,'' said volunteer Donald Baldizol at the Nicaraguan Assistance Center on Friday. ``They are poor people, and they don't see any future there.'' Prominent Nicaraguan exiles agree that even in the best of cases, there will be no mass reintegration of the exiles into Nicaraguan life. Roberto Arguello, president of the Nicaraguan American Bankers Association and a member of the U.S. Senate Task Force on Hispanic Affairs, said he expects 100,000 more Nicaraguans to stream into the United States. ``When they see they have Daniel Ortega for another five years, they will leave,'' said Arguello. He said that in 10 years of Sandinista rule, the average income has slipped to 1950 levels. ``In another 10 years it will be down to the 1920s,'' the banker said. A few Nicaraguans here say although skepticism is merited, there is at least a little hope that UNO candidate Violeta Chamorro can win and exiles can return home. ``You cannot get mangoes from apple trees, and the Sandinista record certainly does not lend itself to having a credibile election,'' said Adolfo Calero, former Contra leader who now works for the Nicaraguan American Foundation. ``But it would be a great advancement if she won, and she could eventually achieve real power, with the support of the people.'' Calero said he had wanted to return to Nicaragua to participate in the elections, but was denied a passport by the Sandinistas. ``If Violeta wins, I will seriously consider going back,'' he said. And even if the Sandinistas win, there is chance that pragmatically, they will have to move closer to the United States. ``Win or lose, the Sandinistas are bound to lose,'' Calero said. ``The only unknown factor is time. They cannot run against the world current and remain untouched.''

DOC.HEAD: Cyprus Ferry To Lebanon Hit by Shellfire
DOC.TEXT: A passenger ferry carrying 116 people was hit by shellfire today off the coast of Lebanon and two passengers were killed, Cypriot police reported. They said 14 people were wounded in the attack, which started at least one fire on board. Initial reports indicated a Syrian naval vessel fired on the passenger ferry when it was eight miles off Lebanon, said marine police in the port of Larnaca. The ferry was steaming from the east Mediterranean island of Cyprus to the Lebanese port of Jounieh, the police said. There has been fighting near Journieh between rival Christian forces. The agents for the ferry, Socomare, had no immediate comment on damage to the vessel. Helicopters were being sent to the boat to take off the wounded passengers, police said. Police said there were 64 passengers and 52 crew members on the ship. The ferry is one of the main escape routes for embattled Lebanese Christians, many now fleeing from three weeks of fighting between the rival Christian forces of army General Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. The captain and crew of the ship had been reluctant to take it into Jounieh because of the risks involved in the intra-Christian battle. The port in the Christian enclave is 120 miles from Cyprus, a seven-hour journey.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st item to CORRECT to `ensign' sted `ensigna,' and to `Intracoastal' sted `Intercoastal.'
DOC.TEXT: It's a mounted patrol Florida-style: cops on jet skis. A Broward County deputy was to begin patrols today aboard a specially equipped jet ski with police ensign and flashing light. The craft, similar to a seagoing snowmobile, will travel along the Intracoastal Waterway, canals and lagoons searching for reckless and improper jet ski operators. ``Jet skis are increasing popular ... and as more people become involved with them, we have to become more cognizant about safety,'' said deputy John D'Agostino, who tested the police jet ski Friday. In Florida last year, 85 jet-ski accidents resulted in six deaths. Beneath his life jacket, D'Agostino will wear a short-sleeve white shirt, police-issue green shorts, black diving booties _ and a pistol in a holster.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Skipper Says He Drank Iced Tea, Beer
DOC.TEXT: Shortly after the Exxon Valdez ran aground, Joseph Hazelwood insisted to investigators that he drank nothing stronger than a beer during a day ashore preceding the accident. Jurors heard a tape Friday of Hazelwood's account told to a Coast Guard investigator. He gave a scenario of his shore visit which was nearly identical to that depicted by witnesses at his criminal trial except for one crucial detail _ the drinking. Witnesses have said that Hazelwood spent at least part of the afternoon of March 23 at the Pipeline Club in Valdez drinking vodka. Hazelwood said it wasn't so. The muffled tape played for the jury showed that the skipper was being questioned about alcohol use 13 hours after the 987-foot tanker ran aground on Bligh Reef, unleashing the nation's worst oil spill. ``There have been some suggestions and statements concerning the fact that, ah, that you had some alcohol or an odor of alcohol on you, do you?'' asked Coast Guard investigator Mark Delozier. Delozier has testified he smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath. ``Well, I had one of those phony beers, `Moussy,' and I'd been ashore,'' Hazelwood responded. ``I had lunch ... drank iced tea.'' He said he finished lunch with some fellow officers in Valdez at about 2 p.m. ``I did a little shopping, got some post cards and sent some flowers to my wife for Easter and picked up some pizza to bring back to the ship with us,'' he said. ``Did you stop at any other establishments in town, liquor places or bars?'' asked Delozier. ``Well, we went by the Pipeline (Club) to see if anybody off the ship was in there, if we knew anybody. ... Nobody there so we left and picked up the pizza,'' he said. He denied drinking anything at the Valdez bar where witnesses said they saw him ordering vodka. Hazelwood said he had one ``real'' beer before boarding the ship and one or two ``phony,'' nearly non-alcoholic, beers before the Exxon Valdez sailed. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony; and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The Exxon Valdez, with a crewman at the helm and Hazelwood off the bridge, struck a reef in Prince William Sound and leaked nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil. The spill blackened hundreds of miles of rocky coastline and killed countless birds, fish and other wildlife. Moussy beer was permitted aboard Exxon ships while other alcohol was banned. Testimony resumes on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Buys Bankrupt Bishop College
DOC.TEXT: A prominent black businessman who purchased a bankrupt college founded by freed slaves and missionaries called on the city's black community to help him make the school a success again. ``I waited until the last minute for someone or some group to come through and buy it,'' said Comer Cottrell, after buying the Bishop College's entire 130-acre campus on Friday. ``But no one floated to the surface. ``It would have been a real blow to the developing black community here if the school was dissolved. Now we need a commitment from the blacks that they will help make it work.'' Cottrell bought the college for $1.5 million in a liquidation auction. Sobbing with joy, Cottrell called the acquisition of Dallas' only predominantly black college his ``moral duty.'' Cottrell owns Dallas-based Pro-Line Corp., the nation's 18th largest black-owned company, which sells more than $30 million a year in hair-care products for blacks. ``What happened to the school is criminal,'' Cottrell said. ``As the past vice chairman of the school, I had to go through the agony, pain and heartache of the demise of the college.'' Cottrell said he will reopen the 108-year-old school as soon as a board of trustees is in place and construction crews clean up the decaying campus. ``We will turn the institution around to benefit the whole of the community _ especially the black youth,'' he said. Cottrell, 58, opened the bidding at $1.2 million Friday afternoon and said after purchasing the college that he had been willing to go even higher. ``I was prepared to pay $5 million, so $1.5 (million) is quite a bargain,'' he said. The auction lasted less than five minutes. Cottrell was one of two bidders, but officials refused to release the name of the other bidder. Bishop College, which is named after Union Army Col. Nathan Bishop, a white man, was founded in Marshall, Texas, in 1881 by nine freed slaves and a group of Baptist missionaries. The college was moved to Dallas from Marshall in 1961. State senator Eddie Bernice Johnson of Dallas said last week state school officials are investigating whether the institution should be resurrected as a teacher's college. Cottrell, who received an honorary degree from Bishop, said the school will maintain its name, but he was unsure if the school would become a teacher's college or remain an undergraduate institution. ``As long as it serves the black community, that's all that matters,'' he said. The school, which suffered from bungled management for more than a decade, was closed in August 1988 by a federal bankruptcy judge after the school failed to raise enough money to subsist. Bob Mottern, an attorney representing Duke Salisbury, the trustee appointed to oversee the liquidation of Bishop's assets, said the money from the sale will go to pay legal fees and salaries of employees released when the school closed down. Cottrell said he is seeking investors to help him pay for the school.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadorans Crowd Church to Mourn Duarte
LaserPhotos NY6,7
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of mourners today thronged a church to pay respects to former President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who tried and failed to ease the searing class divisions that sparked a crippling, decade-old civil war. Duarte died at his home Friday after a long battle with cancer. He was 64. Two of Duarte's six children, Alejandro and Napoleon, accompanied by leaders of the Christian Democratic Party he helped found, carried his flag-draped coffin to the Don Rua Roman Catholic church in the blue-collar neighborhood of San Miguelito. Military school cadets escorted the procession. About 500 mourners, many carrying flowers, awaited them at the church, where Duarte's body was to lie in state until the funeral Sunday. Mourners, many of them poor, continued to arrive early today while hundreds of others blocked streets outside the church. Police cordoned off the area. ``Duarte was everything for us, the women of the markets, for all the poor. .. For us he will live forever,'' said one woman trying to reach the coffin. She asked not to be identified. U.S. and regional leaders praised Duarte's dedication to democracy. ``President Duarte was the father of Salvadoran democracy, a dedicated servant to the people of El Salvador, and a firm friend of the United States,'' said a statement issued in Washington by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Vice President Dan Quayle will lead the U.S. delegation at Duarte's funeral, the White House said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said, ``There could be no more fitting tribute to his memory than for his countrymen to follow his lead and to ensure that human rights and democratic institutions grow and strengthen in the country he loved so deeply and to which he gave so much.'' Duarte was born in San Salvador Nov. 23, 1925, the second of three sons of a tailor father and dressmaker mother. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1948 with a degree in civil engineering, married a childhood friend, Ines Duran, and worked in her family's construction business. He served three terms as mayor of San Salvador. He was winning the presidential election in February 1972 when the army stopped the count and declared its candidate the winner. After supporting a failed coup attempt a few weeks later, Duarte was arrested, beaten and sent into exile in Venezuela, where he spent more than seven years. After reform-minded military officers seized power in a 1979 coup, Duarte returned to El Salvador, and in 1980 he became president of the ruling junta. Duarte tried to institute a land reform and other economic changes but these were hampered by growing violence from leftist guerrillas, the military, and military-linked rightists _ all of whom tried to destabilize his fragile government. Elected president in 1984, Duarte enjoyed wide popularity and opened peace talks with the guerrillas that year. The negotiations failed, however, and a plague of problems that accompanied the war _ accusations of corruption, economic failure, a devastating 1986 earthquake, parching drought _ overwhelmed his government. In May 1988, doctors diagnosed the cancer and removed 60 percent of Duarte's stomach, but the disease had spread to his liver. They gave him from six to 18 months to live. He finished his five-year term, but his last public appearance was the inauguration last year of his successor, Alfredo Cristiani, the rightist president whose party represented the oligarchy Duarte had struggled against. Duarte's death, said Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez, ``leaves a gap in the ranks of the great forgers of Latin American democracy and most especially in Central America.'' Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, head of El Salvador's armed forces chiefs of staff, said history would remember Duarte as ``a fighter who had all the forces necessary to carry out a democratic process.'' ``It is the loss of a person who fought all his life for the democratization of the country,'' Ponce said as he arrived at the church. Ricardo Alvarenga, president of the Legislative Assembly and a member of the rightist Republican Nationalist Alliance that defeated Duarte's party in 1988 and 1989 elections, had no praise for Duarte even in death. ``Today we political adversaries aren't going to slight him,'' Alvarenga said. ``He will be judged by God and I hope God will have forgiven him.'' A high-ranking U.S. diplomat who served in El Salvador during most of Duarte's term said of him: ``He didn't work miracles, but he must be credited with instituting the democratic system itself. His great legacy is the transition. The rest pales by comparison.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced in Nation's Worst Drunken-Driving Accident
LaserPhoto LX1
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of killing 27 people in the nation's worst drunken-driving accident was sentenced to 16 years in prison, but one crash survivor said he should have been sent to jail for life. ``Sixteen years does not take the place of the friends I lost,'' said Tammy Darnell, breaking down in tears after Larry Mahoney was sentenced on Friday. Mahoney was quiet during the sentencing, but many of his relatives burst into tears. His 7-year-old daughter, Shawna, a victim of spina bifida, began wailing after the sentence was read. Mahoney, 36, can be eligible for parole in eight years. Carroll Circuit Judge Charles Satterwhite denied a defense motion to place Mahoney on probation and handed down the sentence recommended by the jury, which convicted him more than two months ago. Telling the packed courtroom that while few may remember what is said at the hearing, ``I doubt that anyone will ever forget what brought us here.'' The defense plans to appeal. On May 14, 1988, Mahoney slammed into the front of a school bus packed with teen-agers on a church outing while driving in the wrong direction on Interstate 71. Twenty-four teens and three adults died. He was convicted of 27 counts each of second-degree manslaughter and first-degree wanton endangerment, 12 counts of first-degree assault, 14 of second-degree wanton endangerment and one of drunken driving. Defense lawyer William Summers urged Satterwhite to grant probation to bring something positive from the tragedy. The defense recommended a probation plan under which Mahoney would have lectured schoolchildren about the dangers of drunken driving, served volunteer time in hospital emergency wards, and spent one year in a work release program. ``Judge, we must do as much good with this as we possibly can. His punishment has already been dealt. He already has been given a life sentence,'' Summers said, referring to Mahoney's suffering since the crash. But prosecutor Paul Richwalsky Jr. of the state attorney general's office vehemently opposed probation, saying, ``Regardless of statements the defense would make, it's time for punishment.'' Mahoney ``alone is responsible. He alone brought us to this place today,'' he said. Jim Daugherty, Mahoney's brother-in-law, said the chemical plant worker had held out some hope for probation but was not particularly upset. ``He's resigned himself to it, I think,'' Daugherty said. Parents of some of the 24 children killed in the crash held a news conference after the sentencing to urge passage of a package of stiff drunken-driving laws pending in the Kentucky General Assembly. Some of the victims and their families expressed satisfaction Mahoney was sentenced, while others said wounds from the tragedy were slow to heal. ``Probation would have left a real sour taste in my mouth,'' said Mickey Muller, whose daughter Katrina was injured in the crash. ``Our poor children don't have probation.'' ``This is not over today,'' said Gary Atherton, whose daughter, Cynthia, died in the fiery wreck. ``It's not over for the rest of our lives.'' During the trial, jurors heard Mahoney issue a dramatic public apology. He said he had no recollection of colliding with the bus, and broke down into tears when disfigured survivors testified of horror and panic inside the flaming bus. The collision punctured the bus's gas tank, shooting a stream of flaming gasoline inside the bus. Defense attorneys argued the bus was unsafe because of insufficent safety exits and had a fuel tank placed in a crash-prone location. They also contended fire-retardant seat cushions and covers could have limited the fire's rapid spread and the toxic smoke which passengers inhaled.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Announces Pizza Topping Recall Because of Broken Glass
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department says a Kansas company has issued a nationwide recall of approximately 106,000 pounds of frozen pork pizza topping because it may contain light bulb fragments. The product was made by Doskocil Sausage Co. and was sold exclusively to food service facilities, including restaurants and carryouts, the department said Friday. It is not available in packages sold directly to consumers. Products include ``Leprino Foods Pizza Topping Mix'' with the code NOV13891131, and ``Pizzano Cooked Italian Style Pizza Topping'' with a code of NOV13891548 or NOV20891548. Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service said both products were shipped in cartons containing five-pound bags. The establishment number 623 was stamped on the cartons and bags. Crawford said distributors and food service operators who have any of the suspected products should return them to suppliers. The company began the recall after receiving four complaints, one on Jan. 15 and three on Feb. 13, about broken glass in pizza topping, Crawford said. There have been no reports of contaminated products being consumed. People with questions about the recall were advised to call the USDA's toll-free meat and poultry hotline at 1-800-535-4555, which operates from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EST Monday through Friday.
DOC.HEAD: Ed Gray Questioned
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee has questioned a former top thrift regulator in an investigation of five senators who intervened with banking officials on behalf of Lincoln Savings and Loan. Edwin J. Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said he met with the committee for four hours Friday behind closed doors and ``they might choose to invite me back.'' Gray declined to discuss his testimony. All five senators under scrutiny _ Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John McCain, R-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. and John Glenn, D-Ohio _ have denied wrongdoing. The committee's investigation is still in its preliminary stage. Sources familiar with the overall investigation said the committee appears to be exploring all possible relationships between the senators and Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr., the former head of Lincoln, based in Irvine, Calif. Gray testified last November that four of the senators asked him, in a private meeting on April 2, 1987, to drop a proposed regulation that would have curtailed risky investments by Lincoln. In return, he told the House Banking Committee, the four would get ``their friend'' Keating to make more home loans. Gray identified the four as DeConcini, Glenn, Cranston and McCain, and described the offer as ``a quid pro quo.'' Those senators and Riegle met a week later to discuss the case with the San Francisco examiners, who were investigating Lincoln and recommending its seizure by the government.
DOC.HEAD: Air Force Secretary Calls Unflattering Report `Hypercritical'
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Secretary Donald Rice says a congressional report contending his service had grossly understated the costs of major weapons was ``hypercritical and inflammatory.'' ``The ... report offers a narrow, CPA's view of the information needed for defense decision-making that has limited relationship to the real problems of defense management,'' Rice said in a three-page letter to the head of the General Accounting Office, Charles Bowsher. The letter was released Friday, the same day Bowsher told a Senate committee Friday the Air Force's accounting system fails to provide accurate cost data for almost 80 percent of its weapons, inventory and equipment. ``We roughly estimate that equipment and missiles are misstated by billions of dollars and aircraft and inventories are misstated by tens of billions of dollars,'' he told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. Bowsher testified as the GAO released its 109-page audit of the Air Force's accounting and financial management system. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio and chairman of the panel, noted that the GAO chose to audit the Air Force because it is the only armed service to develop financial statements that are in accord with accounting practices elsewhere in the federal government. ``If the Air Force does indeed have the best financial management system among the services, then the audit results are an indictment of the financial management systems of the whole Department of Defense _ the Army, the Navy, as well as the Air Force,'' Glenn said. The Ohio Democrat also used the hearing to question Bowsher about Rice's previously unreleased Feb. 15 letter to him. The Air Force secretary wrote that the service volunteered to work with the GAO on the audit and ``in return, the GAO writes a hypercritical and inflammatory report.'' ``I urge you to send your team back to the drawing board with instructions to prepare a report that fairly evaluates the pros and cons of GAO's approach and which uses Air Force data only as a test case for a new approach,'' Rice said.
DOC.HEAD: Justice Department to Appeal Ruling Supporting Flag-Burning
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department says it will ask the Supreme Court to overrule a federal judge's finding that a law banning flag burning is unconstitutional. Spokesman David Runkel said Friday that Justice Department attorneys will file a notice in Seattle federal court of the government's plan to appeal Wednesday's ruling by U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein. The judge dismissed criminal charges against four people arising from a flag-burning incident, saying the law passed last year by Congress violated constitutional free-speech protections. Congress enacted the law after the high court last year threw out a similar Texas statute on the same constitutional ground. President Bush proposed a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning but allowed the bill passed by Congress without signing it. Despite the administration's preference for a constitutional amendment, the Justice Department has a duty to defend the law, Runkel said.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Americans Die In Two Helicopter Crashes
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are investigating the crashes of two U.S. Army helicopters in Panama that killed all 11 servicemen aboard, the Southern Command said. The two helicopters, on a training mission, crashed during a thunderstorm Wednesday night, a Southern Command statement said Friday. An investigation is being conducted but sabotage is not suspected, said Southern Command spokeswoman Marjorie Boggs. The wreckage of the first helicopter, an OH-58, was found Thursday near Punta Diego, about 50 miles southwest of the city of Colon, the statement said. The city is at the Atlantic Ocean end of the Panama Canal. The dead in the OH-58 were identified as the pilot, Warrant Officer James W. Carl, of the 228th Aviation Regiment at Fort Kobbe in Panama, and Capt. Richard Tyndall, of the 7th Infantry Division (Light), at Fort Ord, Calif. Tyndall was a passenger on the flight. Searchers on Friday found the second helicopter, a UH1H Huey, in dense jungle about 55 miles southwest of Colon, the statement said. All four crew members and the five passengers were dead, it said. A spokeswoman said the passengers also were U.S. military personnel. Their names were withheld pending notification of relatives. Both helicopters were based at Fort Kobbe, adjacent to Howard Air Base. The aircraft were on a training mission when they encountered the thunderstorms, rare during the current dry season. An earlier statement said the OH-58 exploded, but also blamed the storm. The last communication with the aircraft was Wednesday night, the statement said. Planes, helicopters and infantry troops searched for the wreckage. The victims were among about 13,500 U.S. troops currently assigned in Panama, about the number that were there before the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that ousted Manuel Antonio Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrities, Countries Donate Items to Help Business School
DOC.TEXT: Convicted drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas has been up to his old game of smuggling, but this time it's for an auction to raise money for college scholarships. Lehder, who is serving a life sentence at the maximum security federal prison in Marion, Ill., sent a signed transcript from his sentencing hearing to benefit business students at Miami-Dade Community College. He smuggled the transcript out by mailing it to ``attorney'' Ed Krohn, the chairman of the college's business administration department who sought the celebrity donations. The transcript is among more than 1,100 items of memorabilia donated by celebrities for the school, including a sun visor from Cher, an engraved silver candy dish from Paul Newman and a pen from President Bush. Jonas Salk sent an autographed copy of a 1955 report on polio. There also are flags from Belize, Lesotho, Liechtenstein and Qatar and a post card of Monaco's royal family for today's auction. Also, there is an autographed airline boarding pass from Mother Teresa and a picture book of former East German president Erich Honecker _ mailed before the fall of his government. And there's Vanna White's black velvet dress. ``Bless her,'' Krohn said. He used that gift as an example to inspire others to donate. ``Miami-Dade has the largest number of minority students and foreign students of any college in the U.S., and those people need money,'' he said Friday. ``We're doing it to raise money for their scholarships.'' Not everyone who was asked complied. ``I don't think the people of Miami would appreciate anything from me at this time,'' said Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Texas Air, parent of the ailing Miami-based Eastern Airlines. Even so, Eastern donated a pair of tickets to be given away as a door prize.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Allowed to Challenge Screening Process
DOC.TEXT: Six Vietnamese were granted legal permission today to challenge the screening process that decides which boat people are to be returned to their Communist homeland against their will, government radio said. The six maintain that the screening system is flawed and unjust, the report said. The British colony, in an attempt to discourage Vietnamese from sailing here, considers all boat people to be illegal immigrants unless they can prove a well-founded fear of persecution back home. Under the screening process, which has been criticized by some human rights groups, each Vietnamese is interviewed by immigration officers who decide whether the applicant is a refugee or illegal immigrant. A final decision is made by an appeal board that sits in private and does not have to explain its decisions. Boat people are not present at the appeal hearings. About 10 percent of the boat people who have gone through the process have been granted refugee status, according to government statistics. The rest are to be sent home. A first group of 51 boat people were repatriated against their will in December, but no more Vietnamese have been forced back since because of objections raised by the United States and Hanoi. The radio did not say when the court hearing for the six will take place. Their case could have signficant repercussions on the screening process.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery of Girl Will Open International Legal Battle
