DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 8th graf prv, beginning, ``Foretich could not xxx with 5 new grafs, beginning, ``Foretich said xxx to update with father's comments
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Morgan will seek an open court hearing in New Zealand, where she sent her daughter into hiding, on allegations that her husband abused 7-year-old Hilary, her family says. ``The truth will have a lot of chance of coming out,'' Elizabeth Morgan's older brother was quoted as saying in today's editions of The Washington Post. Morgan, who spent 25 months in jail rather than let her former husband visit the girl, told the Post she is hoping for a new hearing on her allegations that Eric Foretich sexually abused the girl during court-ordered visits in the Washington area. Foretich has strongly denied the charges and contends his former wife is mentally ill. Detective Chief Inspector Roger Carson of Christchurch, New Zealand, said the girl is in the custody of her grandparents there and that there will be a hearing on the issue next week in the city's family court. ``I've not felt the legal system in Washington, D.C., had listened to the evidence,'' Morgan told the newspaper. ``I didn't think I ever said that I trusted no legal system.'' Her lawyer, Stephen Sachs, said he will ask District of Columbia Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon on Monday to return Morgan's passport so she can go to New Zealand. Dixon is the judge who odered Morgan, 42, to jail in August 1987 for civil contempt when she refused to a court order to produce Hilary for supervised visits with Foretich. She was released from jail in Washington in September after President Bush signed a law limiting civil contempt in District of Columbia child abuse cases to 12 months. Foretich said he was ``elated'' that his daughter has been found and ``appears to be at least physically well.'' ``I would hope to obtain custody,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``That's obviously why I want to bring her back to Washington. I want to bring her back to the court in Washington where she belongs.'' But he said he has no illusions that gaining custody of the girl will be easy. ``Elizabeth Morgan is going to ... wage the same media battle that she's always done in the past,'' he said. ``She is undoubtedly a media person, she's a media queen. And she creates this illusion that I'm some kind of a pervert and she's going to try to do that down there as well and use the media to do it in hopes that that will influence the court.'' Foretich said he resents the publicity as much for his daughter as for himself. ``I don't think it's fair ... for my daughter to ... have her life made unnecessarily more public than it needs to be,'' he said. ``Elizabeth is going to do whatever she possibly can do to protect her daughter,'' Sachs told the Post. ``Elizabeth is confident that the courts of New Zealand will protect Hilary.'' Elizabeth Morgan, in the Post interview, declined to predict how the new court proceedings will go. ``I think time will tell,'' she said. ``It's early days.'' But James Morgan, her older brother, said she wants to introduce in open court the allegations of abuse that U.S. courts ruled against. ``We're awfully happy that we're going to have an open hearing in an open court, unlike the district, where everything was closed,'' James Morgan said.

DOC.HEAD: Hilary Foretich Located, Custody Battle Renews
With PM-Morgan-Girl
DOC.TEXT: A 7-year-old American girl, hidden by her mother during a highly publicized U.S. custody battle, was found living with her grandparents in New Zealand. Her father today said he tracked her down. Hilary Foretich has been living with her mother's parents in Christchurch for three years and is in good health, Roger Carson, the Christchurch detective chief inspector, said today. He said Hilary is the subject of a New Zealand Family Court order issued Friday. ``As a result of that order Hilary is now in the custody of her grandparents and there will be a further hearing in the Family Court in Christchurch next week,'' Carson said. He did not elaborate. The girl's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, a plastic surgeon, accused the father, Dr. Eric Foretich, of sexually abusing Hilary. She was jailed for 25 months from August 1987 for civil contempt of court for failing to obey a judge's order to produce the child. Foretich, a 46-year-old oral surgeon, had offered a $50,000 reward to anyone who could find his daughter. He has strongly denied ever abusing the child. ``I was the one who found my daughter,'' he said in a telephone interview early today from his home in Great Falls, Va., a Washington suburb. He said his lawyer in New Zealand went to court to ask for custody after private investigators on Friday helped ``make a positive identification.'' His account could not be independently confirmed. ``I'm elated,'' he said, but added that about obtaining custody: ``I don't have any illusions that this is going to be easy. ``I found my daughter with the help of investigative reporters,'' he said. ``I made several trips to England where I found information out.'' Last week, his lawyers obtained a court order in England that instructed the producer of a British talk show to investigate the girl's whereabouts after a caller said she recognized the girl's picture broadcast on the show, the Times of London reported Tuesday. Morgan's lawyer, Stephen H. Sachs, was quoted in today's Washington Post as saying, ``Elizabeth is going to do whatever she possibly can do to protect her daughter.'' ``Elizabeth is confident that the courts of New Zealand will protect Hilary, and Elizabeth will go to New Zealand as soon as (Washington D.C. Superior Court Judge Herbert B.) Dixon gives her back her passport, which we've requested several times, and we will renew the request on Monday.'' Dixon confiscated Morgan's passport before he jailed her in 1987. Morgan, 42, declined to predict the outcome of the New Zealand proceedings. ``I think time will tell,'' she said. Robert Callard, the U.S. consul in the New Zealand capital of Wellington, said the embassy's only role was to make sure the child is protected and that nobody tries to take her out of the country. Christchurch is 190 miles southwest of Wellington. Morgan had said she would go without seeing her daughter until the girl turned 18 if necessary to protect her. She was released from jail in Washington in September after President Bush signed a law limiting civil contempt in District of Columbia child abuse cases to 12 months. Morgan has married a federal appeals court judge, Paul R. Michel, since she was released. She and Foretich met in 1981, married in January 1982 and separated in August of that year, about a week before Hilary was born. In 1983 the divorced couple sued each other for custody of the child. In January 1985 Morgan took legal action to stop Foretich's access to Hilary after making the sexual abuse allegations. Hilary's picture was shown on a BBC program last year, when Foretich discussed the custody battle. The caller, the deputy headmistress at Beechfield College, a private girls' school at Plymouth in southwest England, said Hilary was a former pupil. The Times said the headmistress, Pat Holness, told the show's producer that the girl, who went under the name Ellen Morgan, was being looked after by her maternal grandparents, William and Antonia Morgan, during the time she attended the school. She left in summer 1988.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0451 to include writethru designator in slugline
US, Nicaragua Relations Face Change No Matter What
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th pvs, `In today's...' with 1 graf to ADD that Ortega referring to Salvadoran guerrillas. Picks up 15th pvs, `A senior...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Sandinista party is hoping that an election certified as fair by international observers will force the United States to end a decade of hostility even if the U.S. favorite loses. That would be a difficult adjustment for the United States, which views the Sandinistas as a disturbing and destabilizing leftist factor in the region, and for the Sandinistas, who have viewed the United States as an aggressor and an advocate of socially regressive policies. ``They will both have to change,'' said Erick Ramirez, the Social Christian Party's presidential candidate, in an interview. U.S. support is taken for granted if Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pulls what would be a stunning upset over President Daniel Ortega. U.S. aid is anticipated even if the United National Opposition cuts a deal that gives the Sandinistas control of the army and the Interior Ministry's police powers. But if the Sandinistas win it will be more problematic. The Sandinistas are desperate for U.S. recognition, which would pave the way for an end to the U.S.-sponsored Contra guerrilla movement, trigger negotiations with the Bush adminstration and eventually bring in U.S. aid and development dollars. ``But the first thing we need from the United States is peace,'' Ortega campaign manager Bayardo Arce said Thursday. Earlier Thursday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States will not automaticallay accept the judgments of international observers, even people like former President Jimmy Carter. As a second hedge he laid down a set of conditions in anticipation of a legitimate Sandinista victory. ``There will be no normalization until we see a substantial period of good behavior by the government,'' including a halt to support for leftist rebels in El Salvador and political freedom for the opposition in Nicaragua, Baker said. Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, once a harsh critic of the Sandinistas, said the United States should recognize the winner and ``start discussions with the new government.'' Nicaragua needs peace and development badly, Obando y Bravo said, and that can only come with U.S. help. At a Thursday press conference, Ortega was careful to be conciliatory even in the face of Baker's comments, refusing to discuss Baker's conditions and saying he hoped to initiate negotiations with the United States after he was re-elected. In today's editions of the New York Times, he was quoted as saying he would not provide arms to Salvadoran guerrillas after the elections, and he called El Salvador's rightist government ``legitimate.'' A senior Nicaraguan official who spoke on condition of anonymity voiced the Sandinistas' devout hope when he said, ``(President) Bush already threw a bone to the U.S. radical conservatives by invading Panama. He can afford to talk to Nicaragua now without looking weak.'' During the past year the Sandinistas have tried to shed their image as radical Marxists. The Sandinistas have pledged there will be no more expropriations of private property, repeatedly told private business they want a mixed economy, released political prisoners and reduced friction with the powerful Roman Catholic Church. Obando y Bravo, once a bitter critic, said the Sandinistas ``have changed. I believe there are some pragmatic people in the government. ... Circumstances here and abroad are forcing the FSLN (Sandinistas) to change.'' He was referring to the effects of liberalization and economic problems in Eastern Europe since Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev took power. On a practical level, the changes mean reduced subsidies and arms for Nicaragua; on an intellectual and political level they mean communism is no longer a credible alternative. Arce said some Sandinista economic policies of the past 10 years may have been wrong. A local joke has it that the Sandinistas will win to carry out the UNO economic program, although Ortega says he disagrees with policies that might lead to massive unemployment. Ortega also said Thursday that the United States should stop assisting the Contra guerrillas before pointing a finger at Nicaragua; although the U.S. halted arms shipments to them in 1988, non-lethal aid continues. Only about 3,500 rebels are thought to remain inside Nicaragua; the aid comes up for renewal after Sunday's election. ``The problem is that the United States has stayed with a contradictory international policy. They are getting closer to the Eastern European countries undergoing political reforms, but those types of reforms exist in Nicaragua already,'' said Victor Hugo Tinoco, the deputy foreign minister, in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadorans Crowd Church to Mourn Duarte
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS country to dateline
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of mourners today thronged a church to pay respects to former President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who tried and failed to ease the searing class divisions that sparked a crippling, decade-old civil war.
DOC.HEAD: Duarte died ... 2nd pvs
Harbor Reopened After Firefighters Remove Leaky Container of Gas
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters safely removed a leaky container of flammable gas aboard a cargo ship, clearing the way for the reopening of one of the world's busiest seaports. The harbor was reopened shortly before midnight Friday, said Pat Marek, a Fire Department spokesman. The closure had affected harbor traffic for about 24 hours. A 1{-mile stretch of the main channel of the Los Angeles Harbor was closed after gas was found to be leaking from a 2,000-pound cylinder deep in the cargo hold of a freighter. Firefighters on Friday night began removing containers from the ship's cargo hold to reach the leaking container of trifluoropropene, Marek said. ``We were able to get down into the ship to determine the explosive environment,'' fire battalion Chief Leon Pursell said. ``We found it to be free of the flammable liquids. ... That allowed us to get in there and start to remove the containers.'' The leaking container was about 40 feet down in the cargo hold of the 882-foot Taiwanese vessel owned by Evergreen Shipping Co. The closure was the first in 12 years at the nation's top container shipping port. Coast Guard officials said the harbor shutdown did not affect the harbor's vital container ship traffic as much as pleasure boat traffic. ``Most of the container ships were already at anchor and unloading'' when officials discovered the gas leak, Coast Guard petty officer Tim Rowe said. However, two cruise ships, which normally use the channel to load and unload passengers, were forced to berth at adjacent Long Beach Harbor.

DOC.HEAD: Army Deserter: `I Threw 30 Years of My Life Away'
LaserPhoto AH2
DOC.TEXT: An Army deserter who believes he ``threw 30 years of my life away'' by fleeing to East Germany in 1959 said the changes in the United States have left him slack-jawed with amazement. Arnold Kephart, 53, who fled to East Germany fearing punishment after wrecking an Army truck, said adjustment to U.S. society has made him feel a bit like a latter-day Rip van Winkle. ``The first time I saw one of those,'' Kephart said, pointing to a microwave oven, ``I thought it was a TV. Then someone came along, opened it up, and put food in. I couldn't believe he was putting food in the TV.'' In an interview Friday at the home of his brother-in-law, Arlo Dunbar, Kephart said he regretted his decision to enter East Germany only a few weeks after settling in Schmalkalind, he town where he lived for 30 years. ``It was like you were locked up all the time. I never really ever felt at home,'' said the former Army private, who said he twice unsuccessfully tried to escape the country. ``I feel like I threw 30 years of my life away,'' he said. Before his second escape attempt in 1975, Kephart drank ``enough beer to get my courage up and so I'd have an excuse if I got caught,'' he said. Three guards grabbed him as he approached the border, beat him, and sent him back to town, Kephart said. ``After that, I didn't think about trying the border again,'' Kephart said. A year after the escape attempt he met his second wife, Brigitte. She is the mother of Frankie, now 12 and in the United States with his father, and Kephart's 8-year-old twin daughters, Katharina and Kathleen. He has another child from his first marriage in East Germany. The family lived in a small house, Kephart said. Their diet was meager: bread with some bologna-like meat for breakfast, soup and potatoes for lunch. Dinner was a reprise of breakfast, he said. ``You could seldom get eggs,'' he said. ``And the meat in the store, when you could get it, a lot of times had a bad color, like it was old.'' He said the country he has returned to is a ``different world.'' ``Here, everybody has a phone,'' Kephart noted with amazement in a voice heavy with a German accent. On returning to the United States last month, the Army arrested him at the airport as he was being reunited with relatives. He was granted an other-than-honorable discharge a week later. Kephart, who earned a living driving trucks in East Germany, could not believe the interstate highway system when he saw it. He recently drove about 50 miles south from here to Rock Port, Mo., just to test Interstate 29. He said he is enjoying foods he sorely missed. ``I always loved chili,'' he said. ``And pork and beans. They just don't have anything like that over there.'' A deal for a television movie of Kephart's life has been closed, according to his attorney, James Martin Davis. He wouldn't reveal details. Kephart said he now will be try to rebuild his life in Council Bluffs, a southwestern Iowa community. His second marriage ended in divorce in 1988, but he said he wants to remarry Brigitte, bring her and his daughters to the United States and work as a truck driver. He wrote all of this in a letter to his former wife, and now awaits her reply.

DOC.HEAD: New Program Lets New Englanders Pay Federal Taxes With Credit Cards
DOC.TEXT: New England residents who find they haven't saved enough money to pay their federal taxes this year have a penalty-free way out of that dilemma _ charge it. A Southern California company is launching a test program in New England next week that will allow taxpayers to use a Visa, MasterCard or Discovery Card to pay their taxes. The new service, called InstaPay, is being offered by a two-year-old company called InstaTax, one of several companies the Internal Revenue Service has allowed to participate in the new program. It's part of a new IRS electronic payment program called Automatic Deposit of Electronic Payments for Taxes, which will be available to taxpayers in Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. ``This is a convenient way for people who are surprised by their tax return and don't have the money on savings to pay their taxes,'' InstaTax president Donald D. Cook said Friday. ``If they charge it on their credit card, they can begin making payments and avoid penalties from the IRS.'' Taxpayers filing forms 1040EZ, 1040A or 1040 are eligible for the program if they have sufficient credit available on their Visa, MasterCard or Discover Card credit cards to cover their taxes owed and processing fees. Their 1989 tax return also must show a balance due and each person listed on the return must have been living on Jan. 1. The service is available at Mail Boxes Etc. retail outlets or the office of a participating paid tax preparer. The customer fills out an InstaTax Order Form, signs a copy of the terms and conditions receipt and must complete an IRS form. The person then gives the documents, along with their 1989 tax return and W-2 forms, to a clerk who checks the information for accuracy. After payment is received for filing the return electronically, the clerk sends the documents to San Diego-based InstaTax. The firm's minimum fee for filing the return is $29.95. InstaTax will file the customer's tax return electronically with the IRS within 24 hours of receipt. Customers receive a postcard informing them of the date the IRS accepted their return. When the customer uses the credit card to pay the taxes, InstaTax will charge the credit card company and use San Diego Trust & Savings Bank to act as its agent. The bank, like other financial institutions and businesses involved in the program, will transmit tax payments to the Boston Federal Reserve Bank for crediting with the U.S. Treasury. Cook believes this pilot program is the wave of the tax-paying future. ``The IRS is limiting the project to the six New England states this year, but in a few years, I think, all you'll have to do in signing a return is to give a credit card number when you send it in,'' he said. Frank Burgess, head of the Automated Clearing House financial network of the IRS, did not return phone calls Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Monday Layoffs Loom for 4,200 GM Workers in 3 States
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is scaling back production at three assembly plants, idling about 4,200 workers. The layoffs, announced Friday, are part of a wave of cutbacks by major automakers in a season of slow sales. Starting Monday, GM said it will eliminate one of two shifts at each of its car assembly plants in Doraville, Ga., and Linden, N.J., resulting in 1,900 and 1,600 layoffs respectively. The nation's largest automaker also will trim production at its assembly plant in Fairfax, Kan., causing about 700 layoffs. ``There's an air of despondency,'' said Guy Messina, a shop chairman for United Auto Workers Local 595 in Linden, where Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta cars are made. ``It finally sunk in that these are their last days.'' But the expected idling of other autoworkers will be put off. GM said Friday the planned mid-March shutdown of the Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta would be pushed back to between April 1 and July 1 because of a pickup in sales of Buick Estate station wagons and 1990 Chevrolet Caprice cars. Chrysler spokesman Doug Nicoll said Friday that layoffs of 750 employees at an assembly plant in Belvidere, Ill., where luxury cars are made, and 780 layoffs at its factory in Newark, Del., where Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim cars are assembled, will be put off indefinitely. The layoffs originally were scheduled to take effect March 19. Ford Motor Co. has avoided indefinite layoffs by increasing its capacity during the boom years of 1985-88 through overtime at existing plants rather than opening new factories. Automakers use plant shutdowns and production reductions to bring factory output in line with the inventories of new, unsold cars on dealer and plant lots. Automakers have said they expect slower sales through at least the first half of this year with a rebound later. Sales tumbled in October as the 1990 model year began. In January, the pace picked up, mainly because of incentives on Chrysler's popular minivans. Those offers expired Jan. 31, and the rate of sales since then has fallen. On Friday, the Big Three reported their mid-February sales of cars and light trucks were running 15.8 percent behind last year's pace. Since Jan. 1, with effects of Chrysler minivan incentives figured in, the sales pace was running 0.2 percent ahead of last year. Throughout January, the Big Three automakers shut down dozens of their plants for at least a week apiece to cut inventory. The move apparently worked as inventory levels fell from around 90 selling days' worth at the end of December to about 70 days at the end last month. But that's not enough to stop the layoffs. Like GM, Chrysler is shutting down entire plants this year _ its Jefferson Assembly factory in Detroit closed Feb. 2, resulting in 1,700 layoffs, and its St. Louis car plant cut a shift earlier this month and will shut down totally Sept. 21. In all, 3,700 St. Louis employees will be laid off. Workers placed on indefinite layoff status may qualify for a variety of programs designed to give them temporary benefits equal to about 95 percent of their take-home pay. However, UAW officials have said that the benefit funds are currently lower than what is needed to maintain that compensation level.

DOC.HEAD: Lion Tears Off Part of Owner's Arm
DOC.TEXT: A caged lion ripped off part of its owner's arm while the animal keeper was feeding the African cat, authorities said. Charles McEntire, 57, was listed in stable condition Friday after undergoing surgery at Riverside Community Hospital, said a hospital spokeswoman. Sheriff's deputies and California Department of Forestry rescue personnel were called to McEntire's Glen Avon exotic animal compound late Thursday and found him with his left arm severed at the elbow, said Riverside County Sheriff's Lt. Dan Borden. McEntire was licensed to possess exotic animals. A warden from the state Fish and Game Department was investigating the mauling.

DOC.HEAD: New Bank Note Issued
DOC.TEXT: Poland will issue a 100,000 zloty note as part of efforts to accommodate the soaring inflation that has accompanied economic reform, the official news agency PAP reported today. The banknote, to be introduced Monday, will be worth $10.50, the report said. It is the second largest in circulation, after the recently introduced 200,000 zloty note. The Polish National Bank note was being produced in December but had to be redesigned after the country's name was changed from the Polish People's Republic to the Republic of Poland, the news agency said. The banknote honors Stanislaw Moniuszko, a 19th century opera composer. Poland has been struggling with triple digit inflation since last year, following the lifting of controls that had kept prices unrealistically low through government subsidies to unprofitable state enterprises. In January alone, the inflation rate was about 79 percent, but economists forecast an easing of inflation during the next six months as efforts to transform the socialist economy into a market-driven system take hold.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Hits Sister Twice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Viola Ditto is cq
DOC.TEXT: An 86-year-old driver accidentally hit her 84-year-old sister twice while backing a car out of her driveway, authorities said. Viola Ditto was in critical condition Friday at Hemet Valley Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. Marjorie Smith was waiting to take Ditto for a drive Thursday when she backed out of her driveway to look for her sister, said Officer Dan Tarnoski of the Hemet Police Department. The sisters live near each other at a mobile home park in this city about 85 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. When she didn't see Ditto, Smith drove back up the driveway, Tarnoski said. Minutes later, Smith again backed out. She then spotted Ditto lying in the street, Tarnoski said. He said Smith's car apparently knocked Ditto down the first time she backed out. The car ran over Ditto's legs the second time, Tarnoski said. Smith was not cited, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I've given a lot of thought to how the system could be beat. I haven't yet been able to come up with a good scheme.'' _ Elliott Richardson, former U.S. attorney general, who is heading a U.N. observer mission to ensure fair results in Sunday's Nicaraguan elections.
``I feel like I threw 30 years of my life away.'' _ Arnold Kephart, 53, who deserted the U.S. Army and fled to East Germany in 1959 fearing punishment after wrecking an Army truck.

``Sixteen years does not take the place of the friends I lost.'' _ Tammy Darnell, a survivor of the nation's worst drunken-driving accident, after Larry Mahoney was sentenced to 16 years for the 1988 crash in which he slammed into a school bus on a church outing, killing 24 teen-agers and three adults.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Calls For $680 Million Rice Fund For Emergency Aid
DOC.TEXT: The governing party proposed Japan spend hundreds of millions of dollars on foreign rice over five years but use the rice only for foreign aid and not on the heavily subsidized domestic market, officials said today. Millions of tons of rice would be purchased, mainly from the United States, Thailand and Singapore, said Takashi Sato, chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party's Comprehensive Agriculture Research Commission, who proposed the plan. The $680 million plan calls for construction of rice stockpiles in each country, filled with rice purchased by Japan, said Hajime Kondo, an aide to Sato. Kondo said the project would show Japan's willingness to buy rice and contribute to those suffering but not to import foreign rice for domestic consumption. ``We will never liberalize rice imports. We will never, ever allow a single foreign rice grain into our nation,'' Kondo said. The government regulates the domestic rice market, buying much of the rice crop and reselling it to consumers at subsidized prices. Those prices are still several times higher than the world market level. Sato's plan, proposed to begin in April 1991, calls for foreign rice to be added to the list of items to be donated to countries requiring emergency support. The Japanese Red Cross Society will handle the donations, he said. ``We don't want to just give away money and be seen as arrogant,'' Kondo said. The government budgeted $68,000 during fiscal 1990 for feasibility studies. Japan has been trying to persuade its trading partners to accept its existing agricultural trade policy in the current Uruguay round of multilateral trade talks, without success so far. In September 1988, both houses of Parliament unanimously adopted a non-binding resolution against opening the nation's rice market to foreign imports. The resolution said rice production was vital for local communities, the preservation of land and Japanese culture.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed at District of Columbia Nightclub
DOC.TEXT: Four people were killed in a shooting early today at a nightclub in a Washington neighborhood that is a frequent scene of drug-related violence, police said. Three were dead at the scene and the fourth was dead upon arrival at a hospital, officers said. At least two other people were wounded. Police said they were not certain what sparked the shooting, which occurred shortly before 2 a.m. Bystanders told reporters that a gunman just walked into the club and started shooting. The identities of the victims were not immediately available and there were no reported arrests. The attack took place at a club called ``John's Place,'' which was described as a ``hole in the wall'' by a fire department official who declined to allow his name to be used.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Industry Layoffs this Year
With PM-Auto Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of car and truck final assembly plants scheduled to indefinitely suspend all or part of their production in 1990 as announced by automakers. The location of the plant is followed by the approximate number of hourly and salaried employees and the start of shutdowns. All are car plants unless otherwise specified.

Doraville, Ga., 1,900 of 4,500, Feb. 26. Fairfax, Kan., 700 of 4,200, Feb. 26. Lakewood (Atlanta), Ga., all 2,200, April-June. Linden, N.J., 1,600 of 3,600, Feb. 26. Oklahoma City, 600 of 6,000, March 26. Wilmington, Del., 450 of 3,700, Jan. 16.
Jefferson Avenue (Detroit), all 1,700, Feb. 2. St. Louis No. 1, 1,900 of 3,700, Feb. 12. St. Louis No. 1, remaining 1,800, Sept. 21. Toledo, Ohio, truck, 700 of 5,300, April 9.

DOC.HEAD: Mountain of Ice Builds; Maine Bureaucrats Stumped on Snow Removal
LaserPhoto AD1
DOC.TEXT: One might think Maine's largest city would have snow removal refined to an art form, bng snow into a shorefront mountain. But officials now acknowledge that the mass of dirty ice will carry some of the sand and salt into the cove, which drains into Casco Bay, already one of the region's most polluted harbors. The state and city reached a two-year agreement that calls for the snow to be piled up next to the cove while the city conducts an environmental impact study. State environmental officials were concerned especially about keeping the sand out of the cove in order to comply with pollution standards set up the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Hydrocarbon tests on the snow and a study of clams, mussels and microorganisms in the area should be completed by spring. Portland Public Works Director George Flaherty hopes by then to have convinced the state that it is safe to dump the snow into the bay instead of piling it high. ``We felt it hasn't caused a problem,'' he said. Phil Garwood of the state Department of Environmental Protection, who does not think the city should dump any snow into the bay, said the snow pile will lessen the pollutants that go into the waters because the mountain is surrounded by a fine-mesh fence. The fence is designed to let melting snow get through while trapping large particles of dirt and pollutants. ``Some of the trash will no doubt blow into Back Cove,'' he said. Garwood said some Canadian cities are better at handling their polluted snow than their U.S. counterparts. Quebec, for example, has a snow dump that resembles a coliseum, where the snow is allowed to melt and the remaining particles of pollutants are then disposed of. But Portland has nowhere but the bay to put the snow because most city land is used as parks, where salt from the snow could harm vegetation and ground water, Flaherty said. The mountain also has developed into an eyesore, some say. ``I think it's pretty disgusting,'' said Beth Ravenelle, a teacher from Saco who has watched the pile of snow and debris get taller and taller during her frequent jogs along the water. ``We've just watched this thing grow all winter,'' said another jogger, John Williams, a local scientist who sometimes makes his exercise course more interesting by running right over the mound of snow that has been packed into a hard ice by 35-ton bulldozers. The mountain of ice has grown so big that officials expect it to last until mid-summer. This season so far has brought 58.3 inches of snow _ 3.1 inches more than normal for Portland. ``My guess is probably mid-July,'' Flaherty said. He said City Hall workers talk of setting up their own betting pool for predicting the demise of the mound they have christened ``Flaherty's Mountain.'' ``You might as well call it something,'' Flaherty said. ``I have another name for it, but we sure don't put it in the press.''

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Descends on Northeast, Midwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Temperature tables unavailable due to technical problem; will be led if they become available
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell from Michigan to Kentucky to Maine today as a cold front blasted out of the nation's midsection on 55 mph gusts, dragging down temperatures from the Great Lakes to the Northeast. Weekend readings in the Northeast were expected to be 15 to 30 degrees colder than Friday's and the coldest since December. Temperatures tonight will dip below zero as far south as Illinois. Between 5 and 10 inches of fresh snow were likely from northern Pennsylvania and southern New York to New England before ending tonight. Drier, cold air replaced soggy warm air in the Deep South. On Friday, 12 Alabama counties were added to an earlier emergency relief declaration after two weeks of drenching storms. Nine Georgia counties were declared disaster areas because of tornadoes and floods. High water continued to threaten Mississippi's Gulf Coast, and residents in lowland Indiana helped seal off neighborhoods from flood waters with sandbags. Warnings of heavy snow and storms were issued today for Michigan's Upper Peninsula, northern Lower Michigan and northwestern Indiana. Gusty winds up to 55 mph lashed northwestern Iowa on Friday. Temperatures Friday were again unseasonably warm over parts of the Atlantic states. Record highs set for the date include 56 in Portland, Maine; 61 in Worcester, Mass.; 62 in New York City; and 65 in Boston. Friday's high temperature for the nation was 88 at West Palm Beach, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Networks to Pool Exit Polls
DOC.TEXT: The three major television networks and Cable News Network have agreed to create a single exit poll for election days, according to a published report. Two senior network officials told The New York Times that the networks agreed to cooperate to cut costs and to avoid the competition that has resulted in predictions of winners before all votes are cast. CBS, NBC, ABC and CNN are to be equal partners in the group, which is to be called Voter Research and Surveys, the Times said in today's editions. Each network is to receive the same information at the same time on election days, the newspaper said. A public announcement is expected next week. Spokesmen for the four networks said they could not officially confirm the agreement, the Times said. Observers said the group polling would cut down on the competition to be the first network to declare a winner. ``There's a public perception that such early projections are a disenfranchisement of the West Coast,'' since results have been announced there before voting concluded, said Eleanor Singer, a research scientist at Columbia University. But the newspaper quoted network executives as saying that saving money was the driving force behind the pooled polling. Each network will chip in $3 million to operate the service on primary and general election days until the next presidential election in 1992. One executive said a single network might spend $12 million on polling in that time. It was unclear how the arrangement will affect other news organizations, such as newspapers, who have teamed up with networks in past polls.

DOC.HEAD: Burning Suspect to Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of setting his ex-wife's boyfriend on fire was ordered to stand trial for possession of an illegal weapon and criminal mischief, officials said. An attempted homicide charge against John P. Hatbob, 36, was dropped by District Justice Richard Olasz Jr. during a hearing Thursday. The victim, Charles Pickford, 42, of West Mifflin remained in serious condition Friday at West Penn Hospital in Pittsburgh with burns over 23 percent of his body. Police said the fire began when Hatbob started burning photographs of his ex-wife, Barbara Hatbob, in front of her home. When Pickford confronted him, the two began scuffling and Pickford was burned, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesotan Named School Superintendent of the Year
DOC.TEXT: Donald Draayer, a Minnesota school official who says going the extra mile is ``simply the way we do business,'' has been named National Superintendent of the Year. Draayer, superintendent of the Minnetonka Public Schools in Excelsior, Minn., was awarded a gold medallion, a $1,000 U.S. Savings Bond and a $10,000 college scholarship check for donation to the high school where he graduated. Draayer, 54, was selected over three other finalists from a field of 46 states. The awards were announced Friday during opening ceremonies of the American Association of School Administrators annual convention. Other finalists were James Bergera of the Provo City School District in Utah; Shirley Holloway of the North Slope Borough School District, Barrow, Alaska; and G. Thomas Houlihan of the Granville County Schools in Oxford, N.C.

DOC.HEAD: Councilman's Answer to Drug Problem: Controlled Distribution
DOC.TEXT: A City Council resolution to study whether distributing illegal drugs free would cut down on crime has drawn ridicule from politicians and law enforcement officials. Councilman John Street offered the resolution Thursday calling for reports on the legal and medical implications of a drug distribution system. The resolution was routinely and unanimously approved without discussion. But some councilmen said later they were unaware of the resolution's content, and denounced the measure. One councilman said the resolution would go to a committee _ and stay there. ``What they are proposing is a violation of state law and a violation of federal law,'' District Attorney Ronald Castille said Friday. ``If they try to distribute free cocaine and other drugs to anyone, they will be arrested.'' Mayor W. Wilson Goode urged the council to reconsider, saying the study would waste his administration's time and siphon money away from drug treatment and education programs. Pennsylvania Attorney General Ernest Preate called the resolution ``absurb.'' ``You're going to be diverting people who should be out there in the fight against drugs to find ways to make Philadelphia the drug capital of the United States,'' he said. The resolution calls for reports from the city's police and health commissioners, prison and school superintendents, judges and district attorney on the legal and medical implications of giving addicts drugs at low or no cost to see if they can be cured of their habit. ``I think other tools should be brought into the arsenal of government against this terrible drug situation,'' Street said. ``It's stupid; it's nuts,'' said Councilwoman Joan Krajewski. Councilman James Tayoun said, ``He's an idiot.'' But Councilman Thacher Longstreth thinks the idea is worth a shot. ``We had a treatment program using methadone to help heroin users, and that didn't do well,'' Longstreth said. ``But it's always worth investigating. My initial reaction is maybe it's time to experiment again.'' Street insisted he was not advocating the legalization of drugs. ``We don't have enough treatment. We don't have enough police. We don't have enough courtrooms to try those arrested. We don't have enough jails. So there's got to be additional things to do,'' he said. ``My idea is strictly to look into the idea of legalizing drugs for treatment purposes only.'' Councilman Lucien Blackwell said the resolution would be assigned to the Health Committee for a hearing and will not emerge. ``We do have a drug problem. I think we should discuss it. But giving drug users more drugs to wean them off drugs won't work. You got to cut if off entirely,'' Blackwell said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese to Invest in ``Wild West'' Resort in Oklahoma
DOC.TEXT: Japanese investors will provide most of the financing for a theme park featuring Southwest history and culture such as Indian powwows and oil well development, a developer said. Charles Ohmori of BOSS Co. of Japan, who will tour the site in a couple of weeks, will select the investors, said Dallas developer Peggy O'Neal. ``I am trying to bring to the tourists the Indian, the cowboy, ranching, the prairie and oil, and do so authentically,'' Ms. O'Neal said. ``We will try to retain as much of being out on the prairie as possible. ``We want to put on powwows. There's nowhere to go year round to see powwows. We want to have them there.'' The complex will be called Indian Prairie and will include a 2,500-acre ranch. Groundbreaking for the park could begin within a year, Ms. O'Neal said. Michael Jenkins, president of Leisure and Recreation Concepts of Dallas, is designing the master plan for the resort. Jenkins is the former vice president of Six Flags over Texas amusement park, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Beer Keg Bomb Partially Explodes In Hotel, Police Defuse The Rest
DOC.TEXT: A homemade bomb packed in a beer keg exploded in the lobby of a County Down hotel, which was evacuated after masked men dropped off the barrel and warned of its contents, police said today. No group claimed responsibility for the attack and no injuries were reported. The masked men left the device in the foyer of the Slieve Donard Hotel Friday night and shouted a warning as they left, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. About 80 guests, mostly women attending a trade union conference, were evacuated. A constabulary spokesman, who by custom was not identified, said a small bomb inside the 90-pound device exploded about 45 minutes later, damaging a ceiling. But the small bomb failed to set off the main bomb, which was defused today by army explosive experts, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Crashes Claim Lives of 11 U.S. Servicemen
DOC.TEXT: Crashes of two U.S. Army helicopters on training exercises in Panama have claimed the lives of 11 servicemen, the U.S. Southern Command says. American military officials said the helicopters ran into thunderstorms while flying on the Atlantic side of the isthmus. The accident happened Wednesday night and was reported Friday. Officials gave few details. The Southern Command statement said a search and rescue effort was launched shortly after 9 p.m. Wednesday, when communications with the two aircraft were lost. U.S. search teams found an Army OH-58 observation helicopter Thursday morning in heavy jungle terrain near Punta Diego, about 50 miles southwest of Colon. The other, a UH-1H Huey helicopter, was discovered about four miles away Friday afternoon. All four crew members and five passengers in the Huey were dead, said the Southern Command statement from Panama City. Names were withheld until relatives had been notified. Both occupants of the observation helicopter also were killed. They were identified as Warrant Officer James W. Carl, the pilot, and Capt. Richard D. Tyndall. Carl was assigned to the 228th Aviation Regiment at Fort Kobbe in Panama. Tyndall was from the 7th Infantry Division at Ford Ord, Calif. Both helicopters were based at Fort Kobbe, adjacent to Howard Air Base.

DOC.HEAD: Group: New Train System Could Renovate Short-Distance Travel
DOC.TEXT: A 300 mph bullet train that uses magnetic levitation will become the transportation of choice for 150- to 300-mile trips in the United States, a group that hopes to develop the trains says. The trains appear to be the best high-speed ground transportation technology based on cost, environmental impact, speed, comfort and readiness, James Roddey, acting president of Maglev Inc., said Friday. ``What we presently consider the communter airline market represents the magnetic levitation market,'' said Roddey, an advertising executive. Maglev Inc., a group of business, labor and government leaders, was formed to develop a 19-mile demonstration project linking downtown Pittsburgh to Greater Pittsburgh International Airport. The ``maglev'' train hovers on a magnetic field over an elevated guideway, using technology devised in the United States in 1968 and improved in West Germany. Train cars have no wheels and wrap around a guide rail, preventing the train from derailing. The group has completed a preliminary study on the feasibility of magnetic levitation in Pittsburgh and is trying to raise $2.1 million for a more detailed study, Roddey said. ``What we want to do in the Pittsburgh area is become a technological and manufacturing base for magnetic levitation in the United States,'' Roddey said. Richard Uher, director of Carnegie Mellon University's High Speed Ground Transportation Center, said Maglev could create ``a whole new industry here.'' The 12 members of Maglev Inc. have agreed to invest $900,000 for the study, which will take 2{ years to finish. An additional $300,000 will come from the state, Roddey said. The Maglev Promotion Council, a Japanese trading company, has committed about $250,000, he said, and the company is applying for $1.2 million from federal officials. The airport project could be completed as early as 1996, Roddey said. It would cost $300 million to $650 million to design and build, depending on the route and whether a single or double track system is built.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Jazz Vocalist Undergoes Cancer Treatment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to CORRECT spelling Vaughan.
DOC.TEXT: Legendary jazz singer Sarah Vaughan is undergoing treatment for cancer at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. Cedars-Sinai spokesman Ron Wise said Friday that the 65-year-old singer entered the hospital last week for additional treatment of a previously diagnosed tumor in her right hand. ``She's been here at least two other times for treatment,'' Wise said, adding that Miss Vaughan will be released within a few days. Miss Vaughan is best known for her emotional renditions of ``The Lord's Prayer'' and ``Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child.'' She rose to fame as an associate of the pioneer bop musicians.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Leader Optimistic Western Hostages Will be Freed
DOC.TEXT: Recent statements from Iran and Lebanon have given Syria ``great hope'' that Western hostages in Lebanon will be released, Syria's information minister said today. But Mohammed Salam cautioned the sister of American hostage Terry A. Anderson not to expect a quick release of her brother and the 17 other Westerners believed to be held. ``The matter requires careful study and patience as well as coordination of efforts with international and local parties. We are following this road,'' he told Peggy Say, who is on her fifth tour of the region in hopes of securing the hostages' release. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held of the Western hostages. He was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut on March 16, 1985. Salman's optimism stemmed from a statement made Friday in Beirut by Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlalah, the most influential Shiite Moslem cleric in Lebanon. He appealed for a new approach to free the hostages. Fadlallah, who recently returned from a visit to Tehran with senior Iranian leaders, spoke the day after an editorial in the Tehran Times, which usually reflects the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani, urged that the hostages be freed. It was the first time an Iranian newspaper has made such a statement. ``We have to think of finding realistic and humanitarian means to free the foreign hostages'' Fadlallah said in a sermon on the Moslem holy day. The hostage issue ``has been widely exploited by Western forces to harm the image of Moslems,'' Fadlallah said. He is the spiritual guide to the Iranian-aligned Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be an umbrella organization for groups holding most of the Westerners missing in Lebanon. Salman praised the statements. ``We have great hope now that we can work with all concerned to secure the release of the hostages,'' he said. Earlier statements from Iran and Shiite leaders in Lebanon about a possible hostage release ``were not made in such a serious manner,'' he said. Syria, with 40,000 troops in Lebanon, is the main power broker in that country. The Syrians have been instrumental in securing the release of some Western hostages over the past five years and played a role in other releases. Syria is Iran's main ally in the region. Salman said Syria ``would be proud if we were able to secure release of any hostage regardless of his nationality.'' He said Syria is categorically opposed to kidnapping. ``Neither Terry Anderson nor any other hostage is responsible for the problems of the area. And kidnapping cannot solve these problems,'' Salman said. Mrs. Say told him: ``I know in my heart that Syria's conviction to gain the release of the hostages is total.'' Mrs. Say is on a tour with an Associated Press delegation to seek the release of Anderson and the others. She has met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II and Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu to Meet With Bush on Trade Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 4th pvs, ``Kaifu told...'' with White House statement on the summit. Pickup 5th, ``Bush wants...''
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and President Bush will meet in California next week to discuss trade frictions between the two countries and changes in Eastern Europe, the government and news reports said today. Kaifu and Bush will hold their second Japan-U.S. summit meeting in Palm Springs on March 2-3, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. The two leaders met for the first time in September, when Kaifu visited Washington soon after becoming prime minister. Kaifu told reporters today that he had received a telephone call from Bush, and quoted the president as saying, ``I would like to have talks about the global partnership of Japan-U.S. ties without deciding specific topics.'' The White House said the two leaders would discuss ``internatinal developments, the U.S.-Japanese global parntership and bilateral relations.'' ``The visit underlies the vital importance both countries attach to the U.S.-Japanese relationship and its contribution to the preservation of peace and prosperity in the Pacific and throughout the world,'' the White House said. Bush wants to hear Japan's position on the political changes in Eastern Europe and hopes for an early exchange of opinions on Japanese-U.S. cooperation toward thawing East-West ties, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official told Kyodo News Service. Another Foreign Ministry official told Kyodo that the two sides hope to find ways to improve their strained trade relations. Kaifu is expected to reassure Bush that Japan intends to solve issues such as the ``structural impediments'' at the top of Washington's complaint list on trade with Japan. The U.S. trade deficit with Japan for 1989 is expected to reach $49 billion. A two-day round of U.S.-Japan ``Structural Impediments Initiative'' talks ended inconclusively in Tokyo on Friday with the two sides taking widely divergent positions on fundamental aspects of the Japanese economy. The American government believes the Japanese have not responded to U.S. demands regarding market barriers, the ministry official told Kyodo. During the telephone call, the news reports said, Bush also congratulated Kaifu on his governing Liberal Democratic Party's victory in Sunday's elections for the nation's powerful lower house.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Voters To Pick Legislature That Will Steer Toward Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to CORRECT time conversion. Pickup 6th, `Voters lined...'
DOC.TEXT: With an eye toward ending a half century of Soviet rule, Lithuanians today voted for a new legislature that could be led by non-Communists and will undoubtedly seek independence for the Baltic republic. The reformed Lithuanian Communist Party, which broke with Moscow and advocated independence for the republic, made a strong bid to retain power. It is unclear whether Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev will allow the Soviet republic to break away, but some political leaders expect Lithuania to proclaim independence as early as this summer. The Lithuanian Communist Party broke from the national party in December. At least six legal parties and the front-runner Sajudis popular movement are vying for seats in the republic's 141-member Supreme Soviet. Lithuania in December also became the first of the Soviet Union's 15 republics to legalize parties other than the Communist Party. ``This day is a line between the past and the future,'' said Vytautus Landsbergis, chairman of Sajudis, shortly before marking his paper ballot at a high school in Vilnius, the capital. Polls opened at 8 a.m. (midnight EST) and were to close at 8 p.m. (noon EST), the official Tass news agency said. Officials said they expect the first preliminary results Sunday with official results available Tuesday. Voters lined up to vote under clear skies and 50-degree temperatures. ``I think these elections will mean independence for Lithuania. But they are only a first step,'' said Rimantis Jankauskas, an employee of Vilnius University, clutching his young daughter's hand after he voted. ``We must be realistic about this,'' he said. ``We are still on the very beginning of a very long road of negotiations with Moscow.'' About 30 men marked Soviet Army Day in Vilnius on Friday by turning in their military I.D. cards, saying they refused to serve in an ``occupation army.'' A newspaper quoted Algirdas Brazauskas, leader of the republic's Communist Party, as saying last week: ``All of Lithuania seeks an independent state. The re-establishment of statehood is the central aim of the rebirth of our people.'' In 1940, the Soviet Union absorbed the three Baltic republics _ Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia _ under a secret agreement in which Josef Stalin and Adolf Hitler divided central Europe between them. They had been independent for 22 years. The government chosen by the new legislature will seek to negotiate an orderly departure from the Soviet Union, said Landsbergis. Sajudis, which has attracted hundreds of thousands of people to rallies in this republic of 3.6 million people, is the clear leader in today's election. It supports about 30 candidates of the Lithuanian Communist Party. Sajudis and the Lithuanian Communist Party are contesting nearly every seat. Members of the pro-Moscow Alternate Communist Party, including candidates from Lithuania's 200,000 ethnic Russian minority, are running in 78 districts. Many smaller parties with smaller slates of candidates sprang up during the campaign, including the Social Democrats, Democrats, Greens and Christian Democrats. A total of 475 candidates are running for the 141 seats, and only eight are unopposed. Under Gorbachev's political reforms there are no guaranteed seats for Communists. Canadian parliamentarians, invited by Sajudis, are to monitor the election. Bob Rae, a member of the Canadian delegation, said Moscow refused visas to several U.S. congressmen when they claimed the status of official observers. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said visas were denied because the Americans did not have official invitations. He said they could visit the Soviet Union later. A few campaign signs were up Friday. Outside Sajudis headquarters in Vilnius, the capital, a steady stream of people examined the posted election information and pictures of candidates. Sajudis leaders say they are not breaking away from the Soviet Union so much as reclaiming a sovereignty usurped illegally. After the Red Army occupied Lithuania, the parliament was coerced into voting to join the Soviet Union, which formally annexed it on Aug. 24, 1940. The Baltic states became independent in 1918, after the collapse of Russia and Germany in World War I.

DOC.HEAD: Widespread Anti-Roh Rallies; Roh Expects Full Ties With Moscow, Beijing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expands 6th pvs, ``About 600...'' to name other cities where protests occurred. New last graf to ADD more on Seoul's anti-Communist policies.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: About 4,000 radical students and dissidents shouting ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' fought riot police in six cities today, news reports said, in the largest anti-government demonstrations this year. Also today, on the eve of his second anniversary in office, Roh said he expects his country, which has long been staunchly anti-Communist, to establish full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and China. Police firing tear gas charged about 1,000 students holding a protest rally at a park in central Seoul. Students hurled hundreds of firebombs and tore bricks and cement chunks from sidewalks to throw at combat-clad riot police who drove students back with barrages of tear gas. ``Let's crush the anti-democratic merger that tramples the people's sovereignty!'' yelled students, demanding the dissolution of a new governing party created by the merger of Roh's party with two others. The students, dissidents and workers surged through the narrow streets of a fashionable downtown Seoul shopping area shouting anti-government slogans. Police kicked and punched students and at least 50 were arrested. About 600 students at Chosun University in Kwangju fought riot police with firebombs and rocks when they were stopped from marching from the campus, news reports said. Anti-government protests by a total of 2,400 people were held in the cities of Chonju, Anyang, Suwon and Mokpo, said the Chosun-Ilbo and Hankook Ilbo newspapers. There were no reports of serious injuries in the protests. Radicals, a small but vocal minority, have dwindled in recent months but dissidents and radicals claim a new giant governing party created in January by the merger of Roh's party with two others is undemocratic. The newspaper Joong-Ang Ilbo quoted Roh as saying ``I am convinced South Korea will be able to establish formal ties with the Soviet Union and China. ... It will be a matter of time.'' Some news reports said Roh indicated full ties with Moscow could occur before the end of the year. The Dong-A Ilbo, an influential Seoul daily, quoted Roh as saying ``The establishment of formal relations with the Soviet Union and China will be eventually realized, probably at different times.'' South Korea agreed in December to exchange limited consular relations with Moscow. Seoul has said it will soon send a government delegation to Beijing to discuss sending consular officials during September's Asian Games. Roh also said he was optimistic he would visit the two Communist countries before stepping down as president at the end of his five-year term in 1993. Under his detente-oriented ``Northern Policy,'' Roh has been trying to improve diplomatic and trade relations with China, the Soviet Union and other East European countries. Seoul hopes improved relations with Communist North Korea's allies will help ease tension on the Korean peninsula. The Seoul government does not allow its citizens to travel or communicate with rival North Korea without government approval, which is seldom given. Pro-Communist activites are illegal in South Korea. But travel to other Communist nations has been eased with the new diplomatic initiatives.

DOC.HEAD: Gunboat Shells Ferry Off Lebanon; 1 Killed, 15 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 19 grafs to UPDATE with crew members saying gunboat was Syrian, details on shelling; Picks up 16th graf, `The boat ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Syrian gunboat opened fire on a passenger ferry carrying 116 people off the coast of Lebanon, killing one passenger, crew members said. At least 15 people were reported wounded, four critically. The shellfire also caused a fire on board. The gunboat attacked the ferry Baroness M three times in an hour 19 miles west of the Lebanese port of Jounieh, third officer Andreas Michaeliks said. The ferry had been steaming toward the Lebanese Christian port. The gunboat flew a Syrian flag and the name Aoudah was visible on its side, crew members aboard the ferry said. Crew members said the sailors on board the 150-foot-long gunboat fired warning shots over the ferry and then hailed it in Syrian-accented Arabic. ``They asked us who was on board and where we were going,'' said Egyptian mechanic Mohammed Mohammed al-Murshidi, 27. He said he talked with them over the radio because most of the ferry crew spoke only Greek or English. Later, as the ferry turned back toward Larnaca, the gunboat fired shells at the captain's quarters and into passenger areas, the ferry crew said. ``When the Baroness M radioed for help for the wounded passengers, the Syrian boat hauled down its flag,'' crew member Danny Zarour said. The ferry returned to Larnaca with at least 20 holes visible in its side as it docked. One of the shells went through a window on the central deck housing the bar and the cafeteria, causing most of the casualties, Michaeliks said. Crew members said one man was killed. He was identified as Nasser Abu Nasr, 26, who was going to Lebanon to pick up his family. Cypriot police earlier had said two people were killed. British Royal Air Force helicopters earlier evacuated nine men and two women to Larnaca, three in critical condition. A fleet of ambulances rushed the wounded to local hospitals for treatment. Flight Lt. Dick Bardon said four wounded remained on the Baroness, one too badly injured to be winched aboard the helicopters. Most suffered cuts and burns in the legs from shrapnel. The Royal Air Force put two doctors and a paramedic team onto the deck of the ship to assist the wounded, Bardon said. The ship carried 64 passengers and 52 crew members, said Nora Kasbari, spokesman for Socomar, agents for the ship. The port of Jounieh is controlled by the Lebanese Forces, which have been locked in a three-week battle for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave with Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. The Lebanese forces also has a share in the ferry operations. The waters off Lebanon also are regularly patrolled by the Syrian and Israeli navies. Gunboats controlled by Aoun also had been reported at sea. The boat, one of two that travels to Lebanon from Cyprus, is a main escape routes for Christians in embattled Lebanon, many fleeing the army-militia confrontation that erupted Jan. 30. The captain and crew of the ship had been reluctant to take it into Jounieh because of the risks involved in the fighting. Jounieh is 120 miles east of Larnaca, a seven-hour journey. The ferry service and other maritime traffic came under fire repeatedly during six months of fighting in Lebanon in 1989 between Aoun and the Syrian army with their Lebanese Moslem militia allies. The ferries were not hit, but at least eight ships were sunk or set on fire, including small boats taking passengers out to the ferry waiting off shore.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party To Abolish Its Workplace Operations, Postpone Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with vote scheduled on Communists' name change, recast lead. Pickup 5th graf, `Talks between...'
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Party has agreed to remove its representatives from the workplace _ a key demand by the democratic opposition _ and to postpone elections by one month, informed sources said today. The Communists' Supreme Council, at the same closed-door meeting Friday, also decided to let Communists vote on whether to change the name of their party to the Bulgarian Socialists Party, the state BTA news agency said. All Communist Party members would be eligible to vote in the May plebiscite, BTA said. Communist parties in Soviet bloc countries further along the road to democracy already have reformed as Socialists professing democratic ideals, in an attempt to win support ahead of multiparty elections. The Supreme Council agreed in principle to abandon the Communist Party's right to organize in factories, enterprises and administrative units, sources said. The council, which replaced the policy-setting Central Committee under a decision by a recent party congress, proposed the measure be included in a new law on parties expected to be adopted during a National Assembly session beginning March 5. The Supreme Council proposed to hold Bulgaria's first multiparty elections in June, not in May as previously announced. However, the opposition has repeatedly demanded that elections be held in November, the sources said. Talks between the Communists and the opposition Union of Democratic Forces and other political and social groups were suspended Feb. 12 because of disagreement over the party cells and other political demands. The talks began after longtime Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov was toppled Nov. 10. The agreement to get Communist representatives out of the workplace was welcomed by opposition representatives as a positive step. ``It is a good sign because the Communist Party understands that they must do something'' to show their commitment to democratic change, said Alexander Karakachanov, a member of the opposition coalition and president of the Bulgarian Greens Party. However, Karakachanov, who was reached by telephone from Vienna, said he believed the opposition would still go ahead with a protest rally Sunday in downtown Sofia, ``maybe not at the same level'' as originally planned. In a statement read on national television Friday, the opposition urged citizens to attend the weekend rally to protest the Communists' stalling on reforms. The declaration, read on TV by Georgi Spassov, the spokesman for the opposition coalition, also proclaimed the days until March 3 as ``days of protest and struggle for freedom and democracy.'' In another concession to the opposition, the Supreme Council proposed that in future the national holiday should be March 3, not Sept. 9. Since 1944, the national day has been Sept. 9 when a national front, dominated by the Communists, took over. On March 3, 1878, under a peace treaty signed between Turkey and Russia, Bulgaria became independent after nearly 500 years of Ottoman Turkish rule.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Hurt By Shortages of Chinese, French Ammunition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Chinese halting shipments of weapons. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A halt in shipments of Chinese weapons crippled an offensive by Cambodian guerrillas and allowed government forces to retake a strategic northwestern town, fighters and Western diplomats have said. Senior guerrilla officials also said France halted secret arms supplies to one of the rebel groups fighting the Communist Cambodian government after the covert program was publicized. France denied such shipments were made. China has been the main supplier of arms to three of the groups fighting the Vietnamese-installed government, and the guerrillas said in interviews that the halt in shipments is unprecedented in 11 years of fighting. It was unclear whether the suspension indicated a policy decision or logistical problems. A Chinese diplomat in Bangkok _ speaking on condition of anonymity, as most of the other sources did _ last month denied there was any change in support for the resistance. The Khmer People's National Liberation Front said it has not received Chinese shipments in three months, and Prince Norodom Sihanouk's group also has reported shortages. It was not known whether supplies to the Communist Khmer Rouge, China's main ally in the resistance coalition, were affected. Gen. Pan Thai, chief of staff of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, on Friday blamed the loss of the northwestern town of Svay Chek to Cambodian troops on the shortage of arms. Svay Chek _ a gateway to the government military operations center at Sisophon and biggest prize of the front's recent offensive _ was retaken Friday in the government's first major victory. ``The (government) could never have taken back Svay Chek if we had the ammo,'' Pan Thai said in an interview at Aranyaprathet, a Thai border town. ``We would have taken Sisophon a long time ago.'' ``We have nothing. No mortars, rockets, nothing. We have asked the Chinese many times since December, but nothing,'' Pan Thai said. A Western diplomat in Bangkok on Friday confirmed the halt in shipments and agreed it had crippled the guerrilla offensive. The guerrillas had seized a wide swath of territory along the Thai border since late September, when Vietnam said it withdrew its last troops. The Liberation Front seized Svay Chek Dec. 5 and said it was pushing toward Sisophon, but fighting decreased in recent weeks. Some Liberation Front commanders said they believed China is punishing the front for refusing to cooperate more closely with the Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people during its three-year rule, which began in 1975 and ended with the Vietnamese invasion in 1978. The commanders said the shipments ceased after a meeting in early December in which Chinese officials requested closer cooperation with the Khmer Rouge. Senior guerrilla officers also reported that last year France halted its weapons supplies to Sihanouk's group after the covert program was publicized. They said France had been supplying sophisticated FA-MAS assault rifles and Luchaire AC rifle grenades as well as LRAC 89 mm anti-tank guns, which helped shift the tide of the war after September. The French did not supply the other two guerrilla groups. Reporters saw at least a dozen fighters carrying FA-MAS rifles among the guerrillas guarding Sihanouk when he crossed into northwestern Cambodia Friday to end 11 years of exile. Reporters have seen other French-supplied weapons in areas of northwestern Banteay Meanchey province newly seized by the guerrillas. The French Foreign Ministry issued a denial when the Thai Army chief of staff said in April that French arms were being shipped to the guerrillas through Thai territory. The shipments were halted sometime later in the year, the guerrilla officers said. Western diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, on Friday confirmed their account. France, a former colonial power in Indochina, is among many non-Communist countries that extend diplomatic support to the resistance.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Will Try To Recreate The Beer Of Ancient Egypt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th pvs, ``Tutankhamen reigned...'' to CORRECT years of his reign. Pickup 12th, ``Merrington said...''
DOC.TEXT: British brewers and archaelogists wanting to know how ancient Egypt made its beer plan to examine the ruins of a brewery, read hieroglyphics and search for tiny amounts of the liquid in ancient pottery. News of the three-year project, launched by a leading British brewery and the nation's prestigious Egypt Exploration Society, drew headlines in London newspapers on Friday. ``Brewers seek the Pharaohs' secret,'' said one. ``Explorers seek the recipe for Tutankhamen's beer,'' boasted another. The Independent called it one of the first large-scale research projects to be undertaken jointly by archaeologists and a commercial British company. When the researchers have figured out what went into brewing beer in ancient Egypt, the brewery will try to reproduce it at its laboratory in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. But Jim Merrington, corporate affairs director for Scottish and Newcastle Breweries PLC, said he wasn't sure if the fine ale of the pharoahs would be offered to tipplers in British pubs. ``It is highly improbable it will appear on the bar, but it is not beyond the realms of possibility,'' he told a news conference Thursday in Edinburgh. He said the project will be based largely on archaeological excavations at Tell-el Amarna, one of Egypt's ancient capitals located 190 miles south of Cairo. Archaeologists from the society, led by field director Barry Kemp of Cambridge University, are investigating a royal brewery there attached to a temple built by Queen Nefertiti. She was the leading wife of King Tutankhamen's father, the Pharaoh Akhnaton, whose name also was spelled Akhenaten or Ikhnaton. Tutankhamen reigned from 1333 to 1323 B.C. His tomb was discovered in the Valley of the Kings at Luxor in 1922. His solid gold coffin and other fabulous treasures found inside captured the imagination of the world. Merrington said Nefertiti's temple, each side of which measures 750 feet, had its own brewery and bakery for making beer and bread for religious festivals. Both processes employ yeast. But no one knows what the beer tasted like. Ancient texts and wall paintings suggest there were several different beers, ranging from thick gruelly ales to those of a finer texture. Wall paintings from Tutankhamen's day depict courtiers vomiting after getting drunk on beer. Another wall painting shows Nefertiti pouring her beer through a strainer to remove lumps of gruel. Merrington said the archaeologists hope to find minute traces of the beer. If they're successful, he said, scientists working for Scottish and Newcastle would use a chemical process to test those samples to try to determine the ancient brew's taste and consistency. ``Apart from what the archaeologists give us, we hope to examine beer residues left in pots which are now in museums in Europe, America and Egypt,'' Merrington said. ``We will use 20th century technology which can identify flavors to come up with a recipe. Then we will try to brew it.'' Researchers on the project also will examine ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics, tomb models and written material for clues to making the beer. ``The pyramids were built on a diet of bread and beer, with bakeries and breweries operating together,'' Kemp said. ``The ancient Egyptians baked a kind of bread first, then used it as a mash from which to brew the beer.''

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Commander Well; Launch Expected Early Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with countdown under way. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Forecasters said...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Pioneer 11, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With a healthy crew and clear skies, NASA started the countdown today for an early Sunday launch of the thrice-delayed space shuttle Atlantis and its secret military cargo. Atlantis commander John O. Creighton, whose sore throat and head congestion were a factor in earlier postponements, is well and ready to fly, doctors said Friday. And the foul weather that has hung over Kennedy Space Center since Thursday faded. Early today, NASA workers moved Atlantis' service structure away. A few hours later, according to sources, the countdown toward launch resumed at 9:40 a.m. EST. The countdown and precise launch time are secret until the final nine minutes, but NASA said liftoff will be between midnight and 4 a.m. Sunday. Sources said the most likely time is around 1 a.m. EST. Forecasters said there is a 70 percent chance of favorable weather for launch. A slight increase in predicted winds lowered the probability from 80 percent forecast Friday. ``We do expect it to get better as we go into the day,'' said Air Force Capt. Ken Warren. ``We think the winds will die down.'' Atlantis' flight path after launch is expected to be roughly parallel to the eastern U.S. coastline, passing within a few hundred miles of some points. If the skies are clear, residents from northern Florida to New Jersey may be able to see the rocket fire of the space-bound shuttle. Creighton's illness and uncertain weather forced NASA to cancel launch attempts on Thursday and Friday. The astronaut recovered in time for a launch early today, but NASA officials did not even start the countdown after rain, dense leaden clouds and thunderstorms moved into the area on Friday. Sources who spoke on condition they not to be named said Atlantis will deploy a $500 million spy satellite called AFP-731 during a four-day mission. The satellite is capable of taking high-resolution reconnaissance photos and listening in on electronic communications all over the world. Sources said the satellite is to be placed into a high inclination orbit that will cover more of the Earth than satellites previously launched by the shuttle. This orbital path will carry it over most of the Soviet Union, including areas far to the north. The Soviet Union has similar satellites over the United States. Once Atlantis is in orbit, progress of the mission will be blacked out. Unlike shuttle flights with civilian payloads, NASA will not release the air-to-ground communications or give reports on the astronaut activities. The blackout will be lifted just an hour before Atlantis returns to Earth for a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Creighton's four crewmates on Atlantis are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane, and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Atlantis' flight will be 34th space shuttle mission and the sixth secret military mission.

DOC.HEAD: Police Beat Pro-Democracy Demonstrators Who Occupy Cathedral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with student demonstrations today, newsletter banned, official accusing police of beating priest. Pickup 9th graf, `It was...'; DELETES last 6 grafs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Students and anti-government protesters today stoned buses and blocked off a suburb, witnesses said, after police tricked protesters into leaving a church and then beat and arrested them outside. About 100 students ran through the central Boulevard de la Republique, yelling ``Liberty!'' and ``Free our comrades!'' Police did not respond. Also, the clandestine Ivorian Peoples Front said the government banned its newsletter following a first edition that urged a peaceful transition to democracy. Students, who have clashed with police since Monday and pose the strongest opposition in years to conservative President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, demanded reform after electrical power at their university campus was cut off. They want a multiparty government and have protested officials' lavish lifestyles during a time of austerity.
