A Roman Catholic Church official accused a Cabinet minister of lying about assurances for the safe passage of 200 student protesters who were beaten and detained when they ended their 10-hour occupation of the capital's cathedral. The official, who requested anonymity, said a priest who accompanied the students, the Rev. Jean-Pierre Koutouan, also was beaten by police and briefly detained. The official said he had reports that hundreds of students took to the streets of Yopougon, a high-density suburb housing four university dormitories where the trouble started Monday night. He said protesters had blocked the suburb to traffic. But other observers said it may have been sealed off by students or security forces. On Friday, about 200 students in the capital holed up in St. Paul's Cathedral. As night fell, police attacked more than 400 other students gathered opposite the church in downtown Abidjan. A policeman who identified himself only as ``a commandant'' threatened journalists at the scene. ``Go away. We'll beat you up,'' he said. At about 1 a.m. today, the students inside the cathedral ended their sit-in. For nearly an hour, they were photographed by police who took down their names before letting them out the gate. When the students left the cathedral, they milled outside the gate for nearly two hours, obviously frightened. At one point they tried to get back into the cathedral, but were blocked by armed police. Koutouan reportedly negotiated a safe passage for them and they boarded police trucks, which drove around the corner to the main police station. As Koutouan walked away from the station, the thwack of batons was heard and police were seen beating the students, who cried out in pain. It was not immediately known how many students were injured in either incident, nor how many students remained held. British journalist Mark Huband, the Abidjan-based correspondent of the London Financial Times, said he was in the cathedral when Koutouan told students the police had agreed to let them go free if they all were photographed. Huband said the students initially refused, saying they feared police would attack them. Houphouet-Boigny, 84, who has ruled this West African country as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960, has refused recent demands for a multiparty government. The nation's economy is struggling through a recession that has brought unemployment and pay cuts to what was one of Africa's more prosperous countries. Earlier Friday, militant students released the manifesto of a new organization. It said demonstrations were ``the result of years of suffered injustices.'' The manifesto demanded, among other things, salary cuts for Cabinet ministers and other high-ranking government officials in line with wage cuts of up to 30 percent that have been imposed on lesser government employees. The students said they were against the ``opulent lifestyles'' of officials while ordinary citizens suffer from a recession caused by falling cocoa and coffee prices. The manifesto demanded the government do something to solve the problem of agricultural prices. The annual per capita gross national product has fallen from $1,200 in 1981 to $700 last year. The government has reacted slowly, running up a $12 billion foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Province Restricts Marriages of Handicapped
DOC.TEXT: A northeastern province has barred people with physical or mental disabilities from marrying or giving birth, official reports said Saturday. It was the second Chinese province to pass such laws. The reports said the legislature in Liaoning province enacted the regulations to prevent women from giving birth to babies with mental and physical defects. It said the law would improve the quality of the population. The law, which takes effect July 1, also forbids close relatives from marrying. Gansu province, in China's remote and poverty-stricken northwest, passed a law in 1988 ordering all mentally retarded people who married to be sterilized and all mentally retarded women to have abortions if they became pregnant. The China Daily newspaper said the Liaoning regulations ban marriages between directly related members of one's family, collateral relatives within three generations and individuals not confirmed to have recovered from veneral disease and other infectious diseases. It said two-year observation after hospital treatment is compulsory for people with serious mental disabilities if they want to marry. The newspaper did not say if mentally handicapped couples would be subject to sterilization, and officials contacted in Liaoning by telephone could not provide additional details of the regulations. However, the official People's Daily reported earlier this month that a district in the Liaoning city of Benxi had already imposed rules that required people suffering from congenital or hereditary ailments to be sterilized before getting married. It said that as a result of close monitoring of marriages and births, not one of the more than 10,000 babies born in Xihu district between 1987 and 1989 suffered from mental or hearing disabilities. The China Daily said 12 out of every 1,000 children born in Liaoning had physical or mental disabilities and that 14 out of 1,000 children below the age of 14 were mentally handicapped.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students and Dissidents Battle Police in South Korea
LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of radical students and dissidents shouting anti-government slogans fought riot police with firebombs and rocks in six cities Saturday, the eve of President Roh Tae-Woo's second anniversary in office. In central Seoul, riot police dressed in combat gear fired barrages of tear gas and charged about 1,000 students holding a rally. Students hurled hundreds of firebombs, as well as bricks and chunks of cement pried from sidewalks. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' students shouted. ``Let's crush the anti-democratic merger that tramples the people's sovereignty!'' The students were demanding dissolution of a new governing party comprising Roh's party and two opposition groups. They say the merger is undemocratic and a ploy by the Roh government to stifle moves toward democracy. It was the most widespread show of anti-government sentiment so far this year and also included protests in the cities of Kwangju, Chonju, Anyang, Suwon and Mokpo. Support for the radical students had dwindled in recent months, but the surprise party merger in January prompted renewed demonstrations. Roh, speaking on nationwide television Saturday, discounted the possibility the new governing party would bring about a return to authoritarian government. ``The path toward democratization should never be blocked, and authoritarian rule is a thing of the past,'' said Roh, who took office after months of anti-government demonstrations in 1987 forced his predecessor, Chun Doo-hwan, to allow the first free nationwide elections in 16 years. At least four opposition legislators, members of the Party for Peace and Democracy, joined about 50 dissidents at Seoul's Anglican Church after riot police blocked a rally at a downtown cathedral. A party spokesman said the lawmakers went on their own initiative and party policy opposed violence or joining dissidents to fight the merger. At another protest in Seoul, 1,000 radical students ran through the narrow streets of a fashionable downtown shopping area shouting anti-government slogans. Police kicked and punched students and at least 50 were arrested. There were no reports of serious injuries. At Chosun University in Kwangju south of Seoul, 600 students fought riot police with firebombs and rocks when they were prevented from marching from the campus, news reports said. There were no details of anti-government protests in the four other cities, although some rallies were violent, said the Chosun-Ilbo and Hankook Ilbo newspapers. Roh was sworn into office Feb. 25, 1988 for a single five-year term. He was the handpicked successor to Chun, who had taken power eight years earlier with military backing. One of the radicals' major demands has been the withdrawal of 43,000 American troops stationed in South Korea. The radicals say the U.S. presence is an impediment to reunification of South Korea with Communist North Korea. Under Roh, South Korea's staunchly anti-Communist government has sought relations with Communist and East bloc nations to broaden trade and establish ties, which it hopes will help ease tensions with the North. Roh was quoted Saturday as saying he expected South Korea to establish full democratic relations with the Soviet Union and China. ``I am convinced South Korea will be able to establish formal ties...it will be a matter of time,'' the newspaper, Joong-Ang Ilbo, quoted Roh as saying. Some reports said Roh indicated full ties with Moscow could occur before the end of the year. Roh also said he believed he would visit the Communist nations before stepping down as president at the end of his term in February 1993. South Korea has already set up ambassadorial relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia and is expected to establish formal ties with Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia when South Korean Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong visits in March. South Korea agreed in December to exchange limited consular relations with Moscow. The Seoul government does not allow its citizens to travel or communicate with rival North Korea without government approval, which is seldom given. Pro- Communist activites are illegal in South Korea. Travel to other Communist nations, however, has been eased with the new diplomatic initiatives.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Eyeing More Money For Food Programs
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers are taking steps to ensure that feeding programs for the poor don't get short-shrift treatment in the congressional draft of this year's major farm bill. Legislation called the Mickey Leland Memorial Domestic Hunger Relief Act will be introduced Tuesday to improve food stamp and surplus commodity distribution programs to the tune of $600 million. It's a joint House-Senate measure in honor of the former chairman of the House Select Comittee on Hunger who was killed in an airplane crash last year during a visit to Ethiopia. The bill goes farther than the Bush administration proposals, but is expected to become the nutrition title of the farm bill without major changes. ``To me, nutrition programs are not just a title added on to the end of the farm bill,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, whose staff helped write the legislation. ``To me, nutrition programs are a test of the conscience of this nation. This farm bill cannot be complete until the needs of the hungry are met.'' The proposed legislation calls for an additional $600 million in spending for both food stamp and free food programs over the current budget year, which ends Sept. 30. The Temporary Emergency Food Assistance Program changes would require the government to raise from $120 million to $190 million the amount it spends on of high protein food distributed free to the poor each year. The legislation also would require the government to spend $32 million on commodities to be supplied to soup kitchens throughout the five-year life of the farm bill. The food assistance programs are used widely in rural areas where food stamps are difficult to get. About 15,000 food distribution centers, mostly churches, hand out food the government purchases especially for the program and surplus commodities already owned by the government. A key change in the food stamp program is a provision that would take greater account of higher housing costs. ``Studies show that some low income families pay up to 70 percent of their income in rent,'' said Ann Kittlaus, spokeswoman for Food Research and Action Center, which has been lobbying for the improvements. The new legislation would not set a dollar limit on how much a person can pay in rent and still qualify for food stamps. A release from Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said that Kittlaus' organization and 100 religious, government, health and low-income advocacy groups endorsed a ``statement of principles that are embodied in this bill.'' Panetta, who once headed the House Agriculture subcommittee on domestic marketing and nutrition, is now chairman of the House Budget Committee. His interest is significant. ``We've made some very good progress with hunger relief legislation to repeal some of the damage done in the early 1980s,'' Panetta said in an interview with the National Journal. ``The problem we now have is that some barriers still remain.'' Kittlaus, whose organizations works nationally and has lobbied hard over the years to improve programs for the poor, said she was encouraged by the Bush administration's approach to these problems. ``We've been in a lot more contact with the USDA than we ever were during the Reagan years,'' she said. ``Their proposals are not everything we would like them to be, but at least they are listening.'' ``At least they are saying there is hunger in America,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Closes Beaches After Cyanide Containers Found
DOC.TEXT: Authorities closed several beaches in southern England on Saturday, less than 24 hours after they had been reopened, when two more containers of potentially lethal potassium cyanide were sighted. The public was barred from the beaches along the Sussex coast earlier in the week after six containers of the chemical were found there. Officials believe the containers may be from a vessel that recently lost part of a chemical shipment off England during rough weather. Brighton officials told the public to stay away from a 10-mile stretch of beach around Brighton after one container washed up Saturday at nearby Hove and another was seen floating off Saltdean. ``As long as there are still containers floating in the sea there is a danger to the public and they should stay away,'' a city spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Condemned for Dealing Pot, Wife Acquitted
DOC.TEXT: A court Saturday sentenced a man to hang for trafficking in marijuana but acquitted his wife, saying she didn't know about the 21 ounces of cannabis authorities found hidden in their home. Abdullah Zawawi Yusoff, 41, became the 248th person condemned to death for drug trafficking since Malaysia passed laws in 1975 allowing the courts to give that sentence to convicted drug dealers. Of those people, 82 have been hanged. The High Court said in its ruling Saturday that prosecutors had failed to prove that Abdullah's wife, Ma Kalthom Idris, 33, knew the box of marijuana had been hidden in the kitchen of their home in Kota Bahru, 240 miles northeast of Kuala Lumpur. It was not known whether Abdullah would appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Speaker Accused of Appearing in Lewd Video Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The deputy speaker of Parliament resigned Saturday, two months after an opposition legislator accused him of appearing in pornographic videotapes, the state-run news agency said. The letter of resignation from D.P. Vijandran was received by Parliament Speaker Mohamad Zahir Ismail, who said Parliament would be informed on Tuesday. The Bernama news agency said the letter did not give a reason for the resignation, which took effect immediately. However, the communications minister, S. Samy Vellu, told reporters the deputy speaker resigned to prevent opposition parties from using the scandal for political gain. Vijandran will retain his Parliament seat. In December, opposition lawmaker Karpal Singh alleged in Parliament that Vijandran had acted in pornographic videotapes and demanded his resignation. Vijandran denied the allegation and filed a defamation suit against Karpal Singh.

DOC.HEAD: High Court to Consider Anti-Drunken Driving Police Roadblocks
LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Duane Gerstenberger clearly remembers the night he and other state police set up Michigan's first sobriety check lane nearly four years ago. The only people who complained were the two drivers arrested out of 126 who were checked, he says. But this week, the practice is the subject of arguments before the U.S. Supreme Court, with civil libertarians urging the court to rule it's unconstitutional and 30 states weighing in on the side of Michigan officials. Officers set up roadblocks for an hour and 20 minutes on May 17 and 18, 1986, in front of a Vlasic pickle factory about two miles north of Interstate 75 near Saginaw. ``It would have lasted longer, but it rained so hard we had to take it down for our officers' safety,'' Gerstenberger said Friday. ``The drivers were there for 15 to 30 seconds. We didn't get any negative feedback on it, except from the two we arrested,'' said Gerstenberger, who supervised the operation. Authorities dropped charges against one of the suspects, and the other's case is awaiting the outcome of a constitutional challenge brought by state lawmakers. The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday is expected to consider whether sobriety check lanes violate the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches. David's Party Store, located on the four-lane highway near where the 11-man police contingent set up, saw its business dry up that night. Word spread to the Der Eisenbahn Bar, about a half-mile south of the check lane. It cleared out by 12:30 a.m., and most drivers took routes to avoid the check lane. ``I had some people come in and tell me they were going to buy some beer but decided against it once they saw the police cars,'' party store owner Tim David told The Saginaw News at the time. ``People are always skittish on this road because this is the main route for the state police,'' David said Friday. ``Their post is less than a mile from here.'' Nearly four years later, the checkpoint isn't a daily topic of conversation, but, ``We're wondering what's going to happen,'' store clerk Connie Lavery said. So is Howard Simon, executive director of the Michigan chapter of the America Civil Liberties Union. The ACLU orchestrated the challenge in which six legislators won a court order forbidding the state police from setting up more sobriety checks after the first try. ``This is the first case in the history of this country in which the Supreme Court will be considering whether police can stop people for no reason whatsoever to enforce a criminal law,'' he said. Michigan Attorney General Frank Kelley said briefs supporting sobriety check lanes have been filed by 30 states and the U.S. Department of Justice. Alcohol was blamed in 793 traffic deaths in Michigan and more than 18,500 nationally in 1988, the latest year for which statistics are available. ``Driving a car is not a constitutional right. It is a privilege granted by the state,'' Kelley said. ``All we we're doing is taking 30 seconds of a motorist's time.'' Gov. James Blanchard in 1986 directed state police to set up the check lanes. The state appealed a February 1989 Michigan Supreme Court decision that let stand lower court rulings declaring the check lanes unconstitutional. Anti-drunken-driving groups such as Mothers Against Drunk Driving defend the check lanes as relatively unintrusive. ``What we consider an intrusion is when a driver is stopped abruptly on the highway and your body is mutilated in an accident caused by a drunk driver,'' said Bethany Goodman, executive director of the Michigan chapter of MADD. Kelley defends the procedure as a brief inconvenience that constitutes less of a search than the security measures at airports or border entry points. Former state Rep. Rick Sitz, now of Tampa, Fla., was one of the original opponents. ``It's just like in the movie `Casablanca,' where Claude Rains turns to the gendarmes and says, `The colonel has been shot. Round up the usual suspects,''' he said. ``That's what they want to do with check lanes. Groundless searches or dragnets have no place in our society.'' The Michigan Sheriffs Association has another argument against the check lanes, arguing that they are a waste of police resources. ``Give me 14 officers and I'll put them on the road with their only assignment being to find and arrest drunk drivers and if they don't bring in a minimum of one arrest each, they aren't worth their salt,'' deputy director Dale E. Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Project Gets Face-Lift Even As Investors Fight Government
DOC.TEXT: The frown turns to a smile at the sound of giggling. Sam Jones whirls around, pointing at the line of frolicking schoolgirls. ``It wasn't too long ago the people here were too scared to let the kids out,'' Jones says as the girls skip by. But his smile turned to a scowl as he returned to his account of the past, saying ``there were drugs and guns, mostly fear. The parents were afraid to walk around, never mind the kids.'' An alliance of residents and builders is creating a reborn community with few signs of fear, fewer of drugs, and none of guns. Today, the signs are of hope and promise. So far, Glenarden's turnaround is a story of success, one residents and owners say is a model for subsidized housing developments nationwide where drugs and violence have added terror to the troubles of low-income families. Glenarden is owned by an investors group arranged by Associated Financial Corp. of California and managed by an AFC affiliate. The companies, and a web of affiliates, late last month were suspended from any new Department of Housing and Urban Development business. HUD says it is investigating allegations the companies misused government and tenant funds at several developments in Oklahoma and the District of Columbia. HUD Secretary Jack Kemp says AFC is one of a handful of companies that make lucrative fees by syndicating low-income housing tax credits but put too little money back into the troubled developments they take over. At Glenarden, however, the owners are setting aside a portion of their credits to pay for bathroom vanities and other fixtures that HUD said were too extravagant to be paid for with the development's government loan. Residents of Glenarden say they are pleased about a better living environment, no matter how it happened. ``I used to be embarrassed to live here,'' says Frances Howerton, a 20-year Glenarden resident. ``But I feel great pride now. We are becoming a true community.'' Less than two years ago Glenarden was known not as a community but as ``the drugstore,'' with cars often lined up to buy drugs from dealers stationed outside the drab rows of apartment buildings. Inside those buildings were rodent-infested units with leaky pipes and sagging ceilings; families too poor to move, too scared to mingle outside. ``At its worst we had unending drug infestation,'' says Howerton. ``Most of the drug dealers who were here didn't actually live on the property. It was just the best place to do business.'' The new facades on the renovated buildings are the most obvious sign of change. Inside, new cabinets and appliances line the kitchens, the bathrooms have been remodeled and fresh paint covers the walls. A model unit is used to give residents tips on cleaning and energy efficiency. Howerton says the most important change is in the attitude of residents, who are steadily being moved into renovated units, and the owners, whose rental license had been suspended before they agreed to the ambitious $15 million renovation plan. ``Families are no longer afraid to speak up, to have a voice in what is going on around here,'' she says. Howerton, president of Glenarden's residents association, speaks highly now of the owners and managers she once scorned. ``There is a deep trust now,'' she says. ``We have learned to trust one another.'' The owners, however, have had little time or reason to celebrate their success. During tours in December and again last week, AFC officials talked of taking the lessons learned here to troubled projects elsewhere. They talk now about getting out of the low-income housing business while fighting HUD's sanctions. AFC, which denies any wrongdoing, said last week it is negotiating to turn over control of most of the 45,000 subidized apartment units it controls at 350 properties in 35 states. The dispute, likely to trigger a lengthy court battle, pits HUD against one of the nation's largest landlords of subsidized housing; 1988 Republican presidential hopeful Kemp against AFC President A. Bruce Rozet, who has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for Democrats. AFC is assuring the residents of Glenarden the fight with HUD won't make vain the battle being won here. ``We won't leave Glenarden until the work is finished,'' says AFC vice president Richard Tell, who has spent most of the past year at Glenarden supervising the renovations. ``We've come too far here to walk away now.'' A reminder of the stakes lies just down a hill from the first row of renovated units. The windows of this apartment are covered with plywood, the thin beams of sunlight sneaking past the edges providing the only inside light because the fixtures have been ripped from the walls and what is left of the ceiling. Broken glass and beer cans line the floor. ``Was a crack house,'' Jones says quietly. Outside, bulldozers are turning the giant complex into a handful of villages, a plan not only designed to give residents a greater sense of community but also to take away from dealers the easy escape routes police say stymied past attempts to curb the drug trade. Roads that once connected now are being blocked off, leaving just one access route for each village. The gate will be guarded by a tenant. The work is scheduled for completion in the fall. Then, Howerton says it will be up to the tenants. ``After what we've been through here, you have to learn a new way of thinking,'' she says. ``It's a matter of changing attitudes about the way you live. But we have a voice now. Because of that you're going to take pride in what you do and you're going to take care of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Base Talks Won't Be Easy
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney predicted Saturday that talks on the future of U.S. bases in the Philippines will be ``very difficult'' given a wave of anti-Americanism there. ``I ... sense that the political dynamics and the current environment are such that it's difficult to find elected leaders who are willing to stand up publicly and embrace the continuation of the current arrangement,'' Cheney told reporters while en route to Washington at the end of a two-week visit to Asian capitals. Cheney was burned in effigy and hundreds of protestors demanded the closure of the six U.S. military sites during the secretary's talks in Manila. The wrangle over the bases _ whose leases are due to expire in 1991 _ marred an otherwise successful trip for Cheney, his first to the region as defense secretary. President Corazon Aquino, upset over negative coverage of her coup-plagued government in the U.S. media and Congress' decision to cut $96 million in support for the bases, refused to see Cheyney during his visit. Yet he went out of his way to praise Mrs. Aquino and her committment to democracy, and Cheyney reported that she responded, albeit not in person. ``I received a nice response from her through a third party,'' Cheney said. He declined to identify the individual who carried the message. In talks with Philippine Defense Minister Fidel Ramos, Cheney said the United States would abandon the bases if it finds that keeping them is too expensive or that Americans are unwelcome. After Cheney left Manila, Mrs. Aquino said she was ready to discuss ``in security and good faith'' differences over compensation for the bases. Cheney, asked whether he was willing to name a date for such talks, would say only that Washington ``is eager to have the talks begin as soon as possible.'' They are expected to begin in April, but no date for opening the exploratory talks has been set. The defense secretary said he believes the majority of Filipinos want the Americans to stay. But there appeared to be little sympathy among the Philippine political leadership for the economic difficulties in Washington that have led to aid cutbacks and tough talk about compensation for the bases. ``The historic ties are strong,'' Cheney said. But, he added, ``I also came away from my trip ... with the view that the negotiations are going to be very difficult.'' Cheney said his effort to reassure Asian allies of the U.S. commitment to the Pacific was ``well received,'' even though he'd informed them that some 10,000 to 13,000 U.S. troops probably will be withdrawn from the region by 1993. His hosts in South Korea and Japan were willing to listen to his requests that they kick in additional support for those troops, he said. Cheney said the exact details of the drawdown have yet to be worked out, adding, ``the numbers could change by small amounts once we get it all together. ... I want to review carefully those plans myself.'' He said he couldn't predict a dollar amount in savings, saying that would depend on which units are chosen to be withdrawn. ``Clearly, we'll be able to save some money,'' he said. Asked about future cuts, he said he'd reassess the situation at the end of the three-year period for ``possible adjustment levels.'' ``But that will depend on developments. There's no way you can predict. ... what things are going to look like three years from now,'' he said. ``I think it was generally well received,'' Cheney said of his trip. He said his message of fewer troops and less money to pay for them may have come as a shock to some. ``Change is always a little disconcerting in the region, but I felt that, especially the Japanese and Koreans, were understanding and sympathetic and prepared to support the overall initiative,'' he said. The secretary was asked about prospects for opening U.S.-Soviet talks on troop levels in the region, given the opening he's taken with the unilateral force reduction. He didn't rule it out, but pointed to the difficulties surrounding such negotiations. In the Pacific and Asia, Cheyney said, ``We don't have the kind of formal framework you have in Europe,'' such as the NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances that allow for negotiations on conventional troop reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Must Decide Exxon Skipper's Sobriety from Inconclusive Evidence
DOC.TEXT: In the final days of prosecution testimony against Joseph Hazelwood, the state has revived the question of whether the Exxon Valdez skipper was drunk when his tanker went aground. The defense calls the issue ``a red herring,'' but its resolution by a jury will help determine whether Hazelwood is convicted or acquitted on an array of charges. After three weeks of testimony and 39 witnesses, there is extensive but inconclusive evidence about alcohol. Did Hazelwood spend a day ashore drinking before his ship sailed? Some crew members say he had a few drinks at a bar in the port city of Valdez. The wife of a Coast Guard investigator insists she saw the skipper drinking earlier than anyone else. And several witnesses said they smelled alcohol on his breath. But the skipper denies being drunk and not a single witness has said he appeared intoxicated. Repeatedly, defense attorneys have asked witnesses: ``Was the captain impaired? ... Did he slur his words? ... Did he stagger?'' The answer has been, ``No.'' In a last-minute effort to bolster his position, Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole proposed calling in speech experts from Canada and Indiana who claim they can tell by listening to speech patterns whether a person is intoxicated. The experts analyzed tapes of Hazelwood's conversations with the Coast Guard for the National Transportation Safety Board and concluded he sounded intoxicated. Defense attorney Michael Chalos called the speech analysis ``voodoo stuff'' and argued it has never been admitted as evidence in any U.S. court. ``I understand it's less reliable than a lie detector test, which is inadmissible,'' said Chalos. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, who chastised Cole for proposing this tactic so late, hasn't decided whether to allow the testimony. Hazelwood, 43, a seaman from Huntington, N.Y., has a history of drunken driving convictions and underwent 28 days of voluntary rehabilitation in 1985. But jurors can't be told about that because a defendant's prior record can't be used against him. Hazelwood is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, which is a felony, and three misdemeanors _ operating a vessel while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. He could draw 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted on all counts. Recklessness is a key element in proving the charges, and drunkenness would support a finding that Hazelwood was reckless in leaving the control of the tanker to a third mate and helmsman during a dangerous passage. The Exxon Valdez rammed jagged Bligh Reef on March 24, 10 minutes after Hazelwood had left the bridge. Its oil tanks were ripped open, gushing nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound, the nation's largest oil spill ever. Allegations that the captain was drunk surfaced soon after. ``This alcohol issue has been blown up out of proportion and had nothing to do with the grounding,'' said Thomas Russo, one of Hazelwood's defense lawyers. ``The whole hype that was put out about Captain Hazelwood being drunk hasn't panned out.'' Why, then, was the issue raised? Prosecutors have consistently declined to comment outside court, but their case shows that two investigators who boarded the Exxon Valdez shortly after its grounding reported smelling alcohol on the skipper's breath and called for blood alcohol tests of the crew. Hazelwood's test, administered 10{ hours after the grounding, showed he had a blood alcohol level of .06, lower than the Alaska state limit for driving but higher than Coast Guard limits for operating a commercial vessel. Others who were aboard reported smelling liquor on Hazelwood but seeing none of the physical effects of drunkenness. William Murphy, the marine pilot who boarded the Exxon Valdez to guide it through the tricky Valdez Narrows, testified Hazelwood was ``absolutely'' in command of his tanker although he detected the odor of alcohol on the skipper. Prosecutors played for jurors Friday a tape of Hazelwood's first post-accident interview in which he said he drank only one beer in Valdez and one or two bottles of Moussy, a brew with almost no alcohol that was permitted aboard the tanker. If so, how could his blood have tested positive for alcohol so long after the accident? A prosecution alcohol expert will try to explain, and after the state rests Tuesday, defense experts will give their theories.

DOC.HEAD: The Cruel Truth: Tax Laws No Less Mystifying This Year
DOC.TEXT: February has been a cruel month for people who like their taxes simple. It was during this month that most people began giving serious consideration to their tax returns; they opened up the instruction booklet and found the system generally is just as complicated as a year ago. So complicated, in fact, that Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. complained to the House Ways and Means Committee that the laws and regulations ``are imposing an unacceptable burden on taxpayers and our system of tax administration.'' If people can't understand the law, Goldberg said, they ``will engage in shortcuts and not fully comply. It's that simple: a 1 percent drop in compliance costs the treasury more than $5 billion.'' In the same Capitol Hill hearing room two weeks later, there was another message _ from dozens of special interests, ranging from big-time charities to low-income soldiers to tuxedo rental shops _ pleading for the kind of special tax breaks that add complexity to the law. And finally, the payoff: Money magazine announced that 50 tax professionals who had been commissioned to prepare the return of a hypothetical family came up with 50 different tax liabilities that ranged from $9,806 to $21,115. The magazine's $130,000-a-year, make-believe family had some tax problems that the typical family would never encounter, but some of the experts made mistakes on some basic issues, such as moving expenses, that even a low-paid American might have to confront. All this is happening 3{ years after Congress and then-President Reagan agreed on a major tax overhaul whose main selling points were fairness and simplicity. The new law made taxpaying simpler for as many as 6 million low-income people by removing them from the tax rolls. Another 10 million found things simpler because they lost some valuable deductions and no longer had reason to itemize. However, there was a consensus among witnesses testifying before Congress that the new law resulted in little simplification for most Americans. As a result, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has launched a new simplification initiative and asked the public for suggestions. Rostenkowski won't find many in Congress who disagree that the system is overly complex. As in the past, however, he is likely to hear warnings that in many cases, complexity is the price paid for fairness. For example, repealing the deduction for charitable contributions would free more than 25 million people from a lot of recordkeeping and paperwork, but it also would cost them a big deduction and could mean a loss of revenue for churches, schools and organizations that help the poor. The tax system is probably as simple as it is going to be for people whose incomes are almost entirely from wages, interest and dividends. Whatever simplification comes about in the near future probably will be for the benefit of those whose returns reflect a lot of stock transactions, partnership income and more exotic investments. Most of that simplification would have to come from the IRS, which writes thousands of pages of regulations each year spelling out exactly what the tax law means. Goldberg already has his own simplification initiative under way, aiming, for example, to produce basic regulations that are as broad as possible and that do not attempt to cover every conceivable exception. Such an approach might mean there might never be another 222-page regulation such as the one last year whose sole purpose was to define the term ``passive activity.'' The Bush administration also is pushing simplification, using the complexity argument to oppose several targeted tax breaks that were proposed to the Ways and Means Committee last week. However, the administration is recommending a package of targeted tax increases and tax cuts that would add their own complexity. The capital-gains tax cut that President Bush wants would have three different levels of taxation, depending on how long an asset was held. The president also wants to create four tax incentives for the oil industry and recommends a new deduction for parents who adopt children with special needs. Rostenkowski and other Democratic leaders recall that repeal of a capital-gains provision was a key factor that led to passage of the 1986 overhaul. They fear restoration of the benefit would be the first step toward repealing the overhaul and wiping out whatever simplification the law produced.

DOC.HEAD: Nazi Hunter's Claims Challenged By Founder of Israeli Security Agency
DOC.TEXT: The founder of Israel's security services says famed Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal played no significant role in the capture of Adolf Eichmann 30 years ago, despite Wiesenthal's claims to the contrary. ``Wiesenthal had no role whatsoever in either the discovery, the identification or the capture of Adolf Eichmann,'' Isser Harel says in an unpublished manuscript made available to The Associated Press. Harel challenges the enduring legend of Wiesenthal as the dogged tracker who supplied key information that enabled Israeli agents to locate the Nazi fugitive in Argentina. While not an entirely new dispute _ Harel and Wiesenthal clashed years ago _ the Harel manuscript was the most detailed effort yet to debunk Wiesenthal's claims. ``This is a matter of jealousy,'' Wiesenthal said in a telephone interview from Vienna. Harel said he held off disputing Wiesenthal before now because he did not want to ``give satisfaction to Jew-haters and Nazi sympathizers.'' But Harel said he could no longer keep quiet. He said that although he would not publish the manuscript commercially, he wanted it preserved for historians. ``History must express the truth about this case,'' he said. With few exceptions, the 79-year-old Harel has avoided the spotlight. He founded Mossad, the legendary Israeli intelligence agency, and masterminded the 1960 operation in which Mossad agents kidnapped Eichmann in Argentina and spirited him to Israel for trial. Eichmann ran the Gestapo bureau for Jewish affairs and was accused of responsibility for planning and ordering the deportation and murder of 4 million Jews. He was convicted by an Israeli court and hanged in 1962. While Harel remained largely unknown, the 81-year-old Wiesenthal gained world fame as a Nazi hunter, a reputation that began with accounts of his role in the Eichmann case. In books written over 30 years, Wiesenthal has recounted how he narrowly missed capturing Eichmann in Austria in 1949, kept track of his brothers and wife over the years, and supplied Israel with information about Eichmann's whereabouts in Argentina as far back as 1954. ``In all my books, I say it was team work. I never say I alone was responsible'' for the Eichmann capture, Wiesenthal said. Yet, repeatedly in published material and most recently in a 1989 Home Box Office movie about his life, Wiesenthal is depicted as instrumental to the Eichmann abduction. His first book, in 1961, was titled, ``I hunted Eichmann.'' ``Adolf Eichmann, whose spectacular capture was engineered by Wiesenthal,'' reads the flyleaf of Wiesenthal's latest book ``Justice Not Vengeance,'' scheduled for U.S. release next month. Harel does not dispute that Wiesenthal was among those who sought Eichmann, nor does he deny the Holocaust survivor's pivotal role in tracking Nazi fugitives and keeping alive international awareness of the German atrocities. But in his 270-page manuscript, he said, ``All the information supplied by Wiesenthal before and in anticipation of the operation was utterly worthless, and sometimes even misleading and of negative value.'' He repeated that assessment in a telephone interview from his home in suburban Tel Aviv. ``Just as it's very critical to accurately depict Nazi crimes, it is very important that the effort to bring to justice Nazi criminals be truthfully recorded,'' said Neal Sher, who heads the Justice Department's office of Nazi war crimes. While it is clear that many people were looking for Eichmann after the war, ``there can be no doubt that the most reliable and authoritative source on the Mossad operation that captured Eichmann is Isser Harel,'' said Sher, who teaches a course at Cornell University about the Eichmann trial. In the 1970s Harel told his account of the capture in a book entitled ``The House on Garibaldi Street,'' which is where Eichmann lived under an assumed name. Wiesenthal is not mentioned in the book. Harel's book ``gives generous credit to others involved in the affair,'' Sher said. Among those is Fritz Bauer, the West German prosecutor whom Harel identified as the source of the information that eventually led to Eichmann. Harel said he had not known the extent to which Wiesenthal took credit for the operation until he visited the United States last year on a fund-raising drive for Israel and repeatedly encountered audiences who asked about Wiesenthal's role. ``He tried to erode Israel's role in the affair,'' Harel said. Wiesenthal rejected the accusation, but said that when he passed on information to Israel in 1954 about Eichmann being in Argentina, ``no one believed me.'' When interviewed by a Mossad team in Austria in 1959, Wiesenthal said, he again provided valuable information. Yet in a March 3, 1960 summary of the interview, a translated version of which Harel made available, the Mossad operatives said: ``We again found Wiesenthal to be avoiding full and sincere cooperation, although he is prepared from time to time to feed the ambassador crumbs of general information. ... We parted from Wiesenthal very coldly.'' In his books, Wiesenthal tells of informing the German Embassy in Buenos Aires in December 1959 of Nazi fugitive Josef Mengele's last two known addresses in the Argentine capital. This was done as a test case to see whether the Argentine authorities, who were sympathetic to the thousands of Nazi fugitives in their country, would extradite the notorious death camp doctor, he said. Wiesenthal viewed their refusal to hand over Mengele as proof that they would also have refused an Israeli request for Eichmann's extradition. But Harel argues that Wiesenthal had no right to undertake such a risky step without the approval of Israel, which was at the same time closing in on both Eichmann and Mengele. Wiesenthal's action tipped off Mengele who ``decamped from the Argentine a few weeks before we reached Buenos Aires. ... Wiesenthal's initiative could have warned'' Eichmann too and jeopardized his capture, Harel added. ``Here, Wiesenthal's folly borders on the criminal,'' Harel wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Normal Ties Could Be Product of Election
With AM-Nicaragua Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The elections Sunday in Nicaragua are offering the United States and that deeply polarized Central American country a unique opportunity to have a more cooperative relationship after long years of bitter rivalry. But that outcome is far from certain, and Nicaragua could well continue to be a divisive issue both domestically and internationally if the election results are tainted by allegations of fraud, according to officials. For the Bush administration, the most desirable outcome would be a victory by opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro. This would bring about an early exchange of ambassadors, an end to the five-year U.S. trade embargo against Nicaragua and a renewal of U.S. aid for the first time in a decade. The thousands of Contra rebels stationed at base camps in Honduras presumably would lay down their arms and return to Nicaragua in peace. In addition, if the leftist government headed by President Daniel Ortega is returned to power in an honest process, the Bush administration has committed itself to a more normal relationship, provided certain conditions are met in the election's aftermath. Secretary of State James. A. Baker III said Thursday his price for friendlier ties is a ``sustained period of good behavior'' by the Sandinistas. As the election approaches, Republicans and Democrats _ so often at loggerheads over Nicaragua during the 1980s _ find themselves generally in agreement on the basic elements of the situation. If Ortega wins and shows he is both committed to democratic values and to refraining from interfering in neighboring countries, the administration and the Congress agree that a new era in U.S.-Nicaraguan relations is possible. The only differences are in the pace and scope of normalization; Democrats generally seem willing to move more quickly and comprehensively than Republicans. But what happens if Ortega declares victory in a situation in which his announced margin is narrow and there are widespread allegations of fraud? This outcome is widely expected among State Department experts on Nicaragua. Although most polls in Nicaragua show Ortega with a comfortable lead, officials here believe Mrs. Chamorro has the votes to defeat Ortega. The concern among officials is that Sandinista authorities will be able to rig the result in Ortega's favor despite the presence of about 2,000 foreign observers. President Bush will encounter a variety of competing pressures if Ortega wins a disputed victory. If Bush decides that the political costs of contesting such an outcome are too high, he could declare it a flawed but acceptable result and then proceed slowly toward normalization of relations. Some analysts argue that this course would benefit long-range U.S. interests because the hand of hardliners in the Sandinista government, including Interior Minister Tomas Borge, is weakened when U.S. policies are conciliatory. Under this scenario, Ortega also would be more inclined to loosen his ties to his chief hemispheric ally, Cuba. The offer of U.S. trade ties and financial assistance, according to this theory, would give Ortega an incentive not to run afoul of Washington. Alternatively, a tainted Ortega victory almost certainly would produce conservative pressure on Bush not to endorse a process in which there is a strong perception that the will of the Nicaraguan people has been trampled. Former Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams says he is concerned that if the administration blesses an election stolen by Ortega, this would only embolden the Sandinistas to accelerate their assistance to leftist rebels in El Salvador. Abrams says that during the past 2{ years, the Sandinistas have dishonored every promise they have made concerning their links to the FMLN rebels. ``How many agreements have the Sandinistas signed promising to stop arming the FMLN?'' he says. Whatever the outcome Sunday, there appears to be little support here for restarting the Contra war. It was two years ago this month that Congress ended military aid to the rebels. A $49.5 million program of U.S. humanitarian aid for the Contras is about to expire, and the administration soon will open consultations with the Congress on what to do next. Democrats generally will favor an aid program designed to repatriate the Contras while the administration is likely to support a continuation of the existing program, under which food and other aid is provided without strings.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda covers foreign affairs for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed As Warship Attacks Passenger Ferry
LaserPhotos NIC3,NIC4
DOC.TEXT: A Syrian gunboat apparently looking for arms shipments to Lebanon shelled a passenger ferry traveling from Cyprus to Lebanon on Saturday, killing one civilian and injuring 18, crew members and military officials said. The dead man was identified as a 26-year-old Lebanese who had just obtained an emigration vist to Canada and was headed home to pick up his pregnant wife. Crew members said the attackers menaced the Baroness M before pumping 20 shells into it as it headed for the Lebanese port of Jounieh. The ship was flying a Syrian flag and was apparently on guard against weapons shipments to Lebanon, where the Christian army leader opposes the Syrian-backed government and the presence of 40,000 Syrian soldiers deployed to quell civil war fighting. Military sources on Cyprus, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they also believed the boat that attacked was Syrian. Greek Capt. George Samlotakis said the gunboat accosted the ferry three times, first at about 4:30 a.m. when it was 19 miles west of Jounieh. ``They asked us who was on board and where we were going,'' said Egyptian mechanic Mohammed Mohammed al-Murshidi, 27. He said he talked with them because most of the ferry crew spoke on Greek or English, while those on the gunboat spoke Arabic. Samlotakis said he then turned the ferry back to Cyprus and about 30 minutes later the gunboat approached at great speed. ``I immediately prepared to stop and was in the process of doing so when suddenly, and without any warning, the gunboat opened fire against us,'' said the captain. Salmotakis said 20 shells hit the ship, wrecking his cabin right below the bridge and heavily damaging the bar and cafeteria on the deck below, where many people had taken cover. ``There was terrible confusion and panic on board. There was smoke and dust everywhere and people screaming,'' he said. ``We ran from one side of the boat to the other as the gunboat circled,'' said Rima Suleiman, a receptionist on the boat. The captain said at dawn, two hours after the first encounter, passengers and crew went to the top deck and waved flags and sheets at the warship to signal that they needed help for the wounded. Crew member Danny Zarour said at that point, the gunboat took down its flag. It stayed in the distance for awhile, then approached a third time, the captain said. ``As if nothing had happened he ordered me to open the back gangplank so that he could examine our cargo,'' he said. The Baroness M, designed to take cars on and off the back ramp, usually travels with an empty hull to Lebanon. Only the passenger baggage is stored in the area for cars. ``We told him we were a Greek ship under the Cyprus flag and he told us go back to our country and don't try to come to Lebanon again,'' Samlotakis said. The attack wounded 18 passengers, four critically, said a spokesman for the British Royal Air Force bases on Cyprus. The Royal Air Force has a major base at Akrotiri on the southern coast of the island. The Royal Air Force evacuated 15 of the wounded by helicopter before the ferry docked at Larnaca at 1 p.m., said the spokesman, who declined to be identified. The wounded, most suffering cuts and burns in the legs from shrapnel, were rushed to local hospitals for treatment. The dead man was identified as Nasr Abu Nasr, 26. ``He was hit by shrapnel all over his body,'' said Ms. Suleiman. ``He was sitting facing the bar exactly where a shell hit.'' Nora Kasbari, spokesman for Socomar, agents for the ship, said it carried 64 passengers and 52 crew members when it left Larnaca late Friday for the seven-hour trip to Jounieh, 120 miles east. The boat is one of two that travels regularly between Lebanon and Cyprus. It is a main escape route for Christians fleeing their embattled enclave in Lebanon, where Christian army forces are battling for control over the Lebanese Forces Christian militia. The port of Jounieh is controlled by the Lebanese Forces, which also has a share in the ferry operations. The ferry service and other maritime traffic came under fire repeatedly during six months of fighting in Lebanon in 1989 between the Christian army leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, and the Syrian army and its Moslem militia allies. Syrian troops were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 under a peacekeeping mandate to quell civil war fighting. Aoun said they violated the mandate by siding with the Moslems in the war and vowed to drive them out.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Killing Wife One Week After They Reunited in Canada
DOC.TEXT: A man who emigrated from Poland 2{ years ago has been charged with strangling his wife one week after she arrived in Canada with their two children to join him, authorities said. Marian Frej, 42, was charged Friday with second-degree murder after an autopsy indicated that his wife, Joanna, 34 had been strangled. Her body was found Thursday in the bedroom of her husband's townhouse. The victim arrived in Canada from Poland on Feb. 16 with the couple's two children, ages four and six, said city police inspector Jim Balmain. The children are now in the care of another family member living in the southwestern Ontario city, said police. Marian Frej, who was unemployed, had been studying English at a local college. There was no known motive for the killing.

DOC.HEAD: American Plane Burns During Demonstration Flight
DOC.TEXT: An American jet caught fire while landing at a Chinese airport during a demonstration flight, but all seven crew members escaped uninjured, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Saturday. Xinhua said the Lear-31 was owned by the Lear Jet Corp. It was landing in Taiyuan, the capital of Shanxi province, 255 miles southwest of Beijing, when the accident occurred Friday. Chinese aviation authorities were investigating the cause of the accident, Xinhua said. It did not say why Lear conducted the demonstration or for whom.

DOC.HEAD: Lively Entertainment Planned For Governors Visiting White House
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has invited not only the nation's governors to dinner Sunday, but the entire population of Tuna, Texas, to boot. And they are all coming, in the persons of Jaston Williams and Joe Sears, the comic actors and quick-change artists who put Tuna on the theatrical map back in 1982. They have since performed ``Greater Tuna,'' their two-man, two-dozen character take-off on small-town Texas life nearly 2,000 times from Austin to off-Broadway to Edinburgh, and this past December they unveiled a seasonal sequel, ``A Tuna Christmas,'' that broke records at the Kennedy Center. It was there that two transplanted Texans now residing at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, George and Barbara Bush, decided the madcap spectacle of two guys jumping in and out of dresses, overalls, wigs and characters would be just the thing to cap an evening with the governors. The state dinner, for governors, in town for their winter meeting, is a traditional event. Pianist Michael Feinstein performed last year. But who would have thought a Republican president from Yale would get a kick out of two avowedly liberal entertainers who first conceived their ``Tuna'' satire as a thumb-in-your-eye riposte to the Moral Majority? ``You just never know,'' said Williams, ``but we knew better than to say no.'' The Bushes came backstage after taking in the show Jan. 6 on their 45th wedding anniversary. ``The president asked if we were from Texas. He leaned to Mrs. Bush and said, `We must have these boys over to the White House,''' Williams recalled in an interview. They were still in their dressing gowns during that encounter. When they showed up for tea with Mrs. Bush 10 days later, they were wearing their Sunday finest. ``She's a very clever and funny lady. She had seen us in our Texas attire backstage,'' said Williams. At the White House, she eyed them and remarked, ``Well, you two clean up real nice!'' Then she invited them back for the state dinner. Sears and Williams were also invited to dine with the governors, but the duo is passing up the supper. ``We said we would just prefer to be backstage and warming up,'' said Williams. ``It would be a little hard to eat before the performance.'' The two will perform four scenes and six characters during the 25-minute skit. From ``Greater Tuna'' they will reprise a sermon by a Bible-belting preacher and a funeral parlor viewing. They will replay the holiday party from ``A Christmas Tuna.'' They will close the evening with a skit especially written for the occasion: a telephone call to the White House from a Tastee Kreme waitress. ``Joe will be bringing Aunt Pearl (Burras), Reverend Spike and Bertha Bumiller,'' said Williams, ``and I will be bringing Vera Carp, Helen Bedd and Arles Struvie.'' Both actors now live in the Austin area. Williams was born in El Paso, Sears in Oklahoma. After years as struggling actors performing traditional fare, their take-off on life in the third smallest town in Texas has brought both fame and fortune. Wiliams said his father, ``a grizzled, crusty old farmer, told me, `Son, if you'd ever known what was going to happen, you should have put that dress on 25 years ago.'' ``When you can get your father to say that, I guess we have crossed the last hurdle,'' said Williams. Or the next to last. Arles Struvie, Bertha Bumiller & Co. may cross the last hurdle in the East Room Sunday night.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Probers Eye Multiple Charges in Durenberger Case
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee is using a standard tool of prosecutors _ combining major and minor charges _ to establish a potential pattern of misconduct by Sen. Dave Durenberger in promoting his books, sources say. The committee on Thursday found ``substantial credible evidence'' that the Minnesota Republican violated Senate rules and federal law, mostly in promoting two books he authored. The panel voted to hold a trial-like proceeding. Durenberger has launched a public relations effort that emphasizes the less serious charges. His spokeswoman, Carrie Collins, characterizes four of five potential rules violations as minor ``bookkeeping'' or financial reporting errors. But sources familiar with the case, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the combined allegations suggest a pattern of behavior that violated Senate rules to enable Durenberger to sell books. And one allegation that Ms. Collins calls minor could escalate into a major problem, sources said, if evidence shows a willful attempt to file false financial disclosure reports. Former Rep. George Hansen, R-Idaho, was convicted in 1984 of four felony counts for submitting false financial disclosure statements to Congress. He served nearly a year in prison. The sources said the committee is mainly concerned in the case with rulebreaking, not criminality, but the panel is obligated to refer any criminal evidence to the Justice Department. In the possible violation that everyone agrees is major, the committee said Durenberger may have exceeded limits on non-Senate income when he accepted payments for speeches during 1985-86. Durenberger contends the money should not have counted toward the limit, because he made the appearances as an author promoting books _ not in his official capacity as a senator. Also during 1985-86, the committee said, Durenberger failed to publicly disclose the travel reimbursements he received from the organizations that hosted the book promotion speeches. Last July, four months after the committee began its investigation, the senator amended his annual Senate disclosure forms to include the information. This is the potentially troublesome allegation, sources said. Former House Speaker Jim Wright resigned from Congress last year after he was charged with 69 instances of rulebreaking _ including evading outside income limits through bulk sales of his book. Other allegations cited by the Senate committee against Durenberger involve: possible conversion of a $5,000 campaign contribution to personal use by transferring the check to Durenberger's publisher; using Senate space for commercial purposes and acceptance of limousine service in the Boston area in 1985-86. The limousine was provided by host organizations so Durenberger could visit his marriage counselor in Concord, Mass. The sources said the allegations are similar to a prosecutor bringing felony and misdemeanor charges against a criminal defendant. The lesser charges often would not have been brought by themselves but become an important part of the case. Durenberger's public relations blitz, meanwhile, expanded Friday. The senator sent a tape to all Minnesota radio and television stations pronouncing himself pleased that the committee will now ``get some sunshine on the facts.'' Durenberger chief-of-staff Bert McKasy also released a question-and-answer sheet to news organizations, emphasizing that two potential allegations were dropped and the remaining case has ``been considerably narrowed.'' Tom Horner, the senator's former chief-of-staff and now a public relations executive in Bloomington, Minn., was hired recently by Durenberger to aid in the counter-attack. Horner was quoted in Minneapolis as saying, ``The senator has a concern that the full story is not getting out.''

DOC.HEAD: Tennessee Rep. Asks Justice To Collect Fine from Former Senator
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Harrison A. Williams Jr. still owes the federal government much of his 1981 fine for bribery and conspiracy and a Tennessee congressman says he should use his federal pension to pay off the debt. Current law allows the U.S. government to recover debts from federal employees by making deductions from their salaries and retirement pay, the Justice Department says. However, it has never been tried with a member of Congress, according to Assistant Attorney General Carol T. Crawford. ``The law is there apparently, but they've just never applied it,'' said Jim Edwards, a spokesman for freshman Rep. John J. Duncan, R-Tenn. ``I don't believe in kicking a man when he is down,'' Duncan said of Williams, D.-N.J. ``However, the fact is that Senator Williams owes the government money while he is being paid a government retirement check. This situation should be corrected.'' Duncan said only $2,324.23 of Williams' $50,000 fine has been collected so far. Williams, reached earlier this month in New Jersey where he has been helping at a drug treatment program, said attorney John D. Arsenault was handling payment of the fine. ``It's worked out through my lawyer,'' Williams said. ``I know Jack has worked out a program. And I'm going to be abiding with it. It's all taken care of.'' Phone calls to Arsenault's office in New Jersey were not returned. Williams was released from prison in January 1986 after serving two years of concurrent two-year and three-year sentences for bribery, conflict of interest and conspiracy in the Abscam sting. In that FBI operation, undercover agents posing as middlemen for Arab sheiks met with Williams. He agreed to accept a hidden interest in a Virginia titanium mine in return for helping to find military contracts for the venture, according to evidence at trial. Williams said in the telephone interview that the Abscam matter was not yet behind him and he had filed Freedom of Information requests to obtain material that could clear his name. Duncan began pursuing the matter of unpaid federal debts at the request of Knoxville, Tenn., Mayor Victor Ashe, who had seen published reports last September that Williams had drawn more than $320,000 from a federal pension while owing most of his $50,000 Abscam fine, Edwards said. After a series of letters, Ms. Crawford wrote Duncan on Jan. 25, 1990, that the U.S. attorney's office in New Jersey was exploring the possibility of pension deductions. ``Based on your and Mayor Ashe's inquiry, the U.S. attorney's office is now investigating the applicability of these provisions to Senator Williams' case and will utilize them to the extent possible to recover his federal fine,'' she said. Spokesmen for the Justice Department in Washington and the U.S. attorney's office in Newark declined to say whether they had proceeded with deductions. ``We are actively pursuing the funds that we feel the department is entitled to,'' said Doug Tillett of the Justice Department's criminal division. ``The matter is in litigation,'' said Dick Lavinthal, a spokesman for the U.S. attorney in New Jersey. ``When there is an outstanding debt to the government we pursue it.'' Ms. Crawford informed Duncan that other routes had been pursued in collecting Williams' debt, such as seizing his federal income tax refunds. However, she said Williams owns no real property and his Bedminster, N.J., home was purchased in his wife's name, preventing the government from using it to satisfy the debt.

DOC.HEAD: City Hospitals Abandoning Trauma Care, Citing High Costs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AP Extra
With LaserPhoto NY304 of Feb. 22
DOC.TEXT: The helicopter appears as a pinlight on the northern horizon, the brightest star in a dark blue sky. Coming closer, it shoots a wide beam of light over the rooftop at Jackson Memorial Hospital and settles down with a shuddering blast of tropical air. Two men inside have been shot twice each with 9mm bullets, and one is dying. Dr. Jeff Vaughan, waiting on the landing pad, turns to a nurse. ``You're going to see blood now, sister,'' he says. But spilled blood is routine at Jackson Memorial's trauma center. Already this evening, the trauma crew has treated a woman shot by her boyfriend, a man dumped 30 feet off a scaffold, a 10-year-old bicyclist hit by a car and a prison inmate stabbed with a homemade knife. That roster accounts for every serious injury suffered in the Miami metropolitan area in the preceding six hours. If you're badly hurt in Dade County these days, the only place to go is Jackson Memorial. That distinction puts Jackson, a publicly financed teaching hospital, at the forefront of a dismal national trend. It is one of a shrinking number of big city hospitals offering special care for trauma, the medical name given to life-threatening injuries. In Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia and elsewhere, private hospitals have been shutting down trauma units, most of which opened in the mid-1980s, the specialty's boom years. The resulting squeeze threatens not only quality of health care, but also the financial stability of the hospitals left carrying the load. Gunfights, car crashes, the occasional industrial accident _ these are the lifeblood of trauma care centers. The American College of Surgeons estimates that 250 to 350 trauma centers operate around the country, ranging from such giants as New York's Bellevue Hospital and Miami's Jackson Memorial to the N.T. Enloe Hospital in Chico, Calif., and Easton Hospital in Easton, Pa. Trauma units are usually affiliated with, but distinct from, ordinary emergency rooms. ERs handle broken legs, concussions, poisonings, the lesser varieties of mayhem. Trauma units take over in more serious cases of multiple injuries _ when lives are on the line. Trauma centers are staffed by surgeons, and major trauma hospitals keep full staffs of specialists on duty around the clock. If you need a neurosurgeon at 3 a.m., Jackson Memorial will have one. In rural and suburban areas, trauma is almost always the result of auto accidents, and the drivers are usually insured. In these areas, trauma centers pay their way, even make profits. But in inner cities, patients increasingly are members of what doctors caustically refer to as ``the knife and gun club.'' Club members have a couple of things in common: They are almost always involved in drugs; they are almost never insured. At Jackson Memorial, which handles 6,000 trauma cases a year, about one-third of the patients are admitted for ``penetrating trauma'' _ knife or bullet wounds. About one-third of the patients are uninsured. These are expensive injuries, and ``blunt trauma'' injuries suffered in car crashes can be even costlier. It's not unusual for trauma-care bills to mount into the tens or even hundreds of thousands of dollars. ``Even with the paying patient, trauma is going to cost more than the average treatment, more than what insurance will probably pay,'' said Jeanne Eckes, a registered nurse who coordinates Jackson's trauma service. Jackson estimates the trauma unit will lose at least $1.2 million this next fiscal year. In addition to direct losses, the hospital loses money when trauma patients ``bump'' regular patients out of operating rooms and intensive care beds. That happens nearly every day. Of four patients admitted to Jackson's trauma center so far this evening, three have been sent to the operating room or intensive care. The lone exception is the luckless prison inmate, who's been treated for his stab wounds and sent back to jail. It is already a grueling evening, filled with split-second, life-or-death decisions. Even the janitor is busy, mopping up blood from the trauma room floor. On a break in the action, Vaughan and another doctor, Alan Rosenberg, wolf down dinner in the cafeteria. They are there when Air Rescue calls about 10 p.m. Two men with gunshot wounds had shown up at a hospital eight miles away. They couldn't be treated there _ the hospital doesn't handle trauma. They are being flown to Jackson. On the elevator to the roof, Rosenberg and Vaughan turn goofy with excitement. They stretch out on the two gurneys and joke and slap five. They don't get serious until the helicopter is down, and then, with the blades still blurring overhead, they get serious in a hurry. Vaughan is first into the elevator with the more seriously wounded man. Before the doors shut, he is frantically at work. ``He's not moving any air, man,'' he says, his voice tight with tension. He shoves a tube down the man's nose and squeezes a bulbous green bag. A hole in the patient's chest gurgles with blood. When the elevator reaches the ground floor, Vaughan runs with the gurney to the trauma room. His patient is slipping away. Patients like this are flown to Jackson every day. The hospital tallies more than 1,000 helicopter landings a year in what some doctors say is a legacy of the Vietnam War _ the airborne rescue. Some people say the entire modern system of trauma care grew out of the military's medical experience in Vietnam; others say it evolved in large urban hospitals in the 1960s. Trauma care grew rapidly after research in the late 1970s proved trauma centers routinely saved lives that would be lost with ordinary emergency care. By the early to mid-1980s, trauma had become hot business. In search of prestige and profits, hospitals jumped at the opportunity to treat trauma victims, despite the expense of maintaining a 24-hour staff of surgical specialists. Some cities established trauma networks to ensure patients were sent to the closest trauma hospital. Miami's network, established in 1985, ultimately consisted of six private hospitals and the public Jackson Memorial. B. Boyd Benjamin, the blunt-talking, gravel-voiced chairman of the board of the Dade County Public Health Trust, recalls what happened then. ``It was wonderful,'' he said. ``Big committees met, everything was fine. And the first thing that happened, I guess, was some poor sonofabitch got run over and didn't have a penny and he ends up at one of these for-profit hospitals. And they want to ask, `Where's your insurance?' `I don't have any insurance.' ... They found out very quickly that this was going to be a loser.'' In the space of six months in 1987, all six private hospitals dropped out of the network, leaving Jackson the only metropolitan area hospital willing to accept adult trauma patients (Miami Children's Hospital accepts injured children). A similar winnowing process has taken place in other big cities as hospitals discover their expected profits are elusive. ``They see it as fiscally irresponsible,'' said Dr. Gerald O. Strauch, director of the Trauma Department at the American College of Surgeons in Chicago. ``We all know that hospitals have become big business, and they're managed like a big business.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: MIAMI: big business.''
DOC.TEXT: In Los Angeles County, a regional trauma network with 23 hospitals has shrunk to 13. Chicago had 10 adult trauma hospitals two years ago; the loss of another hospital this month will reduce the number to six. Houston is down to just one Level I trauma center, capable of handling the most serious cases. One of Philadelphia's major trauma centers, Temple University Hospital, recently announced it was leaving a regional trauma system. The hospitals that remain are increasingly overwhelmed, their trauma centers resembling nothing so much as military MASH units in the heat of battle. Indeed, the military sends its physicians to inner city trauma centers to prepare them for combat. The consolidation of trauma care raises some daunting questions. What happens to the patient who's in a serious auto accident and has to be taken 25 miles to a hospital instead of five? Worse, what happens when a plane crashes? ``It's gotten to the point where, no matter who you are, if you're injured in a city, your chances of getting to a trauma center that has everything it needs are getting slimmer,'' said Dr. Jeff Augenstein, one of the attending surgeons in charge at Jackson. Jackson's administrators believe they've found a solution. Having accepted their hospital's role as the city's only trauma-care center, they intend to capitalize on it. They are now trying to raise $25 million for what Benjamin, the public health trust's board chairman, calls a ``state of the art, world class, self-contained, free-standing shock-trauma center.'' The idea is to get trauma patients out of the main hospital, leaving more room there for regular, paying patients. ``Our projections show that we will at least break even,'' Benjamin said. Hospital officials hope the new center will become a magnet for research dollars and talented staff. In the meantime, doctors at Jackson insist they can handle anything that comes their way. It is 10:14 p.m. when Jeff Vaughan wheels the gurney into the trauma room. Half a dozen people jump to action. One slips an oxygen mask over the patient's face, another takes blood. Vaughan examines the body. It is young and strong and has bullet holes in the chest and shoulder. Two police officers stand to the side, watching. ``Where's X-ray?'' Vaughan hollers. ``C'mon, Hector, let's get a quick film.'' At 10:18, Vaughan inserts a tube nearly the width of a garden hose into the left side of the man's chest. It begins pumping hemorrhaging blood out of the chest cavity and into intravenous tubes for transfusion. Vaughan's rubber gloves and gown are covered with blood; red dots shine on his eyeglass lenses. ``What's his pressure?'' someone shouts. ``Very, very low,'' Vaughan yells back. ``He's got serious problems in his chest.'' He goes to the other side and inserts another tube. ``We've got blood on this side too, guys, and lots of it.'' Within minutes, the crisis ebbs. The patient's systolic blood pressure, about 50 when he entered the trauma room, is up to 110. His pulse is strong. He breathes with the aid of the oxygen mask. The gurney is pushed out the door and up to the operating room. ``He's a long way from being OK, but he's got a chance,'' Vaughan says. Bloody footprints mark the path down the hall. It has been a remarkable display of grace under pressure, but it isn't enough this time. The patient dies 10 minutes into surgery. His buddy survives, and not for the first time. Medical records show he's been treated at Jackson before for gunshot wounds _ six times. ``Hey, man, you gonna get some frequent flier miles if you keep coming in here,'' Vaughan tells him. Police say the two men claimed to have been attacked on the street for no reason; the cops' tone suggests disbelief. Vaughan drifts into an employee lounge for a Dr Pepper and a smoke. He is about 18 hours into a 24-hour shift and it is beginning to show. He speaks bitterly about the strains of the job and patients who ``would just as soon kill us as look at us.'' ``It's a war zone,'' he says. ``And it's like this in every major city.''

DOC.HEAD: In Emotional Vote, Brandt Named Honorary Chairman of East German Party
LaserPhoto LEI1
DOC.TEXT: East German Social Democrats, many overcome with emotion and with tears in their eyes, on Saturday elected former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt as their party's honorary chairman. Brandt was among many top-ranking West German Social Democrats attending the first national convention of the East German sister party in Leipzig. Public opinion polls have predicted the East German Social Democrats will be the leading contenders in next month's national elections. The 76-year-old Brandt received a standing ovation after his election. He is also honorary chairman of West Germany's Social Democrats, who form that country's biggest opposition party. Brandt was mayor of West Berlin when the Berlin Wall was built in 1961. As chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, he worked for improved relations between East and West. His efforts won him the Nobel Peace Prize in 1971 and made him a hero to many East Germans. Brandt was one of the first West German officials to step into East Berlin after the Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9 at the height of the pro-democracy movement that made next month's elections possible. Social Democrats in both countries have been urging East Germans to stay and work for changes at home. Already this year, more than 100,000 East Germans have resettled in West Germany. ``It's worthwhile to stay here, it's worthwhile to start again,'' Brandt told the 500 delegates. ``It doesn't make sense to run away from a large part of Germany.''
