Despite the enthusiastic reception, there was some resistance to making Brandt the honorary chairman. Several delegates argued that an East German should have the title.

DOC.HEAD: Candlelit Ceremony Celebrates Revolt That Brought Aquino to Power
LaserPhoto MLA2
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people celebrated the anniversary of the revolt that brought President Corazon Aquino to power by lighting candles Saturday at an intersection where Ferdinand Marcos' tanks were stopped in 1986. Elsewhere in Manila, Mrs. Aquino urged Filipinos to rekindle the spirit of the 1986 ``People Power'' revolt to prevent further coup attempts. Mrs. Aquino spoke to civil rights activists on the eve of the 4th anniversary of the military-civilian uprising that ended President Marcos' 20-year rule and forced him into exile in Hawaii. He died there in September. Hundreds of nuns, priests, businessmen, public officials and other citizens marched from the armed forces headquarters to an intersection a few miles away to offer prayers and thanks for the revolution. The marchers formed a human chain and put the lit candles in the shape of a giant cross. In 1986, citizens opposed to Marcos stopped soldiers and tanks sent to the intersection to crush the rebellion. Mrs. Aquino _ who will lead a public celebration on Sunday, the anniversary of the revolt _ criticized rebel soldiers who launched a December coup attempt, the sixth and bloodiest bid to unseat her. ``Recently, our freedom was once again threatened by those who believe that this government could be cowed by guns,'' Mrs. Aquino said. She said the mutineers ``never learned their lesson. That if we stood up, unafraid, for freedom in 1986, we will do the same this year, next year or any year whenever our liberty is in danger.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Arrives For Talks With Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT spelling of Mitterrand; SUBS 7th to remove extraneous material.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to his countryside retreat today, saying their talks are of ``keen interest'' to people around the world. Just before Kohl arrived by helicopter from Dulles International Airport near Washington, Bush told reporters he spoke this morning to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney about his forthcoming meeting with Kohl. He said he also would talk with French President Francois Mitterrand and other leaders as world attention focuses on the fast-moving developments toward reunifying East Germany and West Germany. ``I view this as a very important discussion,'' he said. ``There's a lot of keen interest not just in Europe but around the world on these discussions we're going to have.'' Light snow flurries fell as Bush, clad in a leather flight jacket and wool slacks, and his wife, Barbara, welcomed Kohl and his wife, Hannelore, to Camp David, the retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. ``Welcome, welcome,'' said Bush. ``Wunderbar,'' Kohl replied before getting into a golf cart in which Bush drove him from a helicopter landing zone to the Camp David living quarters. Their talks are expected to focus on the rapid movement toward reunification and when negotiations should be held on bringing the two Germanys back together. Kohl's visit comes as East Germany nears its critical March 18 elections. One of his cabinet ministers predicted in a news report Friday that the election will leave the East too divided to agree on a government, and East Germany instead will opt for immediate union with West Germany. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed this view to Secretary of State James A. Baker III and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, the newspaper report said. Sometime after the March 18 election, talks on unification are to begin between East and West Germany and the four major victories allies of World War II _ the United States, France, the Soviet Union and Great Britain. Baker and Scowcroft are joining Bush and Kohl today for the Camp David meeting. Bush and Kohl both support reunification and agree a united Germany should be a member of NATO. Besides discussing the timing of unification talks, they will also discuss the future of U.S. troops in Europe. ``I would expect the two leaders to discuss the full range of issues related to changes in Eastern Europe,'' including reunification, a U.S. proposal on reducing conventional forces in Europe, and the future of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater on Friday. ``We don't anticipate any new agreements or announcements,'' Fitzwater said. He said the meeting was a chance for the leaders ``to discuss the status of events, where they think things are going,'' including West Germany's newly announced proposal for a one-to-one currency exchange with East Germany. Kohl, just back from a trip to Moscow, also will give Bush an account of his meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is talking now of a slower approach to reunification. The Camp David agenda could also include Poland's icy reception to the movement toward reuniting Germany. Poland is worried that a larger, Western-oriented Germany might reclaim territory that was part of Germany but became part of Poland after World War II. Kohl has taken no position, but West German conservatives are pressing to regain the territory. Bush has said his administration recognizes existing borders. Kohl comes to the United States on the heels of the Feb. 13 agreement in Ottawa calling for the two Germanies to develop a unification plan and meet with the four other powers to approve it and work out larger security issues. Under political pressure at home, Kohl also is looking to the possibility that reunification will bring his party greater support in elections scheduled for Dec. 2 in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Who Seized Armory Unlikely Rebel
DOC.TEXT: With his seizure of an armory to house overflow prisoners, a mild-mannered county lawman with a master's degree in social work was catapulted into a confrontation with state officials. Hampden County Sheriff Michael J. Ashe had been best known for innovative jail and community programs, ranging from one of the first day reporting centers in the country to a jail garden teaming inmates and senior citizens. Then on Feb. 16 he seized the National Guard armory, an action applauded by guards, judges, citizens and even prisoners. He's become a hero on radio talk shows. But the plain-spoken sheriff, who never misses a wake or a wedding and once sneaked off to a McDonald's to fill up after a fancy state dinner at the White House, says he's never fancied himself as a rebel. ``I've always been a team player,'' he said. ``For the past 15 years I've been here we've worked very, very hard in a professional way to try to manage the severe overcrowding.'' ``We've looked in closets, in the garage and under the stairs. And we've had prisoners in all those places. But there comes a point where you run out of a `little magic.' And you just have to go into the ring.'' The sheriff admitted the timing of his move on the Friday afternoon before the Presidents Day holiday was calculated. By the time stunned state officials responded, he had 15 prisoners installed in the armory and public opinion solidly in his corner. On Friday, state officials told a judge they would not challenge his occupation for at least two weeks while looking for other housing. Saturday, the number of prisoners stood at 17. For more than a decade, Ashe's knack of mixing toughness and progressive social programs has kept a lid on his century-old county jail. ``He believes inhumanity and coddling arrive at the same point,'' said Richard McCarthy, jail spokesman. Rather than let prisoners lie in their cells all day, McCarthy said, ``whether it is one of the vocational programs or working in the kitchen, the men have to answer the bell every morning just like John Q. on the street and just like they will have to do when they get out.'' One of the first things Ashe did after taking over the job in 1975 was to turn the sheriff's quarters at the jail into a 60-bed pre-release center where inmates within six months of release get extensive vocational, substance abuse and other counseling. In 1986 he added the day reporting center, where inmates with four months left to serve can be released on a electronic monitoring program that allows them to live at home as long as they report in several times a day. More than 1,500 of the men that passed through his cells have earned high school equivalency diplomas. He also started one of the few prison industry programs to operate in a county jail. Last year the office furniture-making operation returned $200,000 in profits to the county, McCarthy said. Ashe reached the end of his patience with jail overcrowding after more than a year of turning loose hundreds of prisoners to meet a 500-inmate limit established by a federal judge. Previously, Ashe had jammed 726 men into space supposed to house 279. ``It came down to a moral and ethical thing,'' Ashe maintained, saying he could no longer live with the fear of having one of the prisoners he released kill or maim. ``The system had collapsed. And someone had to do something.'' Born and raised in the Irish neighborhoods of Springfield, Ashe married his high school sweetheart. Before running for sheriff, he worked as a social worker, and he and his wife, Barbara, were the first house parents in a program started by the Roman Catholic Church to help homeless children. They have five sons and one daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Opens Way for Swaggart-Gorman Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge has refused to dismiss television evangelist Jimmy Swaggart and seven others from a $90 million lawsuit filed by a preacher. Civil District Judge Richard Ganucheau ruled Friday in the lawsuit filed by Marvin Gorman on Metairie. ``We're disappointed in the result, and we will proceed with trial preparation,'' said Denise Pilie, Swaggart's attorney. Hunter Lundy, Gorman's attorney, said the case could go to trial this summer. Gorman claims Swaggart and others conspired to ruin his reputation and his New Orleans-area television ministry by spreading false stories that Gorman had numerous adulterous affairs. Gorman acknowledged one illicit sexual encounter. At a Dec. 20 hearing, Swaggart's attorneys told Ganucheau that statements made about Gorman were substantially correct and were made as part of Assemblies of God disciplinary procedures in which courts have no right to interfere. However, Gorman's attorneys argued that Swaggart and others made defamatory statements long after Gorman left that church. Swaggart also was eventually ousted from the Assemblies of God, the nation's largest Pentecostal denomination, for sexual misconduct.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Liver Transplant Recipient's Condition Unchanged, Hospital Says
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first and longest surviving heart-liver transplant patient, rested comfortably Saturday as she continued her recovery from a second liver transplant. Stormie, 12, of White Settlement, Texas, remained in critical condition in the intensive care unit of Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said. The girl was placed back on a respirator to relieve breathing problems she experienced Friday after fluid began collecting in her lungs and other parts of her body. ``Doctors are trying to give her body a chance to rid itself of some of the fluids,'' Ms. McMahon said. Physicians also downgraded Stormie's condition to critical, a step down from critical but stable, which is how she was listed after Tuesday's 10-hour transplant and a subsequent nine-hour operation Wednesday to halt internal bleeding. Stormie probably will remain on the respirator for several days, the hospital said. Surgeons were not worried by the development and expect her recovery to proceed normally, Ms. McMahon said. Stormie's first transplant, in 1984 at Children's, was needed to control effects of a rare disease that left her cholesterol levels 10 times greater than normal. The second operation resulted from permanent liver damage caused by hepatitis. Her donor heart has remained healthy, doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands March to Moslem Shrine Demanding Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people chanting ``Freedom! Freedom!'' trekked to a Moslem saint's shrine Saturday to campaign for the secession of Kashmir from India, witnesses and pro-separatist activists said. At least three people died in two separate incidents on Saturday in Kashmir, the center of the four-decade-old separatist campaign, witnesses said. The deaths brought to 109 the number of people killed since Jan. 20 in the latest round of the secessionist violence and the government crackdown. Meanwhile, the president of the Pakistan state of Kashmir said in an interview Saturday that Kashmiris there had begun smuggling arms across the border to Moslem insurgents fighting for independence from India. President Abdul Qayyum, speaking to a reporter who traveled to Pakistan's Kashmir, said the people of his state also had been sheltering insurgents since India launched the military crackdown in its state of Jammu-Kashmir last month. In India's Kashmir, the 600-year-old shrine of Shiekh Nuruddin Wali at Charift Sharief, 20 miles northwest of Srinagar, became a sea of humanity as Moslem men, women and children poured in from Srinagar and nearby towns. Vehicles stopped 10 miles from the shrine as people thronged the roads, said witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Supporters of the militants said they went to the shrine to seek the saint's blessings to ``liberate'' Kashmir from India. In Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, residents were told by Moslem militants to put their clocks back by 30 minutes to correspond with the Pakistan standard time. The militants, led by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, are demanding either independence for Jammu-Kashmir, the only Indian state dominated by Moslems. Groups of young Moslem men sat at street corners, stopping passers-by and telling them to adjust their watches. At least six fights broke out when people refused to comply, said witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity. On Friday, at least 200,000 people marched to the office of the United Nations Military Observers Group in Srinagar, demanding a plebiscite in Kashmir, police said. Witnesses claimed that more than 600,000 people took part. The U.N. group is posted to maintain a cease-fire line drawn between Indian- and Pakistani-held Kashmir after a 1948-49 war over the region. Residents, speaking on condition of anonymity, said security forces fatally shot two men shouting anti-Indian slogans at Khrew, 15 miles southeast of Srinagar. In Srinagar, suspected Moslem militants shot and killed Ashok Kumar, a Hindu government employee, witnesses said, also speaking on condition of anonymity. Kumar was suspected to be a police informer. India routinely accuses Pakistan of arming, training and supporting the militants. The government in Islamabad denies the charge but says the Kashmiri people have a right to self-determination. An AP reporter who traveled to Pakistan's Kashmir last week said state-run banks in the region have begun collections to help the uprising. Signs in dozens of banks called for donations for ``a holy war against India.'' Naveed Hussain, a government spokesman in Pakistan's Kashmir, said in an interview that $5,000 had been raised in a week and that the money would be used to train Kashmiri militia groups in territory held by Pakistan. Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Jack Nicholson, Madonna, Steve Martin, Bill Cosby _ it's not the A-list for a hot Hollywood party, but four of America's top 100 collectors, according to the March issue of Arts & Antiques magazine. ``There are plenty of very rich people buying art who'll never make this list,'' said editor Jeffrey Schaire. ``We seek out those who forge their own ways, who often follow their passions down some very unusual paths.'' Madonna was cited for her collection of modern paintings and photographs. ``I'm attracted to things that are about the sadness of living,'' said the ``Material Girl'' singer. Nicholson likes American and European art and antiquities; his collection includes everything from Monet and Picasso to Mexican primitives and Etruscan bronzes. Cosby specializes in American furniture, paintings and folk art. Martin, a longtime collector of modern American art, recently bought an Edward Hopper lighthouse painting, Arts & Antiques reported. Why is he attracted to paintings? ``A movie lasts an hour and a half,'' the comic actor explained, ``but a painting lasts two minutes or however long you're going to look at it.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Karan cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Ronnie McDowell, whose singing voice is featured in the ABC-TV series ``Elvis,'' has become a father for the fourth time, a spokeswoman said. McDowell's wife, Karan, gave birth Friday night to a 10-pound, 9{-ounce boy named Tyler Dean, spokeswoman Betty Hofer said. Both mother and infant were in good condition at Hendersonville Hospital, she said. The couple also have an 11-year-old son, Ronnie; a 16-year-old daughter, Athena; and a 17-year-old daughter, Kara. Besides impersonating the king of rock 'n' roll, McDowell is known for his country hit records ``The King Is Gone'' and ``Older Women.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after Buster Douglas dethroned boxing champion Mike Tyson, he climbed into a roped-off ring for an experience of an entirely different stripe. Douglas wore the referee stripes Friday at the World Wrestling Federation title bout between Hulk Hogan and Randy ``Macho King'' Savage. His first task was fending off Savage's manager, Sensational Sherri, who despite her sequined frock helped pound on Hogan. The Hulk retained his title, pinning the hot-pink-and-yellow-clad Savage for a quick 1-2-3 count by Douglas. Some of the nearly 19,000 spectators at Joe Louis Arena may not have expected such a short count from Douglas. It was a long count in an eighth-round knockdown that allowed the boxer to go on to knock out the previously unbeaten Tyson in Tokyo two weeks ago. The furious Savage lived up to his name, slapping Douglas, who had climbed into the ring for the end of the match after calling the shots from ringside. Hogan shoved the macho one toward Douglas, and the boxer knocked him cold. Hogan then led Douglas around the ring with an arm outstretched in victory, as adoring fans yelled ``Buster! Buster!'' Douglas won his $100,000 role in the live NBC television show when Tyson canceled after losing his title.

Oscar-winning actor Walter Matthau and comedians John Candy and Rick Moranis have been added to the lineup of presenters for the 62nd annual Academy Awards show. Matthau, who will make his 12th appearance on the show, won best supporting actor for ``The Fortune Cookie'' in 1966 and was nominated as a leading performer for ``Kotch'' in 1971 and ``The Sunshine Boys'' in 1975. Candy, the rotund star of television's long-running ``SCTV Network'' and such films as ``Planes, Trains and Automobiles'' and ``Uncle Buck,'' will be making his second appearance on an Oscar show. Moranis, another ``SCTV'' veteran and co-star of the ``Ghostbusters'' films, will be making his Oscar debut, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said Friday. The Oscars will be awarded March 26.

Jeb Stuart Magruder says what he did as one of President Nixon's aides pales in importance to his current work as a minister. Magruder, who was imprisoned for seven months for perjury and destruction of evidence in the Watergate scandal, discussed his life as a minister last week after performing two funeral services in Marion. He is a pastor at First Community Church in Columbus, about 40 miles south of Marion. ``What I can do for those two families is much more than I ever could have done in the White House,'' he said. ``I can't change things, but I can help people deal with them.'' One funeral was for the 54-year-old wife of a close friend, and the other was for the 28-year-old daughter of a couple who attend First Community. The ministry, he said, ``has changed my life and made it meaningful.''

DOC.HEAD: UMW-Pittston Settlement Leaves Some Miners Perplexed
DOC.TEXT: Steve Powers says he's relieved to be going back to work Monday for Pittston Coal Group, 327 days after 1,695 United Mine Workers struck the company in a contract dispute, but he's also perplexed. Both sides ended up getting basically what they said they really wanted before the strike began: Union members have the job security and health and retirement benefits they sought and the company has its ``operational flexibility.'' Now Powers said the miners are trying to figure out why it took so long to end the fight, which cost the company and the union millions of dollars and caused bitter divisions in coalfield communities. ``It's hard for me to understand,'' the construction worker from Clintwood said after studying the contract and hearing UMW officials compare the terms with the contract that expired in February 1988. Top scale went to $17.52 an hour for selected positions, up $1.20 an hour. Perry Moore said he was equally confused, pointing out the flexible scheduling that Pittston won. ``I can't figure out why we were out 11 months just for that,'' he said. Pittston's UMW workers in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky worked 14 months without a contract before UMW President Richard Trumka called a strike April 5. Pittston had refused to agree to the national contract the UMW negotiated with the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, an industry group. Miners claimed throughout the strike that the motivation behind Pittston's original contract proposal was to eventually set up a non-union operation. Last Monday, the coal miners ratified a settlement that negotiators reached New Year's Eve. The final ratification vote was delayed while the two sides settled legal issues related to the strike. Many miners link the progress on contract talks after months of stalemate with the intervention of Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole and her appointment of former labor secretary William Usery as a federal mediator. Usery said part of his success in bringing the two sides together was his ability to persuade negotiators to set emotions aside and listen to their counterparts. Pittston President Michael Odom agreed. ``Bill Usery brought a new light to the process,'' Odom told reporters after the ratification was announced. UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts said Usery was able to get each side to identify what provisions they truly needed in the contract. ``We all learned some lessons from this,'' Roberts said. ``It's better to talk than to fight.'' Asked to give his advice to future negotiators in labor disputes, Odom said, ``Put yourselves in the other side's shoes. And be innovative.'' Odom bristled when asked if Pittston came out a loser. ``I feel like we were a winner,'' he said. ``We were not trying to eliminate the union. We wanted flexibility.'' The contract allows Pittston to operate for seven rather than five days a week _ UMW members traditionally don't work Sunday _ and put some miners on a weekly schedule of four 10-hour days. Odom said during the bargaining that he couldn't understand why the union was so opposed to the ``flextime,'' which he said will allow Pittston to become more efficient, increase its coal sales and hire more workers. ``It was a good compromise settlement for both sides.'' The contract also includes a new profit sharing plan that gives workers incentive to increase productivity. Mine worker James Gibbs said he hopes the contract will mark the beginning of better labor relations with Pittston. ``Hopefully, that's what the profit sharing is in there for.'' Last summer, the Pittston strike prompted thousands of workers at other mines across the Southeast and Midwest to stage wildcat sympathy walkouts. Violence also erupted sporadically during the strike. Replacement workers and supervisory personnel were often pelted with rocks when they drove to work and verbally abused when they went to town. Now the replacement workers are gone, but the managers and supervisors will be there when the miners return. ``There will be some tensions we will have to deal with,'' Odom said. But Powers said: ``I know I'll be glad to get back to work. I want life to get back to normal.''

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Explodes in Carnival Frenzy
Laserphoto RIO2
DOC.TEXT: Rich and poor put on their dancing shoes Saturday and kicked off Brazil's riotous Carnival, billed as the country's largest and most democratic party. Merrymakers traded clothes for sequin and feather-clad costumes for four days of drinking, dancing and wild sexual abandon. They girated to samba strains in night clubs, ballrooms and on the streets of Rio, the hub of Carnival. Banks, stores and government offices were closed, not to reopen until after noon on Ash Wednesday, Feb. 28, when Carnival officially ends. Nothing, not even Friday's news that inflation reached 73 percent in the first 23 days of February, dampened spirits. In the northeastern coastal cities of Salvador, Recife and Olinda, sunbathers packed beaches and revelers danced along boulevards behind throbbing music trucks heading parade processions. In Rio, temperatures soared into the high 90s, helping bring festival fever to a boil. After fat, jolly King Momo _ Carnival's symbolic sovereign _ received the keys to the city from Mayor Marcelo Alencar in the official opening ceremony at noon Saturday, thousands danced and sang in the downtown financial district. Poorer Brazilians banged out samba rythymns on pots and pans and frolicked in the streets, while the well-heeled donned glittering, beaded costumes and danced until dawn in chandeliered ballrooms. At the Sugar Loaf Ball, the first of the ornate, celebrity studded gala affairs, the throng danced wildly beneath a display of Amazon Indian statues titled, ``Tupi, or not Tupi.'' And at Rio's luxurious Monte Libano nightclub, party goers munched and drank down 1 ton of filet mignon, 650 pounds of shrimp, 210 cases of scotch, and more than 2,000 gallons of draft beer, at $1,250 a ticket. Also on tap was the Grand Gala G, a mecca for homosexuals from around the world. Health authorities, concerned about AIDS, handed out 10,000 condoms and 1.5 million AIDS pamphlets at Rio's dance clubs. Brazil, with 9,555 registered AIDS sufferers through December, has fewer cases only than the United States. About 20,000 police were on duty in Rio's southern beachfront districts to stem a recent violent crime wave. On Saturday, police said the festival was peaceful and reported no major incidents. As always, Rio geared up for the highlight of Carnival _ the ``samba school'' parade, held in two 15-hour sessions on Sunday and Monday. Sixteen ``schools,'' or neighborhood clubs formed in slum areas, will parade as many as 5,000 dancers clad in flashy, feathered costumes and string bikinis down the six-block, outdoor paradeway known as the ``Sambadrome.'' Schools spend a whole year and millions of dollars preparing their parades, composing samba lyrics, choreographing dance steps, and making costumes and floats based on the musical theme. They then compete for a championship prize. Riotur, the city's tourism agency, charges a hefty $170 for the best parade seat for tourists but gives $150 of the fee to each samba school for costumes and floats. Riotur officials expect over 150,000 people will watch the samba school parade.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Airborne Gen. James Gavin Dies at 82
LaserPhoto NY25
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gen. James A. Gavin, who led American paratroops in daring airborne attacks behind German lines in World War II but became a critic of the nation's role in Vietnam, has died. He was 82. Gavin, a highly decorated officer who served twice as ambassador to France under President John F. Kennedy, died Friday in a Baltimore nursing home where he had been confined since January. Private services were set for Wednesday at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in Highland Falls, N.Y., for the ``jumping general'' who also was known for his habit of showing up on front-line patrols with carbine in hand. Gavin jumped with 82nd Airborne Division troops in Sicily and Normandy. As the unit's commander he again jumped at Nijmegen in the ill-fated allied drive to expel the Germans from the Netherlands in September 1944. He wore the two stars of a major general at age 37, one of the youngest men ever to hold that rank. He retired in 1958 and became a critic of U.S. defense policy. He also served as chairman of Arthur D. Little Co., a Cambridge, Mass., management consulting firm. Gavin's military distinction, combined with his dovish views in the late 1960s, brought talk of a dark-horse presidential candidacy. But he declined to run. A native of New York City, Gavin enlisted in the Army in 1924 and won appointment to West Point the following year. He was commissioned a second lieutenant in 1929. He held the Purple Heart, the Silver Star and the Distinguished Service Cross. He also was awarded the Distinguished Service Order by Britain, the Croix de Guerre and the Legion of Honor by France. At the time he retired, Gavin was head of research and development for the Army. He was credited with an instrumental role in developing helicopter-borne forces and tactics for the Army's airborne units. But Gavin also was a maverick within the military establishment. ``I won't compromise my principles and I won't go along with the Pentagon system,'' Gavin said on his retirement. His view that U.S. strategy was too dependant on nuclear weapons was received sympathetically within the Kennedy administration, and President Kennedy named him ambassador to France in 1961-1962 and again in 1962-1963. Within five years, however, he was one of the most prominent Vietnam critics, telling a lecture audience at Brandeis University in 1967 ``We are in a tragedy.'' He urged seeking negotiations ``by every means available.'' Gavin was the author of several books, including ``Airborne Warfare,'' ``War and Peace in the Space Age'' and his memoirs, ``On to Berlin,'' published in 1978. He was married twice and had five daughters.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Treasury Secretary Confers on German Monetary Union
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and his Italian counterpart on Saturday expressed concern that a common currency for East and West Germany could increase world interest rates and slow economic growth, Italian officials said. Brady met Guido Carli for two hours at the Italian Treasury on the second day of his five-day European tour. The talks focused on international economic cooperation and the creation of a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. After the meeting, Carli told reporters the consequences for the world economy of German monetary union received the most attention. West Germany has proposed making the West German mark the currency for East Germany as well to help that country's economic survival. ``We both expressed the conviction that (the level of interest rates) must be in line with the general interest'' and that an increase in interest rates shouldn't ``spill over from Germany to the rest of the world'' because ``that could provoke a slowdown in economic development,'' Carli said. Carli also said the two sides ``recognized the need that the German unification proceed in parallel with an accelerated unification of Europe.'' Brady limited himself to saying the meeting was ``useful and constructive.'' Mario Sarcinelli, director-general at the Italian Treasury, said the greatest worries concern a possible increase in interest rates because of re-emerging ``inflation fears which are shared by many central bankers.'' Sarcinelli said the U.S. economy is currently ``tending to flatten out.'' The key problem, he said, will be to avoid a recession, ``which would be of great consequence for the rest of the world, in particular, for the indebted, developing countries.'' Brady and Carli also addressed the state of the U.S. economy, U.S.-Japanese relations and the ``need to strengthen international collaboration,'' Carli said. Sarcinelli confirmed the finance ministers of the seven most industrialized nations plan to meet this spring. He did not say when the meeting would be. Brady is scheduled to meet with Premier Giulio Andreotti Sunday morning before visiting Paris and London. He met with West German officials on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Prosecutors Used Reagan's Previous Testimony Against Him
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutors used written answers former President Reagan gave more than two years ago to neutralize part of his videotaped testimony last week that could have helped John Poindexter. In his deposition for Poindexter's trial, Reagan initially seemed to suggest that it might have been all right for aides to destroy documents in November 1986 in order to protect the lives of U.S. hostages or Iranian contacts. The former president had to back away from that suggestion, however, when confronted with his earlier statements in the Iran-Contra affair. A portion of the indictment against Poindexter, the former Reagan national security adviser who faces trial March 5 on five felony charges, accuses him of conspiring with White House aide Oliver North to destroy classified documents on the Iran initiative in November 1986. ``Did you ... authorize ... any member of the National Security Council ... to destroy or alter any records ... relating to the Iran or Contra affair?'' Reagan was asked by Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb. Webb clearly expected the former president to say ``no,'' but Reagan didn't answer directly. Instead he emphasized ``the possibility that there were such papers that would violate the secrecy that was protecting ... individuals' lives.'' Renewing complaints about news leaks on Capitol Hill, Reagan said Congress ``was not in many instances capable of the kind of security that we required.'' In response, Webb pulled out a written answer given in the fall of 1987 in which Reagan said that ``At no time did I authorize or approve the destruction or alteration of documents.'' ``Was that a truthful statement?'' Webb asked. ``Yes,'' acknowledged Reagan, abruptly ending that portion of his testimony. Reagan's written responses plus exhibits _ combined in a telephone-book-size document _ were given to a federal grand jury in answer to questions posed by Iran-Contra prosecutors. Only a few of those answers were read into the record at Reagan's deposition in Los Angeles, and the rest remain secret. Reagan was videotaped Feb. 16-17 for Poindexter's trial, and a transcript of his answers was released Thursday. The former president repeatedly gave general answers that appeared to help Poindexter, causing problems for Webb. The prosecutor told U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene in a bench conference midway through the deposition: ``The president has indicated basically there is an atmosphere that he approved and authorized much of what John Poindexter did. And I want to try to bring out as best I can through very specific limited questions that John Poindexter and Oliver North were engaged in a lot of underlying Contra-related and Iran-related activities that he did not know about, did not approve of, did not authorize.'' Webb was only partially successful. Of North's activities on behalf of the Contras, Reagan said: ``I know that he was very active, and that was certainly with my approval. ... I was convinced that they were all being done within the law.'' Asked whether he had given Poindexter authority to send false answers to Congress, Reagan told Webb, ``No. And I don't think any false statements were made.'' Reagan also testified that the Iran initiative wasn't a deal to trade arms for hostages, an assertion that contradicts statements he made in an address to the nation three years ago. ``A few months ago I told the American people I did not trade arms for hostages,'' Reagan said in March 1987. ``My heart and my best intentions still tell me that's true, but the facts and the evidence tell me it is not.'' The Tower Board, which Reagan appointed, concluded that the Iran initiative deteriorated into trading arms for hostages. In his Los Angeles deposition, however, Reagan reverted to the statements he made in November 1986 denying the arms-hostages link. ``The little weekly newspaper in Beirut printed an erroneous story that we were doing business directly with ... Khomeini and trading arms for hostages,'' the former president said in his videotaped testimony. The publication, the magazine Ash-Shiraa, was the first to reveal the initiative. Reagan also testified that the administration wasn't sending munitions to the government of Iran. But Webb drew Reagan's attention to a presidential finding he signed in 1985 which specifically stated that was the case. Poindexter tore up the politically embarrassing finding in November 1986 as lawyers from the Justice Department prepared to launch an inquiry to piece together what really happened in the Iran arms sales. Reagan, who is 79, mischaracterized the Iran initiative, compressing into several months events that took nearly a year and a half to play out. Reagan mentioned one arms shipment to Iran. Earlier investigations have established that there were six. He also contradicted the conclusions of the Tower Board, which found that Israeli officials working with an Iranian, Manucher Ghorbanifar, originated the idea for arms sales to Iran. Reagan testified that a group of Iranian citizens traveled to Israel and that a delegation from the National Security Council met with these citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Princeton Alumni Honor Jimmy Stewart, Admiral Crowe
LaserPhoto TN2
DOC.TEXT: Jimmy Stewart reminisced about Hollywood's past and retired Adm. William Crowe addressed the military's future as fellow alumni honored the two famed Princeton University men Saturday. The Alumni Association gave Stewart its Woodrow Wilson Award for undergraduate alumni distinguished in public service. The James Madison Medal, the graduate student equivalent, was bestowed on Crowe, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Stewart, 81, an Indiana, Pa., native, came to the Ivy League campus more than 60 years ago with an accordian and hopes for an engineering degree. He charmed an audience of 850 with self-deprecating humor and strong opinions about the movie industry today. He remembered his poor mathematics ability that dashed his freshman hopes of being an engineer, saying he switched to architecture on the ``advice of several people, including my math teacher, to stay away from mathematics.'' Summer stock theater after his senior year led to Broadway, which led to an MGM contract. He has appeared in 80 movies. The two-time Oscar winner made it clear he prefers the Hollywood of his early days in the business over today's Hollywood. ``I feel very strongly, looking back, that the big studio system is the only real way to make pictures,'' said Stewart. ``You didn't sit at home waiting for a script you liked. You were there every day. ... Frankly, I think if things were like that today we'd be getting much better movies.'' The studio moguls of the day, Stewart said, ``loved motion pictures. They didn't need censors. They knew what was right for the public. They hated sequels. You know, they make one today and you get six more.'' He told an anecdote about a man who approached him on a movie set and told him: ```Yeah, yeah, I saw you in a picture. ... You were in this room. There was a girl there. ... I don't know who the girl was. You sort of went toward the door, and as the guy went to the girl, I forget what he said, but he said something to you. You turned and looked at him, and I'll never forget that look.''' Stewart told his audience: ``I knew exactly the picture. I knew exactly who was in it. I knew exactly that turn and I knew his reaction to the turn was the reaction I hoped I would get.'' Crowe, who recently retired from the military to teach geopolitics at the University of Oklahoma, received a doctorate from Princeton in 1965. He cautioned against the United States too quickly reducing its military in response to the democracy movement and new governments in Eastern Europe and decreased U.S.-Soviet hostilities. He predicted turmoil until ``the power is sorted out.'' ``We do not know as yet what the final replacement regimes will look like,'' he said. ``I suggest it will be a tough and trying time, if not a dangerous one.''

DOC.HEAD: At Least Seven Killed in Highway Pileups
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with two more crashes, seven reported killed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Fog combined with heavy traffic led to three separate highway pileups Saturday that involved more than 200 cars and killed seven people, police said. Nearly 100 people were reported injured. The worst crash involved 134 cars on the main highway between Frankfurt and Munich. Six people died and 72 were injured, 43 of them seriously, police said. ``There are wrecked cars all over the place. The injured are bleeding and screaming. It looks like a slaughterhouse,'' said a police officer. Another person died when 74 cars crashed into each other on the Frankfurt-Berlin highway, police said. Seven people were critically injured, and 15 others suffered less serious injuries in that accident. The third pileup, with 16 cars and five injuries, occurred on another highway near Frankfurt, police reported. One of the five suffered serious injuries. Police said all three pileups were caused by fast driving in foggy conditions. There are usually no speed limits on West German autobahns. Traffic was particularly heavy Saturday morning because of a short holiday marking the carnival season. ``The visibility was poor, but as usual drivers did not adjust their speed to the conditions and drove too fast,'' said one officer at the scene of the worst crash, on a stretch of the A3 autobahn between Aschaffenburg and Wuerzburg. Police had to close the heavily traveled autobahn in both directions, causing traffic jams of nearly 30 miles. Rescue vehicles had trouble reaching the area because of the crowded highway, police said. The pileup on the Frankfurt-Berlin highway also forced police to block traffic for a period of six hours. Traffic backed up nearly 10 miles near the border with East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Says New Internal Security Will Resemble FBI
DOC.TEXT: BUCHAREST, Romania _ The internal security operations run for decades with ruthless efficiency by Nicolae Ceausescu's Securitate will be revamped into an organization resembling the FBI, the defense minister said Saturday. In addition, the government plans to maintain the tunnels that Securitate troops used during the December revolution to move freely while battles raged above ground against the army, Defense Minister Victor A. Stanculescu said. The underground labyrinth has become a symbol of the repressive, paranoid control maintained by Ceausescu during his 24-year tenure that ended with his toppling Dec. 22 and execution three days later. The narrow passages reportedly connect major government buildings in Bucharest and lead to communications bunkers or to underground storage depots of food, weapons and ammunition. Stanculescu said the tunnels will be maintained in case they are needed in wartime. Stanculescu said Securitate officers who did not commit atrocities would be given jobs in the Defense Ministry's new Internal Security Agency, which he described as similar in character to the FBI. He said the Securitate, which had been part of the Interior Ministry, was ``neutralized,'' but investigations of its former members were continuing, and ``the process will not be over in a week or two.'' He did not elaborate on the process of transforming Securitate _ whose repressive secret police methods had been unmatched in Europe since the Stalinist 1950s _ into a force resembling the FBI, a branch of the U.S. Justice Department charged with investigating such federal crimes as espionage, bank robbery, kidnapping and fraud. Through the Securitate, the Communist government controlled nearly every aspect of Romanian life; it widely recruited informers, discouraged contact with foreigners and even demanded that typewriters be registered. The scarcity of information about the restructuring of Securitate has led to widespread fears that the dreaded force is still in action, despite repeated government denials. Last week, the Romanian Defense Ministry said more than 3,500 Securitate agents had been retired. The force had about 15,000 officers and thousands of civilian informers, according to officials of the interim government. The ministry has said some agents were arrested, but it has not given a number, and only a handful have been convicted. Stanculescu, a lieutenant general, also told reporters he had agreed to work with officers who demanded a purge in the army of elements associated with Ceausescu. ``We established together a plan and a schedule and a system of resolving these problems through teams,'' he said, declining to elaborate. Dozens of officers who played a leading role in the December revolution that ousted Ceasuescu and ended more than four decades of Communist rule held a week of demonstrations earlier this month that prompted the removal of the previous defense minister. The protests posed the first major challenge to the interim government ruling Romania until free elections in May. Stanculescu on Friday met with representatives of the military units. In another development, state radio reported that 35 people were convicted of breaking into government headquarters during a demonstration last week. Of them, 23 received prison sentences of three to six months, and six were fined between $140 to $350. Six others were under age 18 and will be sent to reform school, the broadcast said.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Find No Evidence of Child Abuse Despite Nude Photos
DOC.TEXT: Police say they found no evidence to support a child-abuse case against a day-care center owner who kept nude pictures of some of the childen placed in his care. In the four weeks since John Shaver's arrest on child pornography charges, counselors and investigators interviewed former employees and 20 children from his Rainbow Learning Center, police said Friday. ``What we have is not even close to substantiating a criminal charge,'' said police Capt. Bruce Smith. ``All we have are comments from some children that might be interpreted as inappropriate touching by Mr. Shaver.'' He did not elaborate on what children told the counselors. On Thursday, prosecutors backed away from a report that three of the children had gonorrhea of the throat. The state attorney's office said the three originally tested positive for gonorrhea but had come up negative on a second test. Tests of Shaver found no trace of the disease. Shaver was charged with 29 counts of possessing published pornographic material depicting children. Police acting on a tip from a photo lab also found nude snapshots of childen in his home, but he does not face any charges in relation to those photos. The children in the pictures, including 20 identified by parents as children who attended the day care center, were not depicted in sexual situations. ``The police investigation vindicates my client,'' said Shaver's attorney J. David Bogenshutz. Shaver, who opened Rainbow Learning Center in 1985, had his day-care license revoked. He previously had been forced to close a day-care center in Hawaii following accusations that he improperly touched children there, but he was never charged in that case.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Love R. Divine hated her name when she was in elementary school. But by high school, she had learned that ``Love'' is indeed divine. Ms. Divine, 26, a manager at a grocery store, is named for her great-grandmother, a Cherokee Indian whose tribal name was Love. The ``R'' stands for Renee. ``When I was in grade school, I hated it because the other kids made fun of it,'' she said. ``I cried every day. I was mad at my mom.'' By the time she was in eighth grade, she felt better about it. ``My friends would say, `Oooh, your name is `Love.' And in high school it gave me a lot of attention,'' she said. But she still gets plenty of funny looks and comments. Once, she got stopped by a state trooper, who looked at her identification and asked: ``Is this your real ID? Are you sure?'' He went back to his car and talked on the two-way radio, probably trying to find out if she was genuine, she recalled. ``I still got a ticket, though,'' she added. Checking into a hotel or writing a check can produce some interesting reactions, she said. ``They always ask for more identification,'' she said. ``Once I got asked if I was a porn star. I have to do a lot of explaining.''

You can lead a gorilla to grass, but can you make him sit? That is the question Dallas Zoo officials are trying to resolve. The zoo's four gorillas are scheduled to be moved to a new outdoor enclosure in April. Zoo director Warren Iliff says that may not set well with a few of the large beasts who are now living behind bars in an indoor facility. ``Gorillas are conservative,'' Iliff said. ``They will need time to adapt to the change.'' Iliff said a large male named Om Bom is particularly leery of change. ``He may not even be willing to walk on the grass,'' Iliff said. Zoo staff members are trying to help the gorillas get used to sitting on grass by bringing grass, hay and the like into their cages, so they will be willing to make the move when the new Wilds of Africa primate habitat is completed. Earlier, zoo officials attempted to ensure the new gorilla habitat will be escape-proof by bringing in mountain climbers to detect unforeseen escape routes.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Nicaragua:

THE LAND _ Nicaragua is the biggest, but least populated, country in Central American. It has 57,000 square miles, about the size of Iowa. The most fertile parts of the country are the hills and lowlands near the Pacific Coast. Farming and ranching run through the central mountains. On the east, or Caribbean side, are the hot, wet jungles and mangroves of the Miskito Coast. No road connects the two coasts. Nicaragua has more than 50 volcanos and two large lakes, one of which contains the world's only fresh-water sharks. Honduras borders Nicaragua to the north and Costa Rica to the south.

THE PEOPLE _ The population is 3.5 million. About 90 percent of Nicaraguans live in the western half of the country close to the Pacific Coast. Managua, the capital, has a population of 850,000. About half the population is 15 years or younger. Spanish is the official language. But English and native Indian languages, mostly Miskito, are spoken by ethnic minorities along the sparsely populated Atlantic Coast.

THE ECONOMY _ Nicaragua is mainly an agricultural country, deriving most of its income from exports of coffee, cotton, sesame and beef. But exports have declined sharply since 1979, when the Sandinistas seized power. They were $200 million last year, down from $700 million in 1978. Inflation for 1989 was 1,700 percent, according to the government, a figure that many experts think is low. In 1988 the cost of living rose 33,600 percent. Nicaragua's economy is among the poorest in the world; in some respects, even poorer than that of Haiti, long considered the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.

HISTORY _ Spanish ``conquistadores'' colonized Nicaragua in the 1600s. Independence was achieved in 1821. Relations with the United States have long been sour. In the 1850s, American adventurer William Walker invaded the country several times, once declaring himself president for two years. Several U.S. interventions and military invasions marked the start of the 1900s, and Augusto Cesar Sandino made himself a revolutionary hero fighting U.S. Marines stationed in Nicaragua. In 1934 Sandino was killed and the United States installed the Somoza dynasty of rightists, who ruled for 42 years. The last of them, Anastasio Somoza, was overthrown July 19, 1979, by a popular uprising led by the Sandinista National Liberation Front, which has governed Nicaragua ever since.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua under the Sandinista government has taken a pivotal role in Central America, by turns scaring and angering its neighbors. Here is a brief glance at its regional relations:

HONDURAS _ Nicaragua has accused Honduras of selling its national sovereignty to the United States in exchange for financial aid. U.S. military troops conduct joint exercises with Honduran troops to keep Nicaragua's armed forces _ the largest in the region, with an estimated 150,000 troops _ in check. Nicaragua sued Honduras in the World Court for allowing the U.S.-backed Contra rebels to have bases there, from which they infiltrate Nicaragua.

EL SALVADOR _ Managua denies arming the Salvadoran guerrillas, but it is known that the rebels have a safe haven in Nicaragua. Last November, a small plane loaded with missiles crashed in El Salvador, which pulled its diplomats from Managua in protest.

COSTA RICA _ Nicaragua's once-strained relations with Costa Rica have improved since President Oscar Arias cut down the Contra presence on Nicaragua's southern flank and began efforts to promote regional peace. However, the pro-Sandinista press in Managua regularly accuses the Costa Rican ambassador of inciting unrest and illegally aiding the opposition.
GUATEMALA _ Nicaragua's Sandinistas do not like Guatemala's government. The Sandinistas say it is basically run by a rightist military that tolerates death squad activity.

PANAMA _ The Sandinistas were hurt by the fall of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. He allowed the Sandinistas to circumvent a U.S. trade and economic embargo, re-invoicing and in many cases re-labeling imports and exports in Panama's huge free-trade zones at both ends of the canal. Panama's new government led by President Guillermo Endara has not continued the practice.

CUBA _ Although it is not part of the region, Fidel Castro's Cuba has until recently been a strong influencing factor in Central America. But economic problems and diminished Soviet aid have cut Castro's ability to affect events. Castro's waning influence may be the principal factor pushing the Sandinistas toward economic and political moderation.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Nicaragua's Election Sunday:

THE VOTERS _ There are 1,750,550 people registered to vote Sunday. Turnout is expected to be high. The voting age is 16, lowered from 18 by the Sandinistas who expect to harvest votes from youthful supporters. About one-third of registered voters are between 16 and 25, and about 51.5 percent are women. More than 26 percent of all registered voters live in Managua.

VOTING _ The 4,394 polling places nationwide open at 7 a.m. (8 a.m. EST) and close at 6 p.m. (7 p.m. EST) when anybody still standing in line gets to vote. Voters must present their electoral registration card or a document that is provided to replace lost, damaged or stolen cards. The cards do not have a picture of the bearer. Each voter is handed three ballots _ one to choose a president and vice president; another to choose each party's slate of National Assembly deputy candidates; and a third to choose municipal councils. In autonomous Atlantic Coast regions, voters choose regional councils instead of municipal councils. Voters enter a stall where they have two minutes to mark the three ballots, putting an X under the party of their choice. They leave the stall and deposit each ballot in its corresponding sealed box. To prevent voting more than once, voters must dip their thumbs in a special ink that takes days to wash off.

THE COUNT _ After polls close, the ballots are counted by a three-member commission at each polling station. The count will take place under the observation of party-appointed observers as well as accredited international observers, if they are present. The results are telegraphed to each of nine regional centers, which transmit the results as they come in to the Supreme Electoral Council in Managua. The ballots are then taken to each regional center, where they are counted again. In isolated rural areas this may take days, with ballots being transported on horseback or by boat on jungle rivers.

THE RESULTS _ The Supreme Electoral Council is expected to begin announcing results at about 9 p.m. (10 p.m.EST) and will continue through the night with periodic announcements. Significant results may not be available until Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Man Teaches Students the Art of Horseshoeing
DOC.TEXT: Sparks fly while Reggie Kester hammers a length of red-hot iron just out of the forge, and gradually the metal takes the shape of a horseshoe. Kester works in much the same way as craftsmen have for hundreds of years, using forge, anvil and hammer. His rough hands speak of the 30-odd years he has spent in the trade. But this isn't the village smithy. Kester and his wife, Marcella, run the Oklahoma State Horseshoeing School, where they teach the craft of the farrier, not blacksmithing. People hoping to enter what can be a lucrative trade come to the school from around the world. ``I know guys that are making $150,000 shoeing horses,'' Kester says. But he admits most make between $20,000 and $40,000 a year. They've have had students from Germany, Sweden, Australia, Canada, Ireland, Israel and Switzerland. The six-week course costs $2,450 and is offered six times a year. Kester credits trade advertising and word-of-mouth for the school's wide appeal. All kinds sign up for the Kesters' courses. ``Most of the people we have are people who have experience with horses,'' Kester says. But he adds: ``We have people come through here who know nothing about horses except what they look like.'' Kester says that after his course, they'll all be able to shoe a horse and make a horseshoe from scratch. ``Sometimes you just can't buy what you need,'' Kester says. ``So you make it.'' He says he learned the trade of a farrier as he teaches it: in school. ``I'm a journeyman, certified horseshoer,'' he said. ``I've had a lot of experience, and I've been in the teaching business for 15, 16 years. ``I went to school for it in '66. I thought I knew something until I went to school and met people who did.'' Kester says there's a lot to being a farrier, and it takes instruction and practice. He says an unskilled person who shoes a horse runs the risk of crippling the animal. His students don't spend all their time at the anvil. He's got a textbook, a thick volume called ``The Principles of Horseshoeing II,'' which contains information about anatomy, metallurgy and history. Kester says there are many types of horseshoes for different kinds of animals. There are lightweight, aluminum shoes for race horses; large, heavy shoes for work animals; and even plastic shoes for injured horses. Most horseshoes today are still metal and are nailed to a horse's hoof. But synthetic and plastic shoes that are glued to the hoof are beginning to take over. ``I think in 10 or 20 years the standard horseshoe we've known for hundreds of years'll be obsolete,'' Kester says. As long as there are horses, there will be a need for people to shoe them, but Kester says the farrier's business requires individuals to go out and find clients. ``You don't go get a job'' just out of school, he says. ``You go get a clientele. It's an entrepreneurial deal.'' Clients vary. Racetracks are specialized and many require union certification, he says, and working on show horses requires a high level of skill. Horses with injured hoofs need a special kind of care. In some ways, Kester says, he's an equine podiatrist. But he's not a blacksmith. ``I call myself a horseshoer ... and that's what I am.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Returns to Prison To Get AIDS Drug
DOC.TEXT: A man infected with the AIDS virus stole a videocassette recorder so he could return to prison and receive free daily doses of an expensive medicine that may prolong his life. ``I want to live; that's why I'm back,'' said the man housed in an AIDS isolation cellblock at Limestone Correctional Facility. The American Civil Liberties Union, which represents the man, has not disclosed his name. Other prisoners call the 35-year-old man ``Batman.'' He is one of 140 prisoners at Limestone who have tested positive for exposure to the human immunodeficiency virus and can get the drug AZT at state expense. Caring for inmates with AIDS or HIV infections is estimated to cost $20,000 a month, said Jay Stuman, executive vice president of Correctional Health Care Inc., which provides medical services to the state prison system. Don Williamson, director of the state Health Department's Disease Control and Rehabilitation Services, estimated $7 million a year is needed to provide AZT to Alabamians infected with the AIDS virus but lacking health insurance. AZT was the first drug approved by the federal government to lessen the devastating effects of AIDS on the body's immune system. The cost of the drug to individuals had varied as prices and dosage recommendations both have been cut, but it can exceed $5,000 a year. Three years ago, while imprisoned for burglary and theft, Batman was tested with 12,000 other state inmates and found to be infected with HIV. Seven months after his release in April, he pleaded guilty to stealing the VCR. Police officer William McCormick of Anniston said Batman had enough experience with petty crimes to have stolen the VCR without getting caught, so ``it was obvious he was trying to get back in prison.'' A federal judge last month upheld the state's right to segregate its inmates with the AIDS virus in a special unit at Limestone. The ACLU, representing the segregated inmates, is appealing the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed as Gunmen Spray Washington Bar
DOC.TEXT: Four patrons were killed and two others wounded early Saturday when a pair of gunmen opened fire in a Washington tavern. Police identified one victim as Robert Lee Walker, 24, and said he was pronounced dead on arrival at Howard University Hospital Names of three others pronounced dead at the scene were not learned immediately. The gunmen, apparently hunting for Walker, entered the tavern around 1:30 a.m., police said. They said the other victims were fatally wounded when the assailants sprayed the room before fleeing. The tavern, John's Place, is located in Northwest Washington about a mile and a half from the White House. Listed in serious but stable condition were Robert F. Bently, 25, of Oxon Hill, Md., and Michael L. Anderson, 25, of Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Rule Out NATO Membership for Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Foreign Ministry's policy-making body Saturday ruled out NATO membership for a unified Germany, saying that would tip the balance of European power. The statement from the ministry's Collegium was issued as West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl met with President Bush in the United States to discuss the future of Germany. Both men favor NATO membership for a reunited Germany. At present, West Germany is a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and East Germany belongs to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The Foreign Ministry Collegium, in its statement carried by the official Tass news agency, rejected the argument that membership of a united Germany in the Western military alliance would satisfy Soviet security concerns because it would place Germany ``under some kind of external control.'' Membership in NATO for a reunified Germany would lead to an ``impermissible violation of the military-strategic balance,'' the Collegium said. Soviet officials have previously said a reunified Germany should not belong to NATO. ``The Soviet Union on this account has its own conceptions,'' said the Collegium, which held a meeting on the German question Saturday. ``And these conceptions, of course, don't include at all the proposals that foresee the membership of a united Germany in NATO.'' In remarks on Germany's future printed Wednesday by the Communist Party daily Pravda, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said any disruption of the existing military-strategic balance is unacceptable. East Germany is Moscow's most important military ally and home to about two-thirds of its 575,000 troops deployed in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Microbiologist Who Developed Anti-Pollution Gene
DOC.TEXT: Research microbiologist Stephen Cuskey, who developed so-called suicide genes that self-destruct after making toxic wastes decompose, has died of a pancreatic infection. He was 36. Cuskey, who worked at the Environmental Protection Agency Research Laboratory at Pensacola Beach, died Thursday at Baptist Hospital. A pioneer in genetic engineering, he joined the federal agency in July 1985. The Pensacola Beach laboratory specializes in the study of toxins and gene splicing and supervised the use of fertilizer to speed the growth of oil-eating bacteria to help clean up the Alaskan oil spill last year. Cuskey was a born ``gene jockey'' who loved splicing genes, Hap Pritchard, the lab's chief of biotechnology, said Friday. He added that his colleague's genetic tinkering was done with a concern for the environment. The scientist had fought a lifelong battle with asthma and high blood pressure before the fatal pancreatic infection, Pritchard said. Cuskey received a bachelor's degree in biology from Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa., and did postgraduate work at Virginia Commonwealth University and the University of Michigan before earning his doctorate from Rutgers University in New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Search Resumed for Last Body of Seven Victims in Icy Lake Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: The search resumed Saturday for the body of a man who was among seven people who fell through ice and drowned in a lake in the Sierra Nevada range last week, authorities said. A video camera was lowered into Convict Lake but after two hours nothing but clothing was spotted, the Mono County Sheriff's Department reported. The body of Dave ``Grandpa'' Meyers was spotted by the camera on Wednesday but divers were unable to recover it. Meyers, 53, was a counselor at Camp O'Neal who died Monday with three teen-age boys from the camp, another counselor and two rescuers. Divers recovered the other six bodies earlier in the week. Camp O'Neal is a home for youngsters placed by county social service agencies as well as youths classified as delinquent who have committed minor crimes and are under the jurisdiction of probation departments. The tragedy occurred during an outing for 16 boys from the camp, which is near the eastern Sierra lake 250 miles north of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Counterfeit Audio Tapes Seized, Six Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of bootleg audio tapes, high-capacity copying equipment and $89,000 in cash were found at two homes after a mysterious 911 phone call from one residence, authorities said Saturday. Six men identified as Mexican nationals were arrested. The operation had the capacity to make 15,000 to 20,000 tapes a day, which could cost the record industry millions of dollars, said Deputy Pat Hunter, a sheriff's spokesman. The discovery began with a call to the 911 emergency line that was automatically traced when the caller hung up without saying anything. Sheriff's deputies sent to investigate the call Friday found thousands of tapes. They also found evidence that led them to more tapes in the garage and to $89,000 in $100 bills stashed in a cookie jar in an attic of a house several miles away, said Deputy Rafael Estrada. Pico Rivera is 10 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Kenya's Slain Foreign Minister Buried
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 3rd graf to correct spelling of Ouko. Pickup 4th, `Saturday's funeral...
DOC.TEXT: The slain foreign minister was buried Saturday on his family farm in western Kenya, and his widow appealed for calm as hundreds of police and protesting students faced one another during the ceremony. ``If you love him as you say you do, I beg you with tears in my eyes and as his widow to let us give him a peaceful send-off,'' said Cristobel Ouko. Robert Ouko's funeral Friday touched off major protests in Nairobi and Kisumu, where the body was taken for public display after a memorial service. It was the worst violence in Kenya since a 1982 coup attempt as students demonstrated to demand an explanation of Ouko's murder last week. Saturday's funeral ended without major incident. Mrs. Ouko addressed mourners shortly before President Daniel arap Moi spoke. None of the long line of speakers at the burial was interrupted by the students. Between 500 and 600 students from four colleges arrived at the farm aboard eight buses shortly before dawn. For the next six hours, they paraded up and down Ouko's driveway chanting: ``We want justice!'' ``No cover-up!'' ``Who killed Bob?'' ``Moi should resign!'' Police halted the parading students at noon, when the president, ministers, diplomats and local politicians began arriving for the burial service. At the gravesite, a few yards down a sloping yard from Ouko's hilltop home, Moi was surrounded by some 200 police, their rifles pointing out toward the crowd. Some students managed to get close to the grave and continued muttering their chants. Moi occasionally glanced at them but showed no reaction. In his speech, Moi again promised the government would conduct a thorough investigation into the death of Ouko, whose charred body was found in the brush near his home on Feb. 16. He had been shot once in the head. ``I want the truth about the murder,'' Moi said. Ouko, 58, was the fourth leading political figure to die violently since Kenya gained independence in 1963. The government of former President Jomo Kenyatta was accused of covering up the three other murders. Ouko also was the highest-ranking politician from the Luo tribe, one of four major ethnic groups that vie for power in Kenya's single-party government and engage in rivalries that go back centuries. The others are the Kikuyu, the Luya and the Kalengen. University students in Nairobi began demonstrating early in the week, demanding an impartial investigation of Ouko's death. The government has called in three Scotland Yard detectives and a British pathologist to assist in the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas, Opponents Will Have To Learn How To Compromise
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Sandinista Front will remain the largest political party in Nicaragua even in the unlikely event President Daniel Ortega loses Sunday's election, but there still may be room for minor parties to wield some power in the National Assembly. After the Sandinistas, the Social Christians are expected to be the second-largest single party in the new National Assembly. The United National Opposition, which is mounting the strongest challenge to the Sandinistas behind presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is a fractious coalition of 14 parties that may not survive defeat _ or even victory. Voters will choose 90 deputies on Sunday, and losing presidential candidates get additional seats if their vote total reaches about 1 percent. The formula for calculating the exact vote total needed to qualify for a seat is complicated but will end up at about 15,000 votes, which all eight minor opposition candidates may get. That would result in a 99-member legislature. The 11 UNO parties running candidates for assembly seats will act individually once it is no longer in their interest to be hedged in by coalition decisions. None of the 11 is likely to have more than a few seats, and the Social Christians hope to be second with seven or eight seats. They may also pick up support from one of the UNO parties, the People's Social Christian Party. The Sandinistas would be a cohesive bloc becasue of strong party discipline, but if they lack a majority the Social Christians would become crucial players. A two-thirds majority is needed for constitutional changes of any kind. On the municipal level and in the two regional councils for the Atlantic Coast, the only certain thing is that the Sandinistas will no longer monopolize power. It is almost certain that Yatama, the native Indian organization, will dominate the Atlantic Coast regions, an area different from the Pacific Coast in language, ethnic background and customs. The Indians and English-speaking blacks of the Atlanic side are so fiercely independent that the Sandinista government was forced to accede to their demands for autonomy. Some councils in the 144 cities and towns nationwide will most certainly be in opposition hands, especially in the central mountains where the U.S.-backed Contras _ and UNO _ are strong. Although they have local government responsibilities, their power may be limited by the centralized nature of Nicaragua's government. The councils will have to depend on Managua for money, because they collect no local taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Leaders Call For Unity In Face Of Worldwide Changes
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of a four-nation Arab council Saturday urged Arab unity to cope with changes sweeping the world, and Iraq's president urged Arabs to shift their wealth from the United States to Eastern Europe. ``Just as Israel uses interest groups to apply pressure on the American administration, there are hundreds of billions of dollars invested by Arabs in the United States and the West which could be used for this purpose,'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said. ``In fact, this investment could be converted to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, and I believe it is a profitable investment, probably more profitable than in the West.'' Saddam's statement came at the opening of the first anniversary summit of the Arab Cooperation Council, an alliance of Iraq, Egypt, Jordan and North Yemen. Leaders of the nations held private talks on Friday and closed their summit Saturday night by signing 11 agreements on economic and administrative cooperation. Jordanian Foreign Minister Marwan Kassem said they also called for ``withdrawal of all non-Lebanese troops from Lebanese soil,'' a reference to Syrian and Israeli forces in the strife-torn country. Iraq is a bitter foe of Iran and Syria. The latter has some 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate, while Israel and the militias it funds occupy southern Lebanon as a self-declared ``security zone.'' Kassem spoke at a news conference following the summit's closing session. The chief political adviser to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Osama El-Baz, told The Associated Press that the four nations had also agreed to contact world leaders in a campaign to halt Jewish settlement in Arab territories captured by Israel in 1967. Kassem, however, said that would happen only after a meeting of Arab League foreign ministers in mid-March. Arabs have expressed alarm that tens of thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel could settle in the occupied territories. El-Baz said such settlement would be ``a threat to the security of the Arab nation and to the peace process itself.'' In other resolutions, the leaders supported the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories, backed Iraq in its disputes with Iran, called for peace in Lebanon and praised the release from prison of South African black leader Nelson Mandela. In their speeches, the leaders urged Arabs to overcome differences to cope with the democratic changes that are redrawing the map of Europe. ``The world will not deal with us positively unless this unity is achieved,'' Jordan's King Hussein said in his closing statement. The king said earlier Saturday that ``a new world order is emerging'' based on economic and political blocs rather than on hegemony and the arms race. He said Arabs can either ``be part of the historic developments and employ them to enhance their existence, stability and growth, or ... be on the periphery ... and so become an easy prey that is mercilessly leeched and discarded.'' While Saddam called for Arabs to use their financial muscle to influence the United States, none of the ACC countries has much of it. Egypt and Jordan are both coping with economic crises. Iraq has the world's second-largest known reserves of oil, but it is financially drained by its long war with Iran. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other Gulf states hold the bulk of Arab investment wealth. Saddam said Arabs must deal with the United States, ``but America has to respect Arabs and their rights and not interfere in their internal problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 41 People In Abortion Protest
DOC.TEXT: Forty-one anti-abortion protesters were arrested Saturday after blocking a clinic entrance, police said. Clinic workers broke a window to circumvent the demonstrators and get into the building, police said. All were charged with defiant trespassing and were being released on their own recognizance, said Deputy Chief James Galfy. One person was charged with assault on a police officer for trying to bite him, Galfy said. About 60 protesters from the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue sat in front of the doors of the North Jersey Gynecological Center while about 20 more picketed. Abortions are performed at the clinic. Police carried protesters to two school buses when they refused to leave the clinic, Galfy said. Five protesters locked themselves to each other and to the entrance doors, he said. Clinic administrator Anne Crayfield said she had a window broken so she and other employees could climb into the building. Once they got in, the protesters handed over the keys to the locks they used to chain themselves, she said. ``We just hated to have them have their way, so we hung in there,'' Ms. Crayfield said. ``Some of the patients came from a distance and some people couldn't wait another week.'' Ginny Christel of Operation Rescue said that the protesters remained silent throughout the ordeal to ``identify with preborn babies who have no choice.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bonn Renounces Claims to Poland
DOC.TEXT: The West German government has assured the Bush administration that a reunified Germany will renounce any claim to Polish land, a newspaper said Saturday. The report came as West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl met with President Bush at Camp David, Md., for weekend talks, mainly involving unification. Poland wants a clear renunciation from the Bonn government that a reunified Germany would not seek to take control of German territory that was given to Poland at the end of World War II. The West German newspaper Bild am Sonntag said Saturday that Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has told U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III a reunified Germany would respect the current border with Poland. The assurances were reportedly given during a visit to Washington earlier in the week. Bild am Sonntag said such a declaration could be issued as soon as the East German government votes to join with West Germany, and Schaeuble predicted that step would come shortly after East Germany's free elections, set for March 18. ``There will be an absolute and unmistakable clarification regarding the Polish border,'' Bild am Sonntag quoted Schaeuble as telling the Americans.
