Bild am Sonntag said its information came from a confidential telex that Schaeuble had sent back to the Foreign Ministry in Bonn. The newspaper, which has good contacts within the government in Bonn, said its report would appear in Sunday's editions. A copy was distributed in advance to other news media. It was not clear whether the latest reported West German assurance would satisfy Poland and other jittery nations of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Kohl has refused to categorically renounce any claim to the Polish territory. However, on the eve of Kohl's U.S. trip, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany gave an interview urging a clear West German recognition of Poland's western border. German conservatives, whose votes Kohl hopes to gain in December elections, have pushed claims for about a third of modern-day Poland that was sliced off Germany by the victorious Allies after World War II. In another news report, the West German news magazine Der Spiegel reported that former Communist Party leader Erich Honecker placed money paid by West Germany for the release of political prisoners into a private bank account. According to Der Spiegel, the amount was $48 million last year alone. The prisoners were mostly people convicted of trying to escape from the country under the former hard-line regime. Prosecutors have already said they intend to indict the 77-year-old Honecker next month for treason and corruption. He was ousted following pro-democracy demonstrations in October.

DOC.HEAD: Arctic Cold Invading the Central and Eastern U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A sharp cold front ushered arctic air into the north-central and northeastern sections of the nation Saturday and snow fell over much of the area from the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes region to New England. One storm off the Atlantic Coast produced snow in New England, strong northerly wind produced squalls with heavy snow over the upper Great Lakes, and a low-pressure system centered over southeastern Lower Michigan produced snow from the Ohio Valley into the middle Atlantic Coast region. The storm off the Atlantic Coast dumped 6 inches of snow in Vermont at Brattleboro and Shaftsbury. Portland, Maine, got 5 inches of snow in six hours early Saturday. Winter storm watches were in effect through Sunday for Vermont, eastern New York state, New Hampshire, southern Maine and all of southern New England. The squalls over the Great Lakes produced heavy snow across parts of Upper Michigan, with up to 12 inches at Ironwood and Wakefield, and 10 inches at Marquette, the National Weather Service said. Wind and snow produced blizzard conditions along the Lake Superior shoreline of Upper Michigan. The low pressure system centered over southeastern Michigan produced heavy snow across parts of the Ohio Valley, the lower Great Lakes and the central Appalachians, with a foot in northern Indiana. Strong northwesterly wind ushered arctic air into the central and eastern part of the nation. Wind gusted to 54 mph at Peru, Ind., during the morning, the weat her service said, with gusts to 50 mph around St. Louis, Mo. Temperatures remained below freezing during the afternoon from the northern Plains to the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley, and across the northern Atlantic Coast region. Skies were partly cloudy over the Rockies and Pacific Northwest on Saturday, while most of the rest of the nation had clear skies. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 12 below zero at Warroad, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Poised to License Seabrook Nuclear Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-14, `As an example...evacuation plans,' to CLARIFY Nuclear Regulatory Commission decision. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `That decision...
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook nuclear power plant is on the verge of obtaining an operating license after years of demonstrations, regulatory delays and financial problems that forced its lead owner into bankruptcy. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said last week that it would rule Thursday on a license for the $6.4 billion plant, which became a symbol for opponents of nuclear power in the 1970s. Protests began before ground-breaking in August 1976, when 18 people were arrested at the site. Subsequent protests have resulted in about 3,200 arrests, including 1,400 in a May 1977 demonstration. The last major demonstration was in October, when 475 people were arrested. If the NRC gives its approval, as expected, spokesman John Kopeck said there would be about a week of paperwork before the commission issued the actual license. If promised court appeals don't succeed, Seabrook would go through a three-month buildup to full-power operation. The main sticking point to licensing has been federally required evacuation plans for communities, including six over the border in northeastern Massachusetts, within 10 miles of the plant. Critics argue that the area surrounding the plant, two miles from popular Hampton Beach and 40 miles north of Boston, is too densely populated to be evacuated safely in an emergency. The 10-mile area has a population of 148,000, which swells to a summertime peak of 247,000, according to estimates by Seabrook officials. Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis refused to submit evacuation plans to the NRC, so New Hampshire Yankee, the operating company set up by the dozen utilities that own Seabrook, submitted its own plans for Massachusetts. New Hampshire submitted its evacuation plans long ago, when staunch Seabrook supporter John Sununu, now White House chief of staff, was governor. Critics cite near-gridlock on coastal roads on hot summer weekends as proof the plans wouldn't work. ``I think they're a fraud,'' said Robert Backus, lawyer for the Seacoast Anti-Pollution League. ``I live 40 miles away and I don't feel safe.'' ``This process is a sham. Whenever (the NRC) runs into a rule it can't meet, it changes the rule,'' said Backus, who has opposed the project for years, although he was initially neutral. As an example, he objected to the NRC's changing its rules to reduce standards for utility-drafted evacuation plans after Massachusetts refused to submit its own plans. Seabrook spokesman Rob Williams called that 1987 change a clarification of NRC policy for reviewing such plans. Last fall, the NRC further irked plant opponents by abruptly taking control of critical Seabrook licensing issues after two lower-level NRC panels issued conflicting findings about the evacuation plans. That decision prompted a congressional investigation of NRC procedures that is still in progress. ``Quite apart from the merits of Seabrook, for the NRC to muzzle an appeals board is a brutal and naked power grab, the height of arrogance,'' Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said at the time. Plant officials claim the regulatory process has been stacked against them. ``Seabrook has been through a more stringent regulatory process than any nuclear plant ever licensed,'' Seabrook's top executive, Edward Brown, said in November. ``The people who claim that this is a biased process ignore the fact that it has taken 17 years from the date of the initial license application for Seabrook to get to this point.'' The plant, idle since its completion in 1986 except for low-power testing last year, became an increasing financial burden on its main owner, Public Service Co. of New Hampshire. Barred by state law from charging customers for Seabrook expenses before it generated electricity, Public Service entered bankruptcy reorganization in January 1988. A $2.3 billion takeover of Public Service by Connecticut-based Northeast Utilities, parent company of Connecticut Light & Power, another Seabrook owner, should be completed by July. Public Service first announced plans to build a nuclear plant in 1968, but delayed it for financial reasons. In 1972, the company announced that it planned to build two 1,150-megawatt reactors, the first planned for commercial operation in 1979, the second in 1981. The estimated cost: $973 million. Owners scrapped the second reactor in the mid-'80s, completing the first in July 1986 at a cost of $4.3 billion. Since then, financing and maintenance and other costs have boosted the cost by $50 million a month, bringing the total by Thursday to $6.5 billion. In the meantime, protests against Seabrook continue. The Clamshell Alliance, a group of plant opponents, announced it would hold 24-hour vigils beginning Tuesday at the Statehouse in Concord and at Seabrook.

DOC.HEAD: Important Dates In Decade Of Sandinismo
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of important events in the decade that the Sandinistas have ruled Nicaragua: _ July 19, 1979: The Sandinista National Liberation Front enters Managua, two days after dictator Anastasio Somoza had fled in secret and begins its rule. _ April 1980: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the assassination of whose husband helped bring the Sandinistas to power, quits the governing junta claiming health problems. She would soon start criticizing the Sandinistas. _ November 1980: First attacks by anti-Sandinistas who became known as Contras, short for the Spanish word for counterrevolutionary. _ February 1981: The Reagan administration announces suspension of aid to Nicaragua and accuses the Sandinista Front of aiding leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. _ April 9, 1984: Nicaragua asks the World Court to order the United States to stop helping the Contras. The Reagan administration announces it will not accept the court's jurisdiction. _ Jan. 10, 1985: Daniel Ortega is inaugurated as president following national elections. _ May 1, 1985: Reagan announces a trade embargo against Nicaragua. _ June 27, 1985: The World Court says U.S. support of the Contras violates the U.N. charter's ban on use of force. _ Aug. 13, 1985: The U.S. Senate approves Reagan's request for a military aid package for the Contras. _ Oct. 5, 1986: An American-manned cargo plane is shot down over Nicaragua. Surviving crew member Eugene Hasenfus is captured and implicates the CIA in Contra-supply operations. Hasenfus is subsequently freed. _ Nov. 25, 1986: U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese admits that some of the profits from the sale of American arms to Iran were secretly diverted to the Contras in an operation under U.S. Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North. _ Aug. 7, 1987: Five Central American presidents sign a regional peace plan sponsored by Costa Rican President Oscar Arias. He would subsequently receive the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts. The plan called for amnesties for political prisoners, democratic reforms, an end to foreign aid for irregular forces, and prohibiting one country from allowing its territory to be used by guerrillas to attack another country. _ Feb. 3, 1988: Congress cuts off military aid to the Contras but continues non-lethal aid. _ March 1988: Sandinistas and Contras meet for the first time in face-to-face peace talks in the Nicaraguan border post of Sapoa. _ April 1, 1988: A formal 60-day truce begins. _ May 31, 1988: The Sandinistas decide to extend the cease-fire on a month-to-month basis; the Contras say they consider the truce indefinite. Fighting begins to sink to a low level. _ July 11, 1988: U.S. Ambassador Richard Melton is expelled from Nicaragua along with eight other U.S. diplomats, accused of trying to destabilize the Sandinista government. Washington retaliates by expelling the Nicaraguan ambassador, Carlos Tunnerman, and eight other diplomats. _ September 1988: Contra-Sandinista talks break down, but thousands of Contra guerrilla fighters are moving out of the Nicaraguan hinterland into base camps in Honduras. _ Jan. 30, 1989: Ortega announces a tough austerity program to combat world-record inflation that surpassed 33,600 percent in 1988. _ Feb. 14, 1989: Five Central American presidents sign an accord in El Salvador. Ortega promises early elections in exchange for dismantling the Contras, based in Honduran jungle camps. _ April 28, 1989: President Bush signs a $49 million non-lethal aid package for the Contras. The package runs out Feb. 28. _ Aug. 7, 1989: Five Central American presidents meeting in Tela, Honduras, sign an agreement to dismantle the Contras' bases in Honduras by Dec. 8. They ask help from the United Nations and the Organization of American States. The rebels are not signatories to that pact, which says their demobilization must be ``voluntary.'' The Bush administration wants the Contras to remain intact to guarantee that elections set for Feb. 25, 1990, are free and fair, shortly before their aid package runs out. _ Aug. 26, 1989: Contra Commander Israel Galeano says the rebels will ignore the Tela accord and U.S. advice and starts moving his troops back into Nicaragua. _ Nov. 1, 1989: Ortega announces the lifting of the 19-month-old cease-fire after several attacks and the infiltration of thousands of Contra troops. Fighting surges briefly, but returns to the low level it had reached earlier, after the U.S. cut off lethal aid. _ Nov. 27, 1989: Ortega refuses to deny Nicaragua's role in a shipment of missiles found when a small plane crashes in El Salvador. The United States and El Salvador accuse the Sandinistas of continuing to help the Salvadoran guerrillas, who had launched their biggest offensive on Nov. 11. _ Dec. 12, 1989: Ortega and four Central American presidents issue a communique calling for the demobilization of both the Salvadoran guerrillas and the Contras. _ Feb. 25, 1990: Elections are held and are seen as a test of the sincerity of Sandinista promises to democratize.

DOC.HEAD: Investigator Arrested For Selling `Clean' Urine to Fake Drug Tests
DOC.TEXT: A probation investigator was arrested after selling two vials of his urine for $60 to undercover agents who claimed they were trying to fake drug tests, authorities said Saturday. Roberto Santiago, a 20-year-old investigator in Hudson County's probation department, was arrested Friday after making the sale and was charged with two counts of second-degree official misconduct and held on $5,000 bail, county Prosecutor Paul DePascale said. DePascale said Santiago was arrested at his desk Friday afternoon. The prosecutor said Santiago was immediately suspended without pay from his job. Two other probation investigators also approached by the undercover agents declined to help fake the tests, DePascale said. Both undercover agents secretly recorded conversations with Santiago to establish intent, he said. The county's probation office, which collects urine samples of former inmates and others on parole to check their compliance with the terms of their release, sends the specimens to a private laboratory to test for drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Nationals Indicted for Alleged Weapons Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury indicted four Filipino nationals, including a retired judge, in an alleged attempt to smuggle weapons and ammunition to their homeland, authorities said. They are each accused of five counts of weapons violations and one count of customs violations in connection with what authorities say was a scheme to smuggle 371 pistols and 500,000 rounds of ammunition to Cagayan province in the Philippines. The area has been the site of frequent anti-government activity in recent months. Indicted Friday were Antonio Paredes, 65; his son, Quintin Paredes III, 42; Maria Louisa Tan Hang, 34; and her husband, Kerwin Hang, 42. The elder Paredes, who lives in Long Beach, was once a vice governor and judge in the Philippines, said U.S. Attorney Carol Gilliam, who is prosecuting the case. The other three are residents of the Philippines and the younger Parades has a Manila law practice, Gilliam said. The elder Paredes was freed on $250,000 bail. His son and Mrs. Hang were held without bail and a bail hearing has not been set for Mrs. Hang's husband, authorities said. Authorities said the pistols and ammunition were seized Feb. 8 before they were to be put on a ship bound for the Philippines. If convicted, each of the four faces up to 10 years in prison and a $1 million fine on the customs charge and five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each of the five firearms counts.

DOC.HEAD: Carter: Future Depends on Winners, Losers, U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE number of observers, ADD Dodd quote; pickup graf 12 pvs, `Carter spoke...'
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's future is in the hands of the losers in Sunday's general election as well as the winners, former President Jimmy Carter said Saturday. He also said the United States should move ``immediately'' to repair tattered relations with Nicaragua if the vote is free and fair. At least 3,000 international observers are monitoring the election, according to election officials. But Carter's verdict will be crucial, in part because of the impact he had when he denounced fraud in the Panamanian election last year and in part because his group includes a dozen U.S. senators and representatives. Carter said the Sandinista government, which has been in power since the 1979 revolution, realizes the importance of holding an election that he can endorse and has adopted virtually all of his recommendations to ensure a clean vote. ``It would indeed be a hollow victory if they got the most votes and then I went before the world media and said in my opinion this vote was ... false,'' he said. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., who has been a key player in U.S.-Nicaragua policymaking, criticized the Bush administration for setting conditions for normalizing relations after the vote, such as requiring a period of ``good behavior.'' ``I think you've got to get through the process first,'' Dodd said. The Bush administration has said that even if the Sandinistas win in a fair election, better relations depend on their ``good behavior'' and stopping aid to El Salvador's leftist rebels. The Sandinistas deny supplying the rebels with weapons. Carter and the other major observer missions, the Organization of American States and the United Nations group, have said they are optimistic about election day. They have also emphasized the importance of what follows. ``Will there be reconciliation? What will happen with the Contras?'' Carter asked. ``What will be the future relationship of Nicaragua and the United States?'' If the election is clean, Carter said, the Bush administration should end the U.S. economic embargo that has helped turn Nicaragua into one of the poorest nations in the hemisphere, help demobilize the Contra rebels and re-establish full diplomatic relations with Nicaragua. ``I've urged our country to honor the process that has evolved here and to give credit to the Nicaraguan people for having established what I consider to be a very admirable campaign procedure and ... a superb system for holding the elections tomorrow.'' Carter spoke at a news conference and then in an interview with a small group of reporters. He said the winners and the losers Sunday have a critical, continuing role in the reconciliation of this badly divided nation. ``Will there be a continuing commitment to the level of democracy, freedom, openness of political campaigning, a sense of pluralism ... a respect for human rights? That's a question to answered by the victor,'' he said. ``Will those defeated participate in a constructive way, a minority way? Will there be reconciliation? What will happen with the Contras?'' Carter said peace talks with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels should begin immediately, whatever the outcome. ``I would hope that no matter who wins, even the opposition parties, that the Sandinistas would begin immediate talks with the Contras,'' he said. Throughout the bitter campaign, President Daniel Ortega has accused the coalition backing his main challenger, publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, of being in league with the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arrested After Skyrocket Bursts Under Pesticide Helicopters
DOC.TEXT: A fireworks skyrocket burst below two low-flying helicopters spraying pesticide to control a fruit fly infestation, and two men were arrested for investigation of assault, authorities said. Neither helicopter was damaged by the skyrocket, which was observed by both pilots about 9:45 p.m. Friday, said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Chris Wahla. The alleged attack on the helicopters occurred amid a rising public outcry against the repeated aerial spraying of the pesticide malathion over Los Angeles suburbs where the Mediterranean fruit fly has been found. The non-native Medfly is regarded as a threat to many fruits and vegetables grown commercially in California. Officials maintain spraying of a sticky mixture of malathion and corn syrup bait doesn't pose a health threat, but opponents of the spraying say too little is known about the potential risk. The rocket went up 200 feet before exploding in a shower of sparks, witnesses said. The helicopters were flying in formation at about 500 feet. A state ground spotter in radio contact with the helicopters saw two men lighting the skyrocket, and called authorities. Patrick Gilmour of Lakewood and Charles Rockwell of Fullerton, both 21, were booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon. The men denied ligniting the skyrocket, Wahla said.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Stone Vehicles, Protest Police Beatings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with other reports of protests, teachers supporting students, details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government protesters stoned buses and cars around the capital Saturday and demanded freedom for students who were beaten and detained after ending a church sit-in, witnesses said. Teachers at the state-run university announced support for the 6-day-old student protests, the most serious challenge to the government in decades. Also, the clandestine Ivorian Peoples Front announced the government banned its newletter following a first edition that called for a peaceful transition to democracy. The government cited a 1951 law on the need to protect public order and bar publication of false information. The protesters are challenging the regime of conservative President Felix Houphuet-Boigny. They want a multiparty government and have protested officials' lavish lifestyles during a time of austerity in this West African nation. About 100 students ran through the central Boulevard de la Republique, yelling ``Liberty!'' and ``Free our comrades!'' on Saturday, and police took no action against them. Protesters demanded police free 200 students who were arrested and beaten early Saturday when they ended a 10-hour occupation of the Abidjan's Roman Catholic cathedral. The students also criticized the church, saying it had failed to mediate with the government over their demands for democracy. A Catholic official accused a Cabinet minister of lying to Cardinal Bernard Yago, who was assured the protesters inside the church would receive safe passage if they left. Police also beat and briefly detained a priest who accompanied the students to guarantee their safety, the official said on condition of anonymity. The priest was identified as the Rev. Jean-Pierre Koutouan, curator of St. Paul's Cathedral in this capital city. Police were seen beating the students on the bus that drove them to the main police station. It was not known how many protesters were injured. The cardinal confronted police about the beatings, then met with Interior Minister Youssouf Kone, who denied ever giving assurances of safety, the official said. More than three dozen other students were arrested during the week, but some were released and it was not known how many remained in detention. One student said he had a friend among the church protesters who was arrested and later released. Students and other protesters Saturday stoned buses in the sprawling marketplace of Treichville, a slum suburb a few miles from the city center, and shopkeepers quickly closed their doors, witnesses said. In another protest, students stoned buses and cars on the main road between the city center and Yopougon, a working-class suburb where the trouble started Monday when protesters set fire to two cars. New protests were also reported by witnesses Saturday in Adjame, another working-class neighborhood. The Ivorian League of Human Rights said the ``forces of law and order have brutally intervened ... following the rebellion by students.'' Houphouet-Boigny, 84, has ruled this nation as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. He has refused recent calls for a multiparty government, saying the system endangered national unity. Dissent has grown in Ivory Coast as the economy suffers from a decade-old recession caused by slumping cocoa and coffee prices that brought unemployment and pay cuts to one of Africa's more prosperous countries. In its announcement Saturday, the union of university lecturers announced it was backing the students. It called for political and economic reforms and a better-funded education system. In an indirect response, state television news quoted from a letter it said it received from a citizen denouncing the association's statement ``as intellectual red (communist) trash ... that in no way reflects the realities of the economic crisis facing Ivorians.'' It was the first time the state-run news media has acknowledged the unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Joliet Escapee Back In Custody, One Still at Large
DOC.TEXT: The fifth of six prisoners who escaped a prison in Joliet turned himself in Saturday at his parents' urging, a prison system spokesman said. Ronald Roach, 20, surrendered at the Stark County Sheriff's Department in Toulon after making his way home to Wyoming, Ill., said Nic Howell, spokesman for the Illinois Department of Corrections. Roach was to be returned to Joliet to face arraignment on escape charges, Howell said. Roach was serving a four-year sentence for burglary when he and five other prisoners escaped before dawn Feb. 11 from the maximum-security Joliet Correctional Center, the state's oldest prison. All the other escapees have been captured except for 21-year-old David Rodriguez of Chicago, who was serving a 25-year term for murder.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Want Expanded Funding for Head Start Program
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with session debate; edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The nation's governors parted with the White House Saturday over the level of funding necessary for the popular preschool program Head Start. The debate during the first session of the National Governors Association's winter meeting centered on the national educational goals outlined recently by President Bush. Before the formal opening of their debate, NGA chairman Terry Branstad, the Republican governor of Iowa, declared that ``we believe that it is not acceptable to just let American education sit where it is today. There has to be radical change.'' Many of the goals ``are very ambitious and they may be extremely difficult to achieve,'' Branstand said. Budget Director Richard G. Darman was appearing before the governors on Sunday, and the state officials were having dinner with Bush at the White House. The governors also were to meet with Bush on Monday. Although they expanded the student achievement goal, the most controversial action came in the objectives approved as part of the so-called ``readiness'' goal. Bush in his State of the Union address proposed that by the year 2000, all children in America will start school ready to learn. His focus was on 4-year-olds. The NGA Education Task Force, at the urging of co-chairman Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, approved the objective to fully fund Head Start, which provides preschool services such as breakfast, lunch and health screening to needy children between the ages of 3 and 5. Under the approved objective: ``The federal government should work with the states to develop early intervention strategies for children. All eligible children should have access to Head Start, Chapter I, or some other successful preschool program with strong parental involvement. Our first priority must be to provide at least one year of pre-school for all disadvantaged children.'' Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer pushed to include Chapter I in the objective, although that program aids disadvantaged elementary and secondary students. Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri and Gov. Ray Mabus of Mississippi led the push to insert language to fully fund the preschool program. Asked later whether the White House would have problems with the Head Start language, Clinton said, ``I don't know. I hope not.'' Clinton noted that the Bush administration would have until the year 2000 to accomplish that objective. However, Roger Porter, White House domestic policy adviser, was noncommital. ``I can't say anything until everything's over,'' said Porter, noting that Bush last year proposed spending $250 million for the program and has asked for $500 million for fiscal year 1991. The task force estimated it would cost about $1.5 billion to fully fund the program. The governors also broadened the language of the student achievement goal. Bush had said that by the year 2000, American students will leave grades four, eight, and 12 having demonstrated competency in challenging subject matter, including English, mathematics, science, history and geography. Rather than changing the goal as Clinton had suggested, the task force agreed to add that: ``every school in America will ensure that all students learn to use their minds well, so they may be prepared for responsible citizenship, further learning, and productive employment in our modern economy.'' ``It's pretty hard to disagree with this,'' said Porter chuckling. The conference ends on Tuesday with House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., discussing the congressional agenda. The NGA session was the first opportunity for the governors to begin putting their own stamp on the drive to improve the nation's educational system. ``We are here to create a national consensus to make American education world class,'' said Branstad. ``We believe it is not acceptable to just let American education sit where it is today. There has to be radical change.'' Branstad said that even after the governors approve the objectives ``this will remain a dynamic process and adjustments and improvements will be made along the way.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Safe Driver Fatal, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0602,0384
DOC.HEAD: Youth Judged `Safest Teen-age Driver' Killed in Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `A passenger...with injuries,' to UPDATE that injured passenger in stable condition; RECASTS lead to shorten and CORRECT typo in driver. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Last July...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CR2
DOC.TEXT: A youth honored as America's safest teen-age driver may have fallen asleep at the wheel before his car slammed head-on into another this weekend, killing him and the other driver, police said. The boy, Michael Doucette, 17, of Concord, and the other driver, Sharon Ann Link, 19, of Lebanon, were pronounced dead at the scene. The crash occurred shortly after 5 p.m. Friday. According to the police report, Doucette's car _ which he won in the safe driver competition _ drifted over the center line and slammed head-on into Link's. It appeared Link may have tried to swerve out of the way of the oncoming car, as the collision happened at the extreme right side of her lane. ``Preliminary investigation shows (Doucette) may have fallen asleep at the wheel,'' the state police report said. Henniker police said Saturday that no further information on the accident would be released until the investigation is finished. A passenger in Link's car, Michael Dimascola, 20, of Lebanon, was injured in the crash, and was listed in stable condition Saturday at Concord Hospital. Last July, Doucette won the safe driving title in a contest called ``Operation Driver Excellence'' sponsored by Dodge and AMVETS, a veterans group. The contest was held in Detroit. He won a $5,000 scholarship, a trophy and the use of a 1989 Dodge for a year. That is the car he was driving Friday night. He also won a state competition, netting $250 cash and $500 scholarship. Doucette, driving the winning car, was one of the attractions in a New Year's Eve parade down Concord's Main Street. Concord High School Principal Charles Foley was shaken by the news. ``He was just a fine kid from a good family,'' Foley said. ``It's heartbreaking.'' After winning the competition last year, Doucette said the contest was ``like a driver's test, only a lot harder.'' ``You need to concentrate and be aware of many things. Not anyone can do it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Custody Battle Shifts From Washington to New Zealand
DOC.TEXT: The search for Hilary is over. But the war for her has widened. America's most famed child custody battle has boiled across two oceans in just the past week, first into the courtrooms of Britain, and now, into those of New Zealand. Hilary Foretich, 7 1@2 years old, has been found, by her father's investigators, living with her maternal grandparents in Christchurch. And there, presumably within days, the fight which has cost the girl's mother alone nearly $2 million _ and more than two years in jail _ will resume. Both parents intend to be there, with the prospect that another nation's courts will become embroiled in a case which already has produced more than 450 pleadings before U.S. judges, with no end in sight. Hilary is the daughter of Jean Elizabeth Morgan, the 42-year-old Washington plastic surgeon who has persistently charged her ex-husband, Eric Foretich, with sexually abusing the child. Having failed to support those allegations to the satisfaction of any court, she sent Hilary into hiding and spent 759 days in jail rather than accord Foretich his legal visitation rights, an act which earned the mother, in countless hearts, a martyr's stature. Her sympathizers included the Congress and President Bush, who signed the legislation which freed her last September from municipal Judge Herbert Dixon's indeterminate sentence for contempt. Foretich, 45, a dental surgeon in suburban Falls Church, Va., never yielded, meanwhile, in his search for Hilary. He made several trips to Great Britain, where, just days ago, a BBC talk-show producer, Di Burgess, was forced under court order obtained by Foretich's attorneys to reveal what she had learned in the wake of filming a documentary on the case. And that, in short, was that the child, under the name Ellen Morgan, had attended a girl's prep school in Plymouth, England, in the 1987-88 school year, while living with her grandparents. Within days, Foretich's investigators tracked the older couple, William and Antonia Morgan, to their current home in New Zealand, at Christchurch, about 190 miles southwest of the capital city of Wellington. It had long been speculated that Elizabeth Morgan had entrusted Hilary to her parents, but their whereabouts remained a mystery. Their role discovered, the elder Morgans obtained an order from a New Zealand Family Court on Friday which temporarily entitles them to retain custody of Hilary, according to Roger Carson, detective chief inspector in Christchurch. He said a further hearing is scheduled this week. ``I ... found my daughter,'' Foretich said early Saturday before leaving for New Zealand. ``I'm elated.'' But neither he nor Ms. Morgan would predict what legal fates await them or Hilary. ``I don't have any illusions that this is going to be easy,'' Foretich said. Ms. Morgan, meanwhile, seemed almost relieved that her three-year secret was out. While declining to reveal whether she had had any contact with Hilary since her release from jail, she said: ``I can tell you I talked to her at length today. And we had a heavenly conversation.'' Ms. Morgan and her new husband, U.S. Appeals Judge Paul Michel, spent several hours Saturday with her attorney, Stephen Sachs. Their first objective: to convince Dixon, the Superior Court judge who jailed her, to return her passport, without which she cannot legally travel to New Zealand. They plan to argue for that on Monday. Ms. Morgan declined to give an accounting of her parents' travels, or to say how long they have been in New Zealand. She said, though, that she had been assured that New Zealand has very strong statutes protecting children, and that the court there will make no decision until Hilary has been evaluated by an expert in child sexual abuse. But she also acknowledged that many nations routinely respect the findings of one another's courts in child custody cases. ``I'm not a foreteller of the future,'' she said. ``I would like to think that our courts would offer her what I've been asking. At the moment, if I brought her back today, she would not be protected.'' For years, each parent has accused the other of making Hilary's life a nightmare. In the U.S. courts, the case is called Civil Action No. D 684-83. To the American public, it is the Elizabeth Morgan Story, even as every judge along the way has deemed it unsupported by evidence. Ms. Morgan has claimed there was physical evidence _ scarring _ that Foretich sexually abused their daughter. To that, Foretich countered in court that the scars were the consequence of injuries caused by Ms. Morgan herself to stage photographic evidence to bolster her claims. A Virginia judge dismissed the mother's suit for exclusive custody when she refused to produce her daughter in court. Foretich, recently separated from his fourth wife _ Elizabeth Morgan was the third _ has said ``I've made some poor decisions in some of the women I've been associated with ... but I did not rape my children. That I did not do. I'd blow my brains out first.'' By his account, Ms. Morgan ``is insane ... totally evil.'' At one point, Ms. Morgan also accused Foretich's parents, both over 70, of sexually abusing Hilary on the girl's visits to Foretich's Early Georgian home, modeled after the President's House at his alma mater, the College of William and Mary. By their account, they had driven up from Gloucester Point, Va., each time Hilary was brought to their son's house, on the advice of a lawyer friend who had advised him to keep the place in ``wall-to-wall people'' because of a developing trend in child custody cases _ accusations of sexual abuse. Among others who visited the house at the same time as young Hilary was Foretich's other daughter, Heather, now 10, born to his second wife, Sharon Foretich. And, in 1985, Sharon Foretich, following Morgan's example, accused him of sexually abusing Heather. Foretich contended that his second and third wives had colluded on their cases, and that Heather had been coached. He took and passed two lie-detector tests on his behavior with the two children, and a Virginia court ruled that Sharon Foretich had not proved her allegation, either.

DOC.HEAD: Seven-Year Custody Fight Began 14 Months After Marriage
With AM-Quest for Hilary
DOC.TEXT: Here, in chronological order, are key developments related to the battle between Dr. Elizabeth Morgan and Dr. Eric Foretich for custody of their 7-year-old daughter, Hilary: January 1982: Morgan and Foretich are married in Haiti, where Foretich also gets a divorce from his second wife. Morgan, at the time, is two months pregnant with Hilary. August 1982: Morgan moves out of Foretich's home in Great Falls, Va., a Washington suburb. Morgan and her mother, who has been living with the couple, return to Morgan's home in Washington. Hilary is born a week later. November 1982: Morgan obtains a Haitian divorce from Foretich. March 1983: Morgan and Foretich sue each other for custody in D.C. Superior Court. Since the girl was born, Morgan has permitted Foretich to see the child only in a day care center, and has stopped those visits after hiring an at-home baby sitter. November 1983: Morgan is awarded permanent custody, but Foretich wins liberal visitation rights. November 1985: Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon hears Morgan's allegations that Foretich has sexually abused Hilary. He rules in favor of Foretich, saying the evidence is not conclusive. August 1986: Morgan files a civil suit in federal court against Foretich and his parents, claiming that the grandparents also have abused the child. The grandparents file a counterclaim for defamation. After a lengthy trial, the jury rules against each side's claim. August 1986: After conducting a 12-day hearing on continued allegations of abuse, Judge Dixon orders Morgan to jail for refusing to allow Foretich to visit their daughter. Morgan is released after three days by the D.C. Court of Appeals, which requires that she surrender the deed to her house as bond and turn over her passport. February 1987: Dixon sends Morgan to jail again. She is released after three days, after agreeing let Foretich visit Hilary. April 1987: Dixon orders Morgan to allow Foretich unsupervised weekend visits with his daughter. Morgan alleges that the child is abused again. August 1987: Dixon jails Morgan a third time, after Morgan refuses to produce the child for a two-week, unsupervised visit. The child is missing. August 1988: The D.C. Court of Appeals upholds Morgan's incarceration. Finding that both sides presented believable evidence, the court described the effect on Hilary by quoting an African proverb: ``When elephants fight, it is the grass that suffers.'' December, 1988: Judge Dixon refuses to release Morgan, saying, ``The coercion has only just begun.'' On Dec. 28, her incarceration eclipses the record for civil contempt cases. January 1989: The U.S. Supreme Court refuses to hear Morgan's appeal. September 1989: Morgan is freed after Congress passes a law, tailored for her, limiting civil contempt imprisonment in the District of Columbia to a year. Hilary's whereabouts remain unknown. February 1990: Hilary is discovered by Foretich's investigators to be living in Christchurch, New Zealand, with Morgan's parents. A New Zealand court temporarily bars Foretich from contacting the girl, and indicates it will begin its own custody hearings within a week.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Says He Will Invite Bush To Inauguration
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega, confident he'll be re-elected to a second six-year term, said Saturday he would invite President Bush to his inauguration as part of an effort to normalize relations after 10 years of bitterness. ``The doors of Nicaragua are open to the president of the United States,'' he told a group of journalists. ``I am going to invite the government of the United States and President Bush to the inauguration.'' Relations between the United States and Nicaragua have been bitter for 10 years as U.S.-sponsored Contra guerrillas tried to topple the Ortega's leftist Sandinista government. But with a staggering economy _ in part due to U.S. trade sanctions _ and the military defeat of the Contras, the Sandinistas are eager to normalize relations. Ortega faces an opposition coalition headed by newspaper publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in Sunday's elections, which will be monitored by more than 3,000 international observers. Ortega is considered the favorite, and European diplomats consulted here Saturday said there is a consensus among them that Ortega will be re-elected. He has often said Bush should come to Nicaragua to understand its reality. His invitation appeared to be another pitch to bring the United States to the negotiating table. Ortega said there is mutual distrust between the United States and Nicargua. ``It is not easy to change this situation that the United States caused,'' he said, referring to the U.S. support of the Contra rebels. The United States says Nicaragua has been shipping arms to Salvadoran rebels, and Secretary of State James A. Baker said Thursday that even if the Sandinistas win a fair election, a ``substantial period of good behavior'' would be required before relations could be normalized. ``I can understand Baker's tone. It requires not only the good will of both countries, but the combined action of the international community in favor of an agreement to overcome our differences,'' Ortega said. He said Spanish President Felipe Gonzalez, ``who has good communication with Bush,'' could be a good intermediary between Nicaragua and the United Sates. ``I have talked to Gonzalez about this several times,'' he said. Ortega once again refused to say flatly that his government would not in the future send arms to leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front in El Salvador. He said he has stated repeatedly that Nicaragua is not sending weapons to the Salvadoran rebels, but the United States believes otherwise. A plane from Nicaragua was shot down in El Salvador last November carrying rockets for the rebels. ``The United States and Nicargua must sit down and discuss this,'' he said. ``We said before we are not sending weapons. We have asked the United Nations to verify this.'' Sources close to the Nicaraguan government said the Sandinistas had made a policy decision not to send arms to the FMLN after a Central American summit conference on Dec. 12. Ortega said Central American presidents have a written agreement not to allow weapons to be sent to rebel groups in the region, but that the United States does not respect this agreement. He added the United States says it is sending only humanitarian assistance to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua, ``but that equipment can be used to set up ambushes.'' The U.S. aid consists of non-lethal items such as food, tents and boots, but the Sandinistas point out that boots can help troops in the jungle. The Nicaraguan president also said, in answer to another question, that Sandinista defense expenditures would be reduced as the war with the U.S.-backed Contras winds down. Nicaragua currently has the largest armed force by far in the region. ``All Central American presidents agree that an arms race does not favor economic and social development,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Activist Arrested, Colleague Says
DOC.TEXT: A prominent human rights activist has been arrested in the government crackdown on the movement for multiparty democracy, an associate said Saturday. The arrest was reported on the eve of planned nationwide demonstrations to demand an end to a 29-year-old ban on political parties in this Himalayan kingdom. Government spokesman Radhey Sham Bista refused to comment on the reported arrest. The human rights activist, Mathura Prasad Shrestha, was taken away by policemen from his Katmandu home late Friday to an undisclosed location, said Debendra Raj Panday, the vice-president of the Human Rights Organization of Nepal. Panday said he was told about Shrestha's arrest by ``sources other than his family,'' but he refused to elaborate. He said Shrestha is a member of the Forum for Protection of Human Rights, which works closely with Panday's group. Shrestha, a professor of community medicine at the Teaching Hospital of Tribhuvan University in Katmandu, had organized a rally by doctors and medical students on Friday to protest the deaths of demonstrators during the democracy movement. ``I think that is what prompted the government action. The government is so intolerant,'' Panday said. The government says 12 protesters have died since last Sunday, when two banned political groups _ the Nepali Congress Party and a left-wing coalition _ launched a campaign to demand restoration of multiparty democracy. Most victims died in police gunfire. Activists allege that the death toll is nearly double the government figure. They also say that at least 1,000 people have been arrested and that some were being tortured in jail. The government says 175 people have been arrested and denies allegations of torture. Panday said he along with Shrestha and other human rights activists met Prime Minister Marich Mansingh Shresta on Friday to ``express concern at the repressive measures of the government.'' ``It was an unproductive meeting, and the prime minister had no cogent argument to put before us,'' he said, adding that the two-hour meeting often became heated. Protest leaders said they planned demonstrations nationwide on Sunday to protest the killings during the government crackdown. Political demonstrations are banned in Nepal. Nepal's two-year experiment with a Western-style democracy ended in 1961, when King Mahendra, the father of the present monarch, King Birendra, dissolved the government of the Nepali Congress Party. He accused it of corruption and poor administration and banned political parties.

DOC.HEAD: Decade Of Leftist Rule On The Line in Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with new figure for election observers, Ortega saying he will invite Bush to Nicaragua if he wins; pickup 6th graf pvs, `Ortega has...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA3
DOC.TEXT: A decade of Sandinista pride and U.S. hostility toward Nicaragua goes on the line Sunday as voters decide whether to stick with their leftist government for six more years. The candidates of the two top parties _ Sandinista President Daniel Ortega and Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition or UNO _ embody the choices for Nicaragua's future. ``These elections constitute a gigantic and irreversible step in the process toward a greater democratization and reconciliation of the nation,'' Ortega wrote in an editorial published Saturday in the Sandinista party newspaper Barricada. The Sandinistas have put a priority on not just winning or winning fairly, but also on appearing to win fairly. To that end, they have invited election observers, including the Organization of American States, the United Nations and former President Jimmy Carter. Ismary Castillo, a spokeswoman for the Supreme Electoral Council, said Saturday that at least 3,000 observers had been accredited and that in the end there would probably be 4,000 from more than 40 groups. U.S. policy is also at stake: If the Sandinistas win a fair vote it will be difficult for President Bush to maintain the hostility of the past. Should Mrs. Chamorro win, the U.S. hostility is expected to end. Ortega said Saturday that he would invite Bush to his inauguration as part of an effort to normalize relations after 10 years of bitterness. ``The doors of Nicaragua are open to the president of the United States,'' he told a group of journalists. Ortega has been favored in polls, but his opponents say Nicaraguans are afraid to reveal their true feelings outside a truly secret ballot box. About 1.75 million of Nicaragua's 3.5 million people are registered to vote. The tough guerrilla fighter in Ortega has refused to bow to the United States, which is called ``the enemy of humanity'' in the Sandinista Front anthem. Lately, the statesman has prevailed over the rebel, sending conciliatory overtures to Washington. With changes in the East bloc siphoning off aid and reducing the moral authority of the extreme left, the Sandinistas are eager to restore normal relations with Washington to help right their battered economy. The Sandinistas have released political prisoners, said they wanted a mixed economy and pledged there will be no more expropriations of private property. Ortega's life has been dedicated to the Sandinista cry that ``the past will never return,'' a past that included U.S. military and economic intervention and right-wing dictatorships. Mrs. Chamorro and UNO, he says, are the heirs to that legacy. Mrs. Chamorro portrays herself as a torch-bearer for the democratic ideals of her slain husband, revered civic leader Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, and of his trademark promise that ``Nicaragua will be a republic again.'' Mrs. Chamorro's bitterness at what she considers the Sandinistas' betrayal of those ideals and the nation's deep economic crisis are UNO's two top drawing cards. ``On this bright day, which announces the end of the dark night of Sandinismo, I raise my flag of national reconciliation,'' Mrs. Chamorro told some 60,000 supporters at UNO's final rally a week ago. The Sandinista National Liberation Front has two points in its favor: It helped free Nicaragua from years of dictatorship in 1979, and it has given the common Nicaraguan a sense of national pride in standing up to ``the colossus to the north,'' as the United States is often called. The Sandinistas are counting on that grassroots loyalty and pride to defeat Mrs. Chamorro, whom they call ``an instrument of U.S. policy.'' They admit to some errors but blame the economic crisis on the long war against U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas and a U.S. economic embargo. UNO promises to lift Nicaragua from the dubious distinction of being called by some experts the poorest nation in the Western hemisphere, and to finally bring true democracy after 45 years of Somoza family rule and 10 years of Sandinismo. Ortega has said he is not running against UNO but against President Bush. In fact, the Sandinistas believe that with a certified election in hand, Bush will agree to deal with Ortega. Ortega has said the elections mark ``the beginning of an era where the United States recognizes Nicaragua's right to self-determination.'' Also hanging in the balance are Nicaragua's relations with its neighbors, who worry about the Sandinista military machine and fear it backs leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. The Sandinista Front, the enfant terrible of the region, will be transformed just for having gone through what many consider Nicaragua's first truly free elections this century. From its original project of a Cuban-style one-party state, the Sandinistas' own guerrilla movement has been forced to turn into a party organized to win elections. Ortega himself has evolved from a dour-faced president to a modern candidate who smiles, kisses babies and jumps on stage in jeans and bright cotton shirts while waving the red-and-black Sandinista flag.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Knocks Out Power To Much of Downtown Seattle
DOC.TEXT: About 70 blocks of downtown Seattle lost electrical power for several hours Saturday after a fire in a transformer vault. No injuries were reported, but the outage darkened hotel lobbies and shut down switching equipment for the Washington State Lottery, leaving some people unable to buy tickets on the night of a $6 million drawing _ one of the state's largest in months. The Fire Department responded about 11:30 a.m. and doused it by 1:50 p.m., a fire dispatcher said. City Light spokesman Hugh McIntosh said power was restored at 3:35 p.m. to the entire area. ``There was less damage than we had feared,'' McIntosh said after initially indicating power restoration could take days. The area affected was bigger than, and included, the section that was without power during a similar transformer vault fire in August 1988. In that incident, power was out for three days, McIntosh said. The fire apparently started in a device that works like a circuit breaker in the Olympic Building, he said. The vault is in the building's basement. The primary electric cables were across the room and were undamaged, he said. The vault contains three transformers and three cables. The protector device was replaced, allowing the power to come back on, he said. City Light had closed down those cables plus three others at a nearby substation when news of the fire was received, he said. Those six cables or circuits constitute most of the downtown network, he said. The area of the power outage encompassed Pike Place Market, several major department stores, the Seattle Aquarium and the Port of Seattle. Lottery spokesman Dick Paulson said 417 of the lottery system's 980 terminals in the state _ from south Seattle to the Canadian border _ were without power because of the fire. The terminals are connected to a switching center located in the Westin Building. People in four counties were unable to buy tickets, but the drawing would take place as usual, Paulson said.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Killed in West Bank
DOC.TEXT: Masked Arabs Saturday killed a 30-year-old Palestinian suspected of cooperating with Israeli authorities, Israel radio reported. An army spokesman, who under regulations could not be identified, confirmed the death and said police were investigating the circumstances. Israel radio identified the victim as Ahmed Hawajeh of the village of Naalin near the West Bank town of Ramallah. His death raised to 189 the number of Arabs killed by fellow Palestinians on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities during the 26-month-old Palestinian uprising against the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 658 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians and 43 Israelis have died in the violence. Also Saturday, Israel television reported that Israel is prepared to accept peace talks with a Palestinian delegation that includes a deportee and an Arab living in East Jerusalem. The television said the agreement was worked out after Friday's meeting between Foreign Minister Moshe Arens and Secretary of State James A. Baker III and a series of talks in Washington held by Cabinet Minister Ehud Olmert. A foreign ministry spokesman could not confirm the report and in a later television broadcast Olmert was quoted as denying that such an agreement was reached. Including a deportee in a Palestinian delegation has been suggested as a way of satisfying the PLO's demand that diaspora Palestinians be included in the talks, while at the same time adhering to Israel's insistance that it will talk to only residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The television and both of Israel's radio stations reported Saturday that the nation's four top leaders _ Arens, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Finance Minister Shimon Peres and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin _ will meet to discuss proposals for the makeup of a Palestinian delegation before Arens travels to Poland on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Balaguer Nominated To Run For Fifth Term
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquin Balaguer was nominated Saturday by a governing party convention to run for a fifth term in elections scheduled for May. Balaguer, 83 and nearly blind, had refused to say whether he would seek re-election until he underwent a medical examination in Houston, Texas, on Feb. 12 and received a clean bill of health. The convention of 1,750 members of the center-right Social Christian Reformist Party also authorized Balaguer to pick a running mate of his choice for the May 16 balloting. Opinion polls have indicated Balaguer is the second-favorite candidate after former President Juan Bosch, 82. Balaguer, a former minister under the late dictator Rafael L. Trujillo, was first elected to power in 1966 and won subsequent four year terms in 1970, 1974 and 1986. After Trujillo's assassination in 1960, Bosch, a leftist, won general elections in 1962, but was ousted in a military coup a year later. In 1965 U.S. troops invaded the island after Bosch supporters and loyalist soldiers attempted to overthrow a civilian junta.

DOC.HEAD: 1950s Balladeer Johnnie Ray, Precursor to Rock 'n' Roll
DOC.TEXT: Fifties balladeer Johnnie Ray, known as the ``Prince of Wails'' for his vocal histrionics on such songs as ``Somebody Stole My Gal'' and ``Just Walkin' in the Rain,'' died Saturday of liver failure. He was 63. Ray, who had entered Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on Feb. 16 with liver failure, died at 4 p.m., said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. ``His family and friends were with him at the time of his death,'' Wise said. In the early 1950s, the slender, boyish singer revolutionized popular music with his unique blend of rhythm and blues, country and gospel punctuated with real-sounding sobs. Some said his raw and emotional style opened the door to a new type of music that later became rock 'n' roll. Ray's first hit record was ``Cry,'' followed by ``The Little White Cloud That Cried,'' ``Please Mr. Sun,'' ``Brokenhearted, '' ``What's the Use,'' ``Somebody Stole My Gal,'' ``Who's Sorry Now,'' and ``Yes Tonight Josephine.'' ``Cry,'' perhaps Ray's greatest hit, has sold more than 25 million copies since its original release, said his publicist, Alan Eichler. Ray's raw and emotional style was controversial for the early 1950s, and he drew huge crowds in nightclub appearances in New York and elsewhere. As the press reached for phrases to describe his performance, Ray was crowned at various times as ``The Prince of Wails,'' ``The Nabob of Sob,'' ``The Howling Success,'' `The Song Wringer,'' ``The Cry Guy'' and the ``Master of Misery.'' ``Of course the days are gone of the screaming teen-agers _ and nobody had them screaming more than I did,'' Ray recalled in a 1984 interview with the Associated Press. ``But even in those days I had the same kind of audience I have now _ the elderly, the middle-aged and the young kids,'' he said. ``I don't have a TV series, I've had no hit records. Ray was born Jan. 10, 1927, in Dallas, Ore., a tiny town near Salem. It was there he saw his first movie when he was 3 or 4. ``It was Edna Mae Oliver in `Murder on the Blackboard,' and from then on I wanted to be a movie star,'' he told the AP. In 1954, Darryl F. Zanuck gave him a seven-year contract with 20th Century Fox and he appeared with Ethel Merman, Dan Dailey, Marilyn Monroe, Donald O'Connor and Mitzi Gaynor in ``There's No Business Like Show Business.'' His movie career ended, however, when Zanuck resigned to become an independent producer. Ray recalled that the new chief at Fox was not a fan. Ray's success as a recording artist also waned in the United States as other forms of rock 'n' roll gained popularity. But he remained popular in England and Australia, Eichler said, and he continued to perform there until last year. His last public appearance was Oct. 7 at the Grand Theatre in Salem, Ore. Ray married Marilyn Morrison in 1952, but the union lasted only two years, the publicist said. He is survived by his sister, Elma Money, and several nieces and nephews.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Meet With Prime Minister Kaifu
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Expands earlier brief item to give background on trade dispute.
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Saturday that President Bush will meet late this week in California with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, a meeting bound to touch on frustrated efforts to resolve trade disagreements. The two will meet this coming Friday and Saturday in Palm Springs ``for a general discussion of international developments, the U.S.-Japanese global partnership and bilateral relations,'' a White House statement said. The announcement said that Bush telephoned Kaifu on Friday to congratulate him on the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's recent electoral triumph and that the pair agreed on the ``desirability of an early meeting.'' The two leaders met for the first time in September, when Kaifu visited Washington soon after becoming prime minister. ``The visit underlies the vital importance both countries attach to the U.S.-Japanese relationship and its contribution to the preservation of peace and prosperity in the Pacific and throughout the world,'' the White House said. Bush wants to hear Japan's position on the political changes in Eastern Europe and hopes for an early exchange of opinions on Japanese-U.S. cooperation toward thawing East-West ties, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official told Kyodo News Service in Tokyo. Another Foreign Ministry official told Kyodo that the two sides hope to find ways to improve their strained trade relations. Kaifu is expected to reassure Bush that Japan intends to solve issues such as the ``structural impediments'' at the top of Washington's complaint list on trade with Japan. The U.S. trade deficit with Japan for 1989 is expected to reach $49 billion. A two-day round of U.S.-Japan ``Structural Impediments Initiative'' talks ended inconclusively in Tokyo on Friday with the two sides taking widely divergent positions on fundamental aspects of the Japanese economy. The American government believes the Japanese have not responded to U.S. demands regarding market barriers, the ministry official told Kyodo.

DOC.HEAD: Harsh Rhetoric, Difference In Perspective Strain Relations With U.S.
AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 11th `Filipino diplomatic...' to CORRECT that warning is from Philippine Embassy in Washington, sted U.S. Embassy; pickup graf 12 `The apparent...'
DOC.TEXT: Four years after the United States encouraged Ferdinand Marcos to surrender power to Corazon Aquino, harsh rhetoric and wide differences over U.S. military bases have strained U.S.-Filipino relations. The problems have emerged nearly three months after U.S. warplanes helped save Mrs. Aquino from military mutineers. Ironically, the intervention may have aggravated relations by encouraging her government to assert its independence from its former colonial power. Since her highly publicized ``snub'' of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last week, the government has tried to soften its rhetoric on the advice of its ambassador to Washington, Emmanuel Pelaez. But the strains also have been exacerbated by statements from American officials questioning the political survivability of Mrs. Aquino, who was touted as the savior of democracy when she was swept to power on Feb. 25, 1986 uprising against Marcos. ``Let me just acknowledge to you that ... relations are in a bumpy path right now,'' U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt said in a TV interview last week. ``We're in some turbulent air.'' Relations with Washington began to sour last month after Congress cut $96 million from the Bush administration's Philippine aid package. Filipinos considered this a violation of the October 1988 agreement under which the United States offered $962 million over two years in return for use of Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations through the end of their lease in 1991. Talks on extending the lease are expected to begin in a few weeks. But any agreement must be ratified by two-thirds of the Philippines' 23-member Senate. Many in the 195-member House of Representatives have urged Mrs. Aquino to postpone talks on the bases until aid is restored. Before Cheney's visit, Mrs. Aquino said she would not receive him because she was angry over negative U.S. media reports on her administration. Filipino officials now insist the ``snub'' was to demonstrate anger over aid cuts. But Mrs. Aquino, who bristles at criticism, cited only the press reports, making it appear her decision was more emotional than political. Filipino diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Philippine Embassy in Washington warned the administration that the snub and strong anti-American statements from congressmen and commentators threatened to undermine U.S. support. The apparent attempt by the Aquino government to distance itself from Washington stems from the sensitive nature of the bases issue and a desire to display independence. An influential minority here believes the bases infringe on sovereignty and that the presence of military men contributes to prostitution and drug addiction. Unlike South Koreans, who face an enemy to the north, Filipinos generally perceive no external military threat. Therefore, U.S. arguments that the bases are essential for national and regional defense carry little weight here. Last year, Mrs. Aquino noted to foreign reporters that the presence of U.S. troops failed to deter Japan from invading in 1941 and doubtless encouraged the attack. Filipinos consider the bases a business deal _ renting territory in return for cash _ and say ``failure'' to pay constitutes a breach of contract. The need to ``stand up to the Americans'' was made more urgent by U.S. intervention in the December coup attempt. U.S. warplanes from Clark flew air cover for government forces, and their intervention was widely seen as decisive in defeating the uprising. But the intervention also encouraged a belief that Mrs. Aquino owes her political survival to the Americans and will ultimately agree to extend the bases at terms favorable to the United States. Last January, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State David Lambertson said the ``danger of a new coup attempt exists'' and that corruption ``remains a real problem in the Philippines.'' Some Filipino officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, believe such statements are a pressure tactic to force the government to accept an unfavorable bases agreement. Officials here are deeply sensitive about such statements from Washington because they recall the buildup of criticism of the Marcos administration, culminating in the United States abandoning its longtime ally in favor of Mrs. Aquino. U.S. diplomats here, also speaking on condition of anonymity, fear that the current spate of criticism from Washington may actually encourage military dissidents to try another coup. They reason that coup plotters might be led to believe that Washington would not intervene again, in an effort to convince the Philippines of the bases' value.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Robert Reid has been The Associated Press bureau chief in Manila since September 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kohl Discuss Polish Border Question, Reunification
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEDEs with 10 grafs to UPDATE with highlights from talks; pick up 5th graf pvs ``I view...''; edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl held talks Saturday to discuss the Polish border question and German reunification. Kohl spent the weekend with Bush at the president's snow-swept retreat at Camp David. During three hours of talks Saturday afternoon, Kohl discussed with Bush ways to approach the problem of Polish borders, West German spokesman Dieter Vogel told reporters. The two leaders were meeting again after dinner on Saturday and then resuming their talks after attending church on Sunday, he said. Kohl reiterated his assertion that only a reunified Germany could give a final guarantee to Poland that the border question is closed, Vogel said. Poland is worried about demands by some German conservatives that Germany be allowed to retake territory that was within German borders until it was transferred to Poland by the World War II victors. But Vogel said Kohl suggested a number of ways in which the two German states could reassure Poles in the meantime, including talks with the Polish government or a joint declaration. During three hours of talks Saturday afternoon, Bush and Kohl also discussed a range of issues affecting reunification, Vogel said. The two leaders were joined by close advisers, and the American side said the two German states should begin soon to consult with the four powers as they make progress in their reunification talks in parallel consultations before the formal two-plus-four talks begin, he said. Vogel said Bush told Kohl of his assessment of developments in Soviet-American relations and arms-reduction talks. The president stressed that the West should support Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's attempts to change the Soviet Union, Vogel said. ``I view this as a very important discussion,'' Bush said as he walked out to meet Kohl, who arrived by helicopter from Washington-Dulles International Airport in Virginia. ``There's a lot of keen interest, not just in Europe but around the world on these discussions we're going to have.'' Bush declined to answer reporters' questions about the substance of the talks, noting he and Kohl would hold a news conference on Sunday morning before Kohl's return to Germany. Bush, bundled up against the icy morning air in a leather flier's jacket and gloves, greeted Kohl and his wife at the landing pad with a hearty, ``Welcome, wlcome.'' ``Wunderbar (wonderful),'' replied Kohl, who was dressed in a business suit with no coat. ``In this time of dramatic change, German-American ties are of essential significance,'' Kohl said through a translator. Bush hustled the West German into a golf cart to drive to the Camp David living quarters, while Barbara Bush took the wheel of a second cart and chauffeured Mrs. Hannelore Kohl. The two leaders were discussing ``the full range of issues related to changes in Eastern Europe,'' according to White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Coming at this volatile juncture, their talks at Camp David were seen as critical in making sure the two allies are together, a German official said. In addition, the Kohl visit was considered an important symbol of close ties between the two governments, three weeks before East Germany holds an election that is to precede reunification talks. Kohl himself faces election in West Germany next Dec. 2, against stiff opposition from the Social Democrats. While Kohl has agreed with Bush that a reunified Germany should remain a member of NATO and NATO troops should remain in West Germany, the Social Democrats contend there will be no need for NATO if the Warsaw Pact continues to diminish in importance. The Soviet Foreign Ministry's policy-making body on Saturday added another facet to the issue by ruling out NATO membership for a unified Germany. Membership in NATO for a reunified Germany would lead to an ``impermissible violation of the military-strategic balance,'' the Foreign Ministry Collegium said in a statement issued by the official Tass news agency. Kohl recently created some uneasiness in Washington with his suggestion that the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation pact that includes the United States, oversee NATO troop deployments and reductions, effectively superseding NATO itself. Agreement to unify the two Germanys was reached earlier this month in Ottawa during talks between East and West Germany and the four World War II victors that divided them: the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union. Joining Bush for this weekend's talks were Baker and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Colombian Guerrillas Free Two Americans
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas released two Americans on Saturday, 10 days after they were kidnapped to protest the visit of President Bush to Colombia for an anti-drug summit. James Donnelly of Detroit and David Kent of Indianapolis were released to a Colombian human rights group in a village in a remote part of the Andes mountains in northwestern Colombia. The rebels gave Donnelly a message for the Colombian government that said ``the country's rich people will be punished if any more guerrillas disappear or if there are any more massacres of peasants.'' Right-wing death squads have killed more than 1,000 people in the last four years, many of them peasants who apparently were suspected to be guerrilla supporters. Donnelly, in a live broadcast interview, said he was treated well by the rebels. Kent was taken to a hospital in the northwestern city of Medellin for treatment of hepatitis, the Colombian radio network RCN said. He fell ill after being kidnapped, and the guerrillas brought a doctor to their mountain hideout to treat him, RCN said, quoting sources with Colombia's Human Rights Committee. The two Americans were released in the village of Cocorna, about 35 miles south of Medellin, RCN said. National Liberation Army guerrillas claimed responsibility for kidnapping the two Feb. 13 in Medellin. Donnelly said in the interview with RCN that he was abducted by 15 men in cars and trucks. ``They treated me well. They gave me good meals,'' Donnelly said in Spanish. ``They said they didn't have any problems with the American people, but just with some parts of the U.S. government that is intervening in Colombia.'' Donnelly, 65, said he has lived in Colombia for 20 years and is married to a Colombian. He said he and Kent, kidnapped spearately, were taken to the mountain hideout the same day they were abducted. Kent, 40, is a teacher at a Medellin school. The were kidnapped three days before President Bush met in Cartagena with three Latin America presidents for an anti-drug summit. The three other presidents _ Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Alan Garcia of Peru, and Jaime Paz of Bolivia _ promised to continue fighting drug traffickers, who are sometimes allied with guerrillas. The National Liberation Army is commanded by a former Roman Catholic priest, Manuel Perez of Spain. Several other priests are believed to be members of the organization, which was founded in the 1970s by another priest, Camilo Torres. He was later killed in a battle with the army. The group has become the most active of Colombia's six guerrilla groups. It kidnapped an American priest, Francis Amico Ferarri, on Feb. 15 in the eastern city of Cali to protest the Bush visit. He was released Feb. 19.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Ban for Domestic Flights Goes Into Effect
DOC.NOTE: EDS: To DELETE reference to Connecticut grandmother, RECASTS first 7 grafs, picking up 8th pvs, Airport terminals...
DOC.TEXT: This weekend the airplane becomes one more no-smoking zone. Beginning Sunday, smokers must contend with a ban effective on all domestic flights and trips to Alaska and Hawaii lasting six hours or less. The ``no smoking'' signs will be turned on permanently on 99.8 percent of daily domestic flights. ``I would probably go into the bathroom and smoke a cigarette,'' said New York stockbroker Art Lehne, who has smoked for 32 of his 55 years. Tampering with an automatic smoke detector is a federal offense punishable with a $2,000 fine. Lehne already has been arrested and fined $40 for defiantly lighting up on non-smoking commuter trains to New York. Lehne's willingness to break the law shows how much the tables have turned. Where non-smokers trying to avoid secondhand smoke once were forced to move, smokers now must contend with a shrinking group of permissible spaces in which to continue their habit. Airport terminals and Amtrak trains may not be far behind, according to the authors of the ban, Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill. Anti-smoking initiatives are taking on new life in President Bush's Cabinet. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan on Friday asked athletic associations to reject sponsorships by tobacco companies. Sullivan also has attacked cigarette makers for targeting advertising on minorities, women and the young. The airline smoking law, an extension of the two-hour ban the senator and congressman won at the end of 1987, exempts flights abroad and those longer than six hours headed to Alaska and Hawaii. ``The result we think will be happier, healthier airline customers and a safer, healthier workplace for airline employees,'' Lautenberg said. But Dan Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, said he could barely keep up with telephone calls from irate smokers accusing the tobacco lobbying group of abandoning them. ``They're miserable,'' Lauria said of the smoking public. ``We are telling the people the law is the law. We're telling people not to smoke in the (airliner's) bathroom. It's dangerous to the plane.'' Lautenberg, Durbin and a host of health organizations say the ban will protect passengers and flight crews from gases and smoke particles recirculated in cabin air. ``A new report just issued by the Department of Transportation proves once again that our concerns were well-founded; that study found that long-term exposure to tobacco smoke in airplanes represents a significant risk of premature death,'' Lautenberg said. The study found 12-15 premature cancer deaths among every 100,000 cabin crew members breathing cabin air. ``That's a risk that no one should have to take,'' he said, although tobacco interests dispute the findings. Non-smoking frequent fliers applaud the measure. ``It definitely will be much more comfortable,'' said Kimberly Smith, a 30-year-old Washington computer consultant who travels on business several times each month. ``I won't feel as though my privacy or space is being invaded against my will.''
