She said she particularly would appreciate the change on longer flights, when even in a non-smoking section, ``after several hours, the smoke still ends up circulating through the filtration system.'' Juliette D. Lenoir, national vice president of the Association of Flight Attendants, said the new policy has been welcomed by the nation's 90,000 flight attendants. ``We received tremendous support nationwide, because flight attendants and the American public said it is not unreasonable to demand a healthy workplace and a smoke-free travel environment,'' she said. The American Lung Association reported last week that several airlines will exceed the law. For example, Virgin Atlantic Airways is offering smokeless flights from New York to London and USAir is banning smoking on its flights to the Bahamas and Bermuda. The association has passed out wallet-sized cards suggesting ways smokers can ``make it through non-smoking trips with flying colors.'' They include breathing exercises, stretching, drinking non-alcoholic and caffeine-free beverages and napping. Ahron Leichtman, president of Citizens Against Tobacco Smoke, a coalition of 100 anti-smoking groups that lobbied for the ban, says the key is to treat smokers with compassion while safeguarding the health of non-smoking passengers. Airlines have been making some preparations for the change. Sara Dornacker, a United Airlines spokeswoman in Chicago, said the airline has agreed to make refunds or accommodations for smokers unable to handle long hours on smoke-free planes. By switching direct flights to flights with interim stops, they can dash into an airport terminal for a quick cigarette. Since Feb. 15, all United arrival announcements have mentioned the new policy, while information and entertainment guides in seat pockets also spell out the change. At Trans World Airlines in St. Louis, spokesman Jim Faulkner said pre-boarding announcements since Feb. 14 have included news of the ban. Calls to travel agencies last week indicated no passenger complaints about the new system.

DOC.HEAD: Sisulu, Mandela to Preach Peace Between Warring Black Groups
DOC.TEXT: A top official in the country's leading anti-apartheid group said Saturday that fighting with other black factions is huring efforts to end white rule. The official, Walter Sisulu, said newly freed ANC leader Nelson Mandela would join him at a rally Sunday in Natal province to plead for peace among warring factions. More than 2,500 blacks have died since 1986 in fighting among supporters of the African National Congress _ or ANC _ members of the Inkatha political party of Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi and various criminal gangs. Sisulu, who is leading the ANC peace delegation into the Zulu townships around Durban and Pietermaritzburg, said Saturday he would brief Mandela before the mass rally in an open sports field. ``I will leave him in no doubt as to the need to call for an end to the violence,'' said Sisulu. ``We have a gigantic task in leading a liberation movement. This distasteful violence, which has caused so much trouble and pain to our people, is a great obstacle to our cause in many ways.'' Nine blacks, the youngest age 12, were buried Saturday in the eastern Cape province town of Uitenhage as the result of factional fighting over the past two weeks between ANC supporters and supporters of the Pan-Africanist Movement. That movement opposes negotiations with the white government and participation of whites in the struggle to end apartheid. The ANC has said it will send a delegation to talk with officials of the white government. Raymond Mhlaba, a Mandela co-defendant freed from a life prison term in October along with Sisulu, signed a peace pact in Uitenhage last week designed to end the fighting. Funeral speakers urged the community to put the pact into effect. At the Durban news conference Saturday, Sisulu said the ANC is glad that Inkatha leaders had urged their supporters to attend the Sunday rally to welcome Mandela. The two major groups fighting for political supremacy in the Natal townships have always had separate rallies, and violence usually follows when the crowds head home through the opposite camp's neighborhoods. Organizers said they expected 175,000 to 200,000 people at the rally Sunday. Buthelezi reportedly did not plan to attend. He was a friend of Mandela's before the founder of the ANC guerrilla wing went to prison in 1962 for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Buthelezi consistently called for Mandela's release from prison during the next 27 years until he was freed early this month. However, Buthelezi opposes sanctions and guerrilla attacks, which the ANC uses. He has also accused the ANC of using its radio broadcasts to call for his death and the murder of other Inkatha leaders. Exiled ANC leaders accuse Buthelezi of collaborating with apartheid by heading the Zulu tribal government. By law and custom, apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Panel Hits Some Insurance Industry Practices
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT Paramus, N.Y. to Paramus, N.J.
DOC.TEXT: The same fraud, self-dealing, rapid growth, accounting gimmicks and lax regulation that forced a $166 billion federal bailout of savings and loans last year also threatens the insurance industry, a House panel has concluded. The Energy and Commerce Committee's investigative panel said in a report Saturday that the cost of liquidating and paying off the claims of failed insurance companies now reaches into billions of dollars. While there is no evidence yet of an insurance crisis comparable to the S&L debacle, the subcommittee said, `the same early warnings of potential disaster are abundantly evident, as they were five years ago in the thrift industry.'' In a 76-page report, the panel said its inquiries into both insurance and thrift enterprises show that ``a relatively few crooks, scoundrels and incompetents are capable of bankrupting huge companies, and possibly an entire industry.'' The subcommittee spent 18 months investigating four insurance companies _ now insolvent _ with unpaid claims or other liabilities totaling more than $5 billion, and the near failure of two other companies. It attributed their problems to rapid expansion, extensive and complex re-insurance arrangements, underpricing of premiums for remote but expensive risks, false reports, reckless management, lack of adequate reserves, fraud and self-dealing. ``Ultimately, the public bears the burden through higher insurance premiums or insurance claims that aren't paid,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of both the investigations panel and its parent committee. ``In some cases, the taxpayer may have to replenish the guaranteed funds.'' The four failed companies cited in the report are Mission Insurance Co. and Transit Casualty Co., both of Los Angeles; Integrity Insurance Co. of Paramus, N.J., and Anglo-American Insurance Co. of Dallas. All four companies were engaged primarily in commercial property-casualty insurance, a highly competitive $477 billion segment of an industry with assets totaling $1.75 trillion. ``The driving force was quick profits in the short run, with no apparent concern for the long-term well-being of the company, its policyholders, its employees, its re-insurors or the public,'' the subcommittee said. It found that none of the officials responsible for running the four failed companies has been prosecuted or even cited by state insurance agencies responsible for regulating the industry. State regulators, the subcommittee said, appear bogged down by jurisdictional restraints, unreliable information, limited penalties they can impose and an unwillingness to pursue wrondoers. It said there is a ``shocking reluctance'' in some states to deny or withdraw an insurance license unless a person has a legally proven record of criminal fraud. ``As a result, there is not meaningful deterrent to dissuade those who are inclined or tempted to plunder insurance companies,'' the report said. With inadequate reserves, some of the companies were using premiums from new policies to pay incoming claims ``in the well-known Ponzi scheme pattern,'' the subcommittee said. The report stopped short of recommending a federal takeover of insurance regulation, a function that was delegated exclusively to state governments under the 1945 McCarran-Ferguson Act. ``But current problems could give rise to reconsidering that delegation,'' it said. Possible federal intervention could include a law empowering national associations of state regulators of insurance companies to develop and enforce adequate solvency standards. ``Particularly in the aftermath of the savings and loan catastrophe, Congress must make certain that all insurers are financially able to pay claims,'' said Rep. Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, the subcommittee's ranking Republican. Dingell said the panel would hold two hearings on the report in March.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Pullout to Start Monday in Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets plan to begin withdrawing their 73,500 soldiers and thousands of tanks and armored vehicles from Czechoslovakia on Monday. The chief of Soviet forces in Czechoslovakia said Saturday that 1,220 Red Army tanks and 2,505 armored vehicles will be withdrawn as part of the pullout. Gen. Eduard Vorobjev released the new details of the program to reporters at the headquarters of Soviet troops, about 20 miles northeast of Prague. Vorobjev also said 77 combat planes and 146 helicopters would be withdrawn during the three phases of the pullout, scheduled to end by 1991. The first phase starts Monday in Frenstat pod Radhostem, 110 miles southeast of Prague, and in Krnov, on the Czechoslovak-Polish border 150 miles east of Prague. The Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia were left by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion in 1968 to suppress attempts at political reform. However, following Eastern Europe's reforms and Soviet moves to reduce its overall troop strength, Soviet and Czechoslovak negotiators agreed Thursday on a total withdrawal from Czechoslovakia. Hungary is also negotiating for a complete pullout of Soviet troops from its territiory.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Rumors Link Animal Rights Activists to Dean's Killing
DOC.TEXT: Police nationwide were alerted last week to rumors that militant animal rights activists might be planning to kill a veterinarian school dean each month for a year, authorities said. Homicide Detective Lt. Larry Johnson of the Knox County sheriff's office, lead investigator in the Feb. 8 ambush slaying of University of Tennessee veterinary school dean Dr. Hyram Kitchen, said the information was released as a precaution only. ``We just put out third-hand information,'' Johnson said. ``We put it out for only one reason: we didn't want to sit on anything.'' Kitchen, 57, was gunned down outside his home in north Knox County as he was leaving for a work-related breakfast meeting. He was shot eight times with a .22-caliber revolver, twice in the back of the head. The alert was sent nationwide Wednesday on the National Crime Information Center computer to law enforcement agencies with veterinary schools in their districts, Johnson said. ``Everything in it was unconfirmed,'' he said. ``It was a `for-what-it's-worth' teletype based on second-, third- and fourth-hand information. He described the information as ``gossip that's come back to us.'' He said investigators have no reason to think animal rights activists are responsible for Kitchen's murder. Police have no motive nor suspects in the shooting. ``With high-profile people like Dr. Kitchen, there could possibly be a dozen motives,'' Johnson said. ``If they did it, they probably would say so,'' he said, referring to animal rights activists.

DOC.HEAD: Diver Killed In 80-Person Free-Fall
DOC.TEXT: A sky diver was knocked unconscious during an 80-person free-fall Saturday and fell to his death after another diver tried to deployt his chute but couldn't, a sky-diving company official said. Paul Williams, 40, of Kentucky, was one of the last people to jump from four planes at 15,000 feet when he collided with another diver and lost consciousness, said Susan Basse, an owner of the Palatka Paracenter. ``Another sky diver, seeing the man flailing in free fall, attempted to get to him and pull the rip cord, but was unable. To the best of our knowledge, unfortunately he never regained consciousness and died on impact,'' Ms. Basse said. Williams was part of a group divers from across the southeastern United States who joined in an 80-person formation. ``There's a pretty large concentration of sky divers. We'll never know exactly what happened, but I believe he just misjudged his distance from another sky diver,'' Ms. Basse said. ``This was an experienced jumper, in excess of 2,600 sky dives. We're talking a serious jumper who made a mistake. Unfortunately, it was a fatal mistake,'' she said. The man landed on one of the runways at Kay Larkin Airport, about a half-mile from a crowd of friends and relatives who had come to see the jump. Ms. Basse said several of Williams' friends from Kentucky but no family members were there. Most of the other divers in the jump continued to join hands and legs and landed safely after breaking the formation at 4,500 feet. They probably were unaware that Williams' chutes failed to open, she said. Palatka police, who are investigating the accident, identified Williams, but refused to release his hometown.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather Causes Big Highway Crashes; 19 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with four additional storm deaths. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `In Illinois...
DOC.TEXT: Heavy, blowing snow created a driver's nightmare in the Midwest Saturday, contributing to as many as 19 traffic deaths, as a rush of cold air ended several weeks of unseasonably mild weather from the Great Lakes to New England. In the flood-weary South, more homes were inundated in southern Mississippi as flood crests moved downstream toward the Gulf of Mexico. Chain-reaction crashes and other traffic accidents in bad weather killed 13 people in Ohio, nine of them in one pileup on Interstate 75; three in Illinois; and one each in Michigan, Indiana and Kentucky. Two people were killed in a snowstorm Friday in New York state. Airline travel to and from Chicago was slowed, with delays of up to two hours, as wind above 50 mph forced officials to close four of six runways at O'Hare International Airport for a time, said Lisa Howard, spokeswoman for the Chicago Department of Aviation. A number of flights were canceled, she said. Nine people were killed Saturday evening and 45 injured in a fiery chain-reaction crash on I-75 outside Dayton, Ohio. It involved two tractor-trailer rigs and 16 other vehicles, said Highway Patrol Cadet Robert Scott. Elsewhere in Ohio, one person was killed when a car collided with a snowplow on U.S. 33 south of Athens, one was killed in a 57-vehicle crash on I-71 in Fayette County and two were killed in a weather-related crash on I-280 outside Toledo. In Illinois, three people were killed and at least seven others injured in a 15-vehicle pileup on I-80 west of Peru, hospital officials and state police said. Sgt. Richard Ferguson of the state police said snow and ice contributed to the crash. Hundreds of vehicles were involved in chain-reaction crashes in blwoing and drifting snow in Michigan. A pileup on I-94 in Berrien County killed one person; only minor injuries were reported in three other crashes on I-94 involving at least 130 vehicles in all and in a 100-vehicle collision on I-75 north of Pontiac. In northern Kentucky, at least one person was killed and 21 others injured in a pileup on I-75 near Walton, police said. Northern Indiana got as much as a foot of snow Saturday, and blowing and drifting snow reduced visibility to near zero at times over much of the state, authorities said. Two sections of I-65 were closed, while the weather contributed to a pileup of at least 20 vehicles near Greensburg. ``We're recommending no travel at all today in the state of Indiana. It's just extremely bad,'' said Indiana state police Sgt. Tom Goble. ``We've had a lot of people just drive off the road because they can't see where they're going.'' Wind-driven snow also caused hazardous conditions in southwestern Ohio. ``You top a rise where the wind's whipping across the field and all of a sudden you're looking at a patch of ice and snow two to three inches thick,'' said Earl Francis, spokesman for the Ohio Department of Transportation. Wind blew at 25 to 35 mph across Ohio, with higher gusts, and forecasters said the wind chill effect was expected to hit 20 to 30 below zero early Sunday. In Michigan, overnight lows were forecast at zero in Detroit and as low as 21 below zero in extreme northern Michigan. Overnight lows into Monday morning were expected to range from zero to 5 above over most of New York state, with temperatures dipping below zero in the Adirondack Mountains. New York City had a record high of 62 on Friday; Saturday morning, snow fell and the temperature was in the low 30s. The cold came too late to halt flooding in northern Ohio, where about 20 homes in a low-lying area of Toledo were flooded early Saturday by rain-swollen Swan Creek. Authorities said the area floods periodically, but usually in spring, rather than in late February. In Mississippi, flooding that has plagued the South for a week continued with new flooding in the southeastern part of the state as swollen rivers drained toward the Gulf of Mexico. Water began seeping into homes in Jackson County early Saturday and officials warned dozens more homeowners to prepare for high water from the Pascagoula River. ``When we went to bed it was right at the bottom of the back door, so we knew it was coming in,'' Harold Morris, who lives in the River Bend area of Escatawpa, Miss., said early Saturday. ``We got a couple of inches downstairs.'' In Alabama, the National Weather Service said rivers were receding Saturday. The Coosa River had dropped to two feet above flood stage at Gadsden and Childersburg and was below flood stage near Montgomery.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Malcolm Forbes Dies at 70
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with further details of discovery of Forbes body. Picks up 4th graf pvs: `Often seen ...' SUBS 14th graf, `Forbes was ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Forbes magazine's competitive position and advancement through '80s and to DELETE that Forbes was first to fly in balloon across U.S. Picks up 15th graf pvs: `Miss Taylor ....
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY33,35,36,39,41
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm Forbes, colorful owner of the business magazine that bears his name and an unabashed salesman for capitalism, died of a heart attack at his home Saturday. He was 70. He was pronounced dead of a heart attack at 4:30 p.m. at Timberfield, his home in Far Hills, N.J., where he died in his sleep, said William Donald Garson, director of corporate communications for New York-based Forbes Inc. He was found by a houseman after failing to keep a doctor's appointment, Garson said. Forbes, whose frequent forays on Harley-Davidson motorcycles and hot-air balloons made him a symbol of capitalist machismo, had returned Saturday morning from a trip to London. Often seen with longtime friend Elizabeth Taylor, Forbes appeared in newspaper celebrity columns as often as on their business pages. ``Forbes was the Babe Ruth of business publishing,'' said George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the New York Yankees. ``He made his mark through integrity, a toughness and wonderful sense of humor. We'll miss him.'' Billionaire developer Donald Trump expressed shock at the death of his friend. ``Malcolm was an extraordinarily positive force in America's business and social life. His loss takes excitement, creativity and genuine business leadership from every American businessman,'' Trump said. Lee Iacocca, chairman of Chrysler Corp., said: ``Malcolm Forbes was someone who lived life to its fullest and in doing so made all of our lives a little more colorful. He was a great businessman, publisher and collector, but more importantly, a great friend to many. We will miss him deeply.'' In Los Angeles, industrialist Armand Hammer released a statement saying: ``The whole world will miss Malcolm, who brought humanity to the capitalist system.'' Forbes spent a reported $2 million on his 70th birthday party Aug. 19. He was proclaimed an honorary citizen of Tangier as that Moroccan bash _ which included seaside fireworks and nightlong dancing _ drew to a close on Aug. 21. The nearly 1,000 guests featured some of the top names in business, industry, entertainment and the arts. They feasted on pigeon pie, lamb mechoui and chicken tadjine. Chairman and chief shareholder of Forbes Inc., Forbes's worth has been estimated at $400 million up to $1 billion by various sources. Experts value his company's flagship business magazine as high as $600 million, while its American Heritage magazine, suburban newspaper, real estate and art holdings almost add $100 million or more. Forbes magazine rode the 1980s bull market and the pro-business Reagan era to the greatest success since its founding by Forbes' father. Since 1979, the amount of advertising space sold surged 50 percent while rates rose sharply, as biweekly Forbes pulled ahead of Fortune in ad space and gained ground on Business Week, which publishes more often than its two main competitors. According to Publishers Information Bureau reports, all three big business magazines will post record ad revenue this year. Forbes made the first free flight over Beijing in a hot-air balloon and set six world ballooning records. He rode his Harleys in numerous charity events, and made the first motorcycle tour of China. Miss Taylor had been his frequent companion since his 39-year marriage ended in divorce in 1985. His ex-wife, the former Roberta Laidlaw, spends much of her time at her Wyoming ranch and plays no role in the Forbes business. On Dec. 31, a Los Angeles Times story reported that Forbes' son, Steve, would inherit 51 percent of the voting control of the Forbes empire. But along with that, the son might also inherit a potential tax nightmare, the paper reported. State and federal taxes on big estates are levied at about 55 percent and the 1987 tax reform closed loopholes that had eased the burden on family businesses. The estate tax threat has shadowed Forbes Inc. through its best years, since Forbes magazine's big increase in value came relatively late in Malcolm's life. While Forbes family members declined to discuss with the Times their estate tax plans in detail, it is clear that their business strategy had been constrained by the prospect of a tax bill that could exceed $300 million. Forbes was born in Englewood, N.J., on Aug. 19, 1919, two years after his father founded the magazine. He was the third child of five born to B.C. ``Bertie'' and Adelaide Forbes. His father, named after Prince Albert of Great Britain, was the son of a poor Scottish family who emigrated to the United States and worked his way to affluence on Wall Street. In 1941, the newly graduated Malcolm Forbes was appointed publisher of a weekly newspaper in Lancaster, Ohio, and within a year had founded a second paper. But in 1942, he entered the Army as a private. During service in Europe, Forbes fought as a staff sergeant commanding a machine-gun unit and eventually won the Bronze Star and a Purple Heart for saving the lives of many of his company. Forbes was shot in the thigh and spent 10 months in 1944-45 recovering. Following the war, Forbes joined his father's magazine as a vice president with a broad mandate to modernize the journal's design and layout. Forbes entered politics in 1949 by gaining a seat on the Borough Council in Bernardsville, N.J. He served in the state Senate from 1951 to 1957 and ran for governor of New Jersey in 1957 on the Republican ticket, with a ``No state income tax, no state sales tax'' platform. He lost Robert B. Meyner. At 38, having lost his bid for the Statehouse, Forbes took over as editor-in-chief of the magazine. He also was the author of seven books, including ``They Went That-a-way'' which spent five weeks on the best-seller list. In addition to his former wife, Roberta, survivors include sons Malcolm ``Steve'' Jr., Robert, Christopher and Timothy, a daughter, Moira Mumma, a brother, Wallace and eight grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to 16 Years for Nation's Worst DUI Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `Satterwhite said...serious crime,' to UPDATE with crash victim's comment; DELETES redundant 11th graf pvs, `Mahoney had...' Pick up 12th graf pvs, `Russel Baldani...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LX1
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of killing 27 people in the nation's worst drunken-driving accident was sentenced Friday to 16 years in prison. He could be eligible for parole in eight years. Carroll County Circuit Judge Charles Satterwhite denied a defense motion to place Larry Mahoney on probation, and instead imposed the sentence recommended by the jury that convicted Mahoney on Dec. 21. Satterwhite said the community would not stand for probation and that punishment must be strong for such a serious crime. One survivor of the crash, 18-year-old Tammy Darnell, said Mahoney should have been sent to prison for life. ``Sixteen years does not take the place of the friends I lost,'' she said, before breaking down in tears. Mahoney, a 36-year-old chemical plant worker, was driving the wrong direction on Interstate 71 on May 14, 1988, when he crashed into the front of a school bus packed with teen-agers on a church outing. Twenty-four teens and three adults died. He was convicted of 27 counts each of second-degree manslaughter and first-degree wanton endangerment, 12 counts of first-degree assault, 14 of second-degree wanton endangerment and one of drunken driving. The recommended sentence totaled 611 years, but the jury said the terms should run concurrently. That effectively gave Mahoney 16 years. He is classified as a violent offender under Kentucky law and must serve at least half his sentence before being considered for parole. Defense attorney William Summers urged Satterwhite to make something positive out of the bus crash tragedy. The defense recommended a probation plan under which Mahoney would have lectured to schoolchildren about the dangers of drunken driving, served volunteer time in hospital emergency wards, and spent one year in a work release program. ``Judge, we must do as much good with this as we possibly can. His punishment has already been death. He already has been given a life sentence,'' Summers said, referring to Mahoney's suffering since the crash. Prosecutor Paul Richwalsky Jr. of the state attorney general's office vehemently opposed probation. ``He alone is responsible. He alone brought us to this place today,'' Richwalsky said. ``Regardless of statements the defense would make, it's time for punishment.'' Russell Baldani, one of Mahoney's three attorneys, said earlier this week that Satterwhite's decision would be appealed. During testimony, jurors learned Mahoney was upset over financial problems brought on by expensive medical bills for his daughter, who suffers from a spinal birth defect, and that he spent most of the day of the crash visiting friends and drinking beer at several taverns. He testified that he only occasionally drank beer and abhorred hard liquor. He said he didn't remember drinking hard liquor at a party later that evening. He said he had no recollection of getting into his pickup and driving the wrong way on the interstate. The collision punctured the gas tank of the bus, sending a stream of flaming gasoline into the passenger compartment. The 27 deaths were attributed to smoke inhalation, but Mahoney's attorneys contended that toxic smoke emitted from the plastic seats had poisoned the passengers. When Mahoney took the stand, he publicly apologized for the tragedy. Richwalsky said earlier this week that he didn't expect Friday's hearing to be the last of the Mahoney case. ``It's not over and done with,'' he said. ``I'm sure there will be an appeal and so we change gears and go into another arena.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest in Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 militant students demanding the downfall of the government moved into the capital's Roman Catholic cathedral Friday and refused to leave when armed police surrounded the church. Cathedral officials asked the students to leave and promised to negotiate their safe getaway, but the protesters said they feared soldiers and police would beat them. The students, numbering about 150, chose the cathedral to win publicity for their protests. The state-run media have ignored the anti-government protests that began Monday night when students set two cars ablaze and police responded with tear gas and rubber truncheons. Several students have been injured in clashes with soldiers and police, but only a handful needed hospital treatment, the students say. There was no violence Thursday. About two dozen armed police marched through a cathedral gate and surrounded the modern building decorated with large stained glass doors and windows. But they were ordered out after a more senior officer arrived on the scene. There appeared to be a standoff later Friday, with police remaining outside the gates and students refusing to leave. Dozens of other students opposite the cathedral raised their fists at the soldiers. A few yelled what has become a rallying cry: ``We are opposed!'' President Felix Houphouet-Boigny has ruled this West African nation as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. He has refused recent calls for a multiparty system, saying it would endanger national unity. ``We don't want Houphouet, we don't want his government,'' one student protester said Friday. ``We will demonstrate until we have a multiparty state. We want freedom.'' Earlier in the day, student leaders announced formation of an independent National Organization of Students and School Children to replace another union. The existing group is in effect a youth league of the ruling Democratic Party. The students claimed they have the support of 7,000 of the 22,000 students at the state-run National University of Ivory Coast. However, demonstrations have been limited to little more than 300 students at a time. The students say the low numbers reflect cuts in bus service between the university and surrounding neighborhoods.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Nominee: Junk Bond Market Bears Watching in Wake of Drexel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS 4 grafs on congressional investigations
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission should keep tabs on the amount of junk bonds held by financial institutions in the wake of the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., an SEC nominee said Friday. Philip R. Lochner Jr., deputy general counsel of Time Warner Inc., also told a Senate panel that there might be a need for a national quotation system, such as the one used to monitor the over-the-counter stock market, to keep track of junk-bond prices. ``We absolutely do need more information on this issue,'' Lochner said at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, parent of the Wall Street investment banking house that practically created the high risk, high yield ``junk bond'' market, filed for federal bankruptcy protection earlier this month, rattling the already unstable market. Committee Chairman Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., asked Lochner if the SEC should assemble information on what kind of financial institutions _ such as banks, thrifts, mutual and pension funds _ hold junk bonds and in what amount. ``I think there's no systematic information on who holds junk debt and how long it's been held,'' Lochner said. ``I think in order to understand it better I think, yes, we absolutely do need more information.'' Riegle was the only senator present during most of the questioning of Lochner, nominated by President Bush in January to fill the unexpired term of former SEC Chairman David Ruder, who returned to teaching law at Northwestern University. Lochner expressed views similar to SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, saying that enforcement of securities laws would be a high priority for him, particularly in an attempt to restore the confidence of individual investors. Lochner also said jurisdictional disputes between the SEC and the rival Commodity Futures Trading Commission were hurting American competitiveness with overseas markets. The panel also questioned Arthur J. Hill, nominee for president of the Government National Mortgage Association, also known as Ginnie Mae, and John J. Adair, who was nominated this week as the first inspector general of the Resolution Trust Corp. The RTC was established as part of the savings and loan industry bailout legislation to dispose of failed thrifts. Riegle said the committee was expected to vote on all three nominees next Friday. The committee also has scheduled a hearing for next Friday on the downfall of Drexel, with Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden scheduled to testify. In addition, Rep. John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee has asked the SEC to supply all the information it has on hefty bonuses Drexel paid to employees before its bankruptcy filing on Feb. 13. Dingell, in his capacity as chairman of the oversight and investigations subcommittee, asked the SEC to ``provide the subcommittee with the commission's analysis of these payments in relation to violations of both the letter and spirit of the applicable provisions of the federal securities laws.'' The subcommittee also asked the SEC to deliver by March 16 ``a copy of Drexel's bankruptcy contingency plan, and copies of any minutes, transcripts or other memorializations of any board of directors meetings where any such plan was discussed or approved.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Still Some Concern Over Soviet Arms Violations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that the Soviet Union had taken ``encouraging and significant'' steps to correct violations of arms control agreements, but added that serious concerns remain. ``During the past year, there has been an encouraging change in the Soviet approach toward arms-control compliance,'' Bush said in a report to Congress. ``The Soviet Union now appears to be willing to take significant action to resolve some U.S. concerns.'' Bush said he hoped recent Soviet actions ``indicate a new willingness also to address and resolve our remaining concerns.'' While highlighting positive action, Bush said the Soviet Union still did not comply completely with the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty and the 1972 biological and toxin weapons convention. Bush noted last year's admission by the Kremlin that its massive radar complex at Krasnoyarsk was a ``clear violation'' of the ABM treaty, as the United States had long argued. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze pledged last year that the facility would be dismantled. Bush said in his report that action would ``improve the atmosphere surrounding bilateral relations,'' emphasizing that the United States will not conclude agreements on strategic or space weapons until concerns about Krasnoyarsk are resolved. Bush credited the Soviet Union with ``constructive steps'' to correct other violations of the ABM treaty even though they had not formally admitted they were not complying. On another front, Bush said the Soviet Union had admitted technical errors in complying with a 1987 treaty to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear missiles and had corrected them. ``During the past year,'' Bush said, ``our insistence on scrupulous complaince, together with improved cooperation by the USSR, has enabled generally successful implementation of the INF treaty, the removal of one ABM treaty violation and positive movement toward Soviet correction of the Krasnoyarsk radar violation. ``This represents encouraging and significant positive movement in arms control treaty compliance,'' the president said. In terms of chemical and biological warfare, Bush said the United States had found no basis for amending earlier conclusions that the Soviet Union was been involved in the production, transfer and use of toxins for hostile purposes in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistan. He said there was no confirmed evidence of use of lethal agents since January 1984, but said the alleged violations remained a cause for serious concern. Moreover, Bush said that contrary to Moscow's claims, ``the Soviet Union has maintained an active offensive biological warfare program and capability in violation of the 1972 biological and toxin weapons convention.'' ``We judge that the Soviet capability may include advanced biological and toxin agents of which we have little or no knowledge and, and against which the U.S. has no defense,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Cites Faulty Pump as Likely Cause of In-Air Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A faulty fuel pump apparently caused an Air Force tanker jet to explode in flight last fall, killing four crewmen, military investigators said Friday. Officials at Loring Air Force Base said they determined that there were two explosions, both in a fuel tank area in the rear of the plane, and that the tail section separated from the fuselage after the second blast. ``Post-accident analysis of the air refueling pumps recovered from the crash site indicates one of two pumps ... was a likely ignition source,'' said a statement issued by the base. The pump reached a temperature of at least 1,435 degrees before the explosion, which occurred over the Canadian town of Perth-Andover, New Brunswick, on the morning of Oct. 4. Residents of the area had reported that the explosion lit up the predawn sky and started a fire in the woods where the wreckage landed. The KC-135A plane, which was 25 years old, was a Boeing 707 reconfigured as a tanker. It was used in the midair refueling of fighters and bombers based at Loring. The Air Force, releasing the first detailed account of the events leading to the explosion, said the four-engine jet took off from Loring at 11:40 p.m. the previous night and had completed a midair refueling of two planes east of Newfoundland. It was returning to Loring, descending from 3,000 feet to 2,500 feet, when it exploded about 13 miles south-southeast of the base. The investigation turned up no discrepancies in the maintenance of the plane. The crew members were technically qualified and toxicology tests ``disclosed no evidence pertinent to the investigation,'' the investigators said.

DOC.HEAD: Spacecraft in First Saturn Flyby Exits the Solar System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Montye cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Pioneer 11, the first spacecraft to visit Saturn, flew beyond the orbit of Neptune on Friday and became the fourth human-made craft to exit the solar system, NASA and the probe's builder said. ``We wish it a fond farewell,'' said Montye Male, a spokeswoman for TRW Inc., which built Pioneer 11 at its Space & Technology Group facility in Redondo Beach. Neptune is now the outermost planet. Pluto currently is closer to the sun in an elongated, elliptical orbit, part of which is beyond Neptune's path. By crossing Neptune's orbit Friday at a distance of 2.8 billion miles from Earth, Pioneer 11 followed Pioneer 10 and Voyagers 1 and 2 out of the solar system, said Peter Waller, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center in Mountain View. Both officials acknowledged that some don't consider the orbit of the outermost planet to be the edge of the solar system. Some scientists consider the true edge to be the heliopause, where solar wind yields to interstellar wind an estimated 5 billion to 14 billion miles from the sun. A few even consider the solar system to end at the Oort Cloud, a theorized but yet-unseen spherical cloud of comets that may be located about 7 trillion to 14 trillion miles from the sun. Waller said NASA considers the Pioneers and Voyagers to be outside the solar system because _ to use a seafaring analogy _ ``once you've left land behind, you don't worry about coastal waters.'' Pioneer 11 was launched April 5, 1973, and visited Jupiter on Dec. 2, 1974, a year after Pioneer 10 flew past the solar system's largest planet. Pioneer 11 whizzed by Jupiter at 107,373 mph, which Waller said was the fastest speed ever traveled by a spacecraft. It passed only 26,600 miles from Jupiter's cloud tops _ much closer than the Voyager 1 and 2 flybys in 1979 _ and was bombarded by the planet's intense radiation belts. On Sept. 1, 1979, it became the first spacecraft to explore Saturn, visiting the ringed planet 14 months ahead of Voyager 1 and two years ahead of Voyager 2. Pioneer 10 didn't fly past Saturn. Waller said in a telephone interview that Pioneer 11 flew about 13,000 miles from Saturn, taking the first closeup pictures of that planet, discovering two small moonlets and a ring, and collecting data that scientists used to determine that the major moon, Titan, was too cold for life despite the presence of organic chemicals. Although Pioneer 11 was launched four years before the Voyagers, it took longer to fly beyond the outermost planet's orbit because it is traveling through space in the same direction as the sun and the rest of the solar system, Male said. In June 1983, Pioneer 10 became the first spacecraft to pass beyond the planets. It is now 4.5 billion miles from Earth, Male said. In three years, it will become difficult to simultaneously operate Pioneer 11's radio transmitter and scientific instruments, although engineers may be able to get the spacecraft to send back data on solar wind until 1995, project manager Richard Fimmel said. Pioneer 10, with a stronger power supply, may return information through the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Governor's Press Secretary Resigns Over Lewd Remark
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Madeleine Kunin's press secretary resigned Friday for making a lewd comment to a reporter. ``I deeply regret the fact that I failed to perform according to the standards required,'' Peter Freyne wrote in his letter of resignation to the governor. The resignation came two days after Kunin suspended Freyne without pay for two weeks and three days after Freyne made the comment, which he said was a joke. The remark was made to Betsy Liley, a reporter for The Burlington Free Press, who asked him for a preview of the governor's revenue forecast. Freyne replied, ``If you took off all your clothes and (performed a lewd act) I might tell you.'' He paused, then added: ``Even if you did that, I wouldn't tell you.'' On Tuesday, Kunin called the remark ``totally inappropriate,'' adding that it was sexist but she didn't consider Freyne to be sexist. She issued a statement Friday saying she accepted Freyne's resignation with sadness and regret. ``Peter has made the right decision,'' Kunin said. ``Despite his deep remorse, he has recognized that he has lost his capacity to be a spokesman for me.''

DOC.HEAD: 18-Year-Old Guilty in Killing Woman Who was Decapitated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of strangling and decapitating his brother's girlfriend was convicted of murder Friday after witnesses described the 18-year-old defendant singing rap songs about the killing. Ruben Deases was found guilty in the May 28 murder of Jennifer Ann Gardner, 20, capping a trial that at one point erupted into a scuffle between brothers. Defense attorney Glenn Sedgwick put his arm around Deases as the verdict was read. Deases showed little emotion at the verdict, which the jury reached after about two hours and 15 minutes of deliberations. In Iowa, a conviction on first-degree murder carries a mandatory life sentence with no possiblity of parole unless a governor commutes the sentence to a set term. The state's key witness was Deases' 16-year-old brother, Johnny, who testified about the killing and said Ruben had sex with the corpse afterward. A third brother, Edward, 21, awaits trial on murder charges. The woman shared an Ames apartment with the eldest of the four brothers, Eustaquio Deases, 23, who was out of town at the time of the killing took place in the apartment. Prosecutors said she died because of the younger brothers saw her as an impediment to their advancement in Eustaquio's cocaine-dealing business, and witnesses said it took place soon after she threatened the younger brothers with a gun. Eustaquio is serving a five-year federal sentence for cocaine possession. Four youth workers testified that Ruben bragged about the killing after his arrest and even made up rap songs about it. One such song included the lines, ``She thought she was cool, and I was a fool. And now she's dead and I'm ahead,'' said Jack Leinen, a former youth services worker at a Des Moines detention center where Ruben was held. Judge M.D. Seiser had told jurors they could return a verdict of innocent or of guilty to charges of first-degree murder, second-degree murder or voluntary manslaughter. No sentencing date was sent. Ms. Gardner's head was found in a ditch along a gravel road south of Ames on May 29, and her body was found June 1 in a lake north of Ames. Defense lawyer Stephen Terrill said he would appeal. As Eustaquio was led into the courtroom last week to testify for the prosecution, he lunged across the defense table, throwing punches and snarling obscenities at Ruben. Terrill had portrayed Ruben Deases as a frightened little boy who didn't take part in the killing or the decapitation. ``I'm afraid that Ruben Deases may end up paying for a crime he did not commit _ a terrible crime that his brother Edward committed,'' Terrill told jurors in his closing arguments Thursday. But County Attorney Mary Richards had called Ruben ``a cold-blooded killer'' and told jurors that ``reading at a fifth-grade level is no excuse for committing murder.''

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Join Social Democatic Party Convention
With AM-Germany Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German opposition leaders joined the East German Social Democrats at their convention Friday to criticize the policies of Helmut Kohl, the West German chancellor. The convention chose Ibrahim Boehme, a 45-year-old historian, to be the party's chairman and lead it in East Germany's first free elections March 18. The Social Democrats are favored to win the elections and Boehme could be the next premier of East Germany, which was ruled by Communists from the Stalinist mold until a few months ago. Several recent polls have indicated the Social Democrats would win at least 50 percent of the vote. As the convention began in the industrial city of Leipzig, former Chancellor Willy Brandt started his weekend of East German campaigning with a rally in Plauen, a southern city. He told an audience of 40,000: ``As Germans and as Europeans, we must cooperate in securing world peace.'' West German politicians, including Kohl, have taken advantage of the election campaign to speak at rallies across the country, despite misgivings by the Communist-led interim government. While lending support to sister parties in East Germany, the West Germans also are seeking to establish power bases before reunification. Speakers from West Germany often have overshadowed East German party leaders, making some campaign rallies seem like forums on West German political issues. Earlier this week, Kohl addressed a rally of 100,000 in Erfurt and received a more enthusiastic reception that he usually gets back home. National elections in West Germany are scheduled for December, and with the movement toward reunification gaining speed, some West German politicians think it could become an all-German ballot. The left-leaning Social Democrats of West Germany accuse Kohl of rushing into unification in hopes of boosting his re-election chances by becoming the chancellor who reunites Germany. They want one Germany, but favor what they describe as a more cautious pace in accomplishing it. Their East German sister party is a strong advocate of reunification. Included in the West German delegation to the convention of East German Social Democrats on Friday was Oskar Lafontaine, the Saarland state governor who is expected to be the party's challenger to Kohl in December. Brandt, who is very popular in East Germany, also will speak at the Leipzig convention, which continues through Sunday. He is to be made honorary chairman of the East German Social Democrats, the same title he has in West Germany. Lafontaine's convention speech criticized Kohl for not giving billions of dollars in immediate aid. East Germany requested $9 billion, but Kohl balked at providing it to a Communist-led interim government. West Germany did provide the equivalent of about $3.5 billion, most of it for projects over which the East German government would have little control. Speaking to about 500 delegates, Lafontaine said Kohl's decision was a ``blow to Germany unity.'' He also criticized Kohl for calling 1989 the ``year of the Germans.'' It was much more a year of ``freedom and liberation of the people of Eastern Europe,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Secret Service Agents Slightly Wounded in Counterfeit Raid
DOC.TEXT: Two Secret Service agents were slightly wounded and an alleged counterfeit money dealer was badly injured during a raid that netted nearly $500,000 in bogus bills, officials said Friday. Details were kept secret of the undercover investigation that erupted in gunfire Thursday night, but the Secret Service confirmed two of its agents suffered minor gunshot wounds in the raid at a Los Angeles County residence. The identities of the agents were not released. Dick Griffin, special agent in charge of the Secret Service office in Los Angeles, said one was a 37-year-old man and the other a 30-year-old woman. Also injured was Ignacio Padilla, 44, who suffered chest and hip wounds and was in critical condition Friday at Martin Luther King Jr.-Drew Medical Center, county sheriff's Deputy Van Mosely said. Padilla lives in Los Angeles, Mosely said. A second man, Oliveros Orosco, 26, also of Los Angeles was not harmed. He was arrested for investigation of attempted murder, Mosely said. Griffin said the probe comes amid an extraordinary concentration of counterfeiting activities in Los Angeles. ``At this point they were just people who came to our attention as dealers,'' he said. ``In the overall scheme of things ... counterfeiting in Los Angeles has been something that we've experienced quite a bit of in the last two years.'' It was not clear who fired the shots that wounded the three. One agent suffered a superficial leg wound and was treated and released from a hospital Thursday night, said Griffin. The other agent suffered broken bones and some nerve damage to a foot and remained hospitalized. Griffin said the undercover agents, backed up by an unspecified number of other agents and Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies, were negotiating with the men to purchase about $485,000 in counterfeit $50 bills. At a ``key point'' in the negotiations, a decision was made to arrest the two men, Griffin said. All of the bills were seized, Griffin said.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky and The Raven
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT quote to `as of,' sted `as if.'
DOC.TEXT: ``Suddenly there came a tapping, as of someone gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door.'' Yo. Edgar Allan Poe, meet Sylvester Stallone. Stallone took a detour during filming of ``Rocky V'' to visit the Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site, a house where the poet and short-story writer lived for two years. Park ranger Joelle Wagner said Thursday she answered a knock at the locked front door Feb. 12 to find the creator of movie hero Rocky Balboa on the doorstep with co-star Talia Shire and a bodyguard. ``I was flabbergasted,'' she said. ``I had to take a few moments to compose myself.'' As the group toured the three-story structure, one of four houses Poe rented while living in Philadelphia from 1838 to 1844, Stallone told Ms. Wagner he had written a movie script about the author of the poem ``The Raven.'' ``He's just in awe of Poe,'' Ms. Wagner said. ``He said he really admired him.'' Stallone, the lead in such action movies as ``Rambo'' and ``Tango and Cash,'' did not say if he wanted to portray Poe, she said. Ms. Wagner said the trio viewed the park's slide show, which describes Poe's life from his childhood in Richmond, Va., his time at West Point and his literary life in Philadelphia, where he was most successful as a poet, short-story writer, literary critic and editor. Poe died in 1849 in Baltimore as he was traveling to New York. Stories at the time said he collapsed in the street of an alcohol or drug overdose. While touring the house, Stallone discussed Poe's life and literary works with his friends, according to Ms. Wagner. ``There wasn't much I could tell him'' about Poe, the park ranger said. She said Stallone bought a book on the writer. Movie publicist Dave Fulton said Stallone wrote the script because he believes the writer ``gets within the soul'' of people and poetry. ``He's a big fan,'' Fulton said. Poe also wrote ``The Fall of the House of Usher,'' ``The Black Cat,'' and ``The Murders of the Rue Morgue,'' which established the mystery or detective short-story form.

DOC.HEAD: Former Florida Governor Switches Back to GOP to Run Again
DOC.TEXT: A former Florida governor announced Friday he has switched back to the Republican Party after a stint as a Democrat to challenge Gov. Bob Martinez in the September GOP primary. ``The opportunity is there,'' said Claude R. Kirk Jr., who was governor from 1967 to 1971, the first Republican since Reconstruction to win the office in Florida. Kirk, 64, who once vetoed his own budget, lost his re-election bid in 1970. His ability to attract votes virtually disappeared after he was turned out of office by Democrat Reubin Askew. Kirk mounted another ill-fated gubernatorial bid as a Democrat in 1978 when he and running mate Mary Singleton finished sixth in a field of seven. Two years ago, Kirk came in fifth in a six-way race for U.S. Senate. In addition to Kirk and Martinez, state Sen. Marlene Woodson-Howard of Bradenton and Fort Lauderdale resident Anthony Martin are seeking the GOP nomination. Gainesville businessman Ben Campen said Thursday he will probably enter the race next week. ``A primary against Bob Martinez is a farce,'' said J.M. Stipanovich, the governor's campaign manager. ``They're wasting their time, their money and their effort.'' Kirk and Martinez are Florida's only two Republican governors this century. Both won office when the Democratic Party was fractured by bitter primary battles. Kirk, accompanied by his daughter Claudia and former state GOP chairman Tommy Thomas, said he hoped to raise $1.3 million for his primary challenge. ``Anything more than that is obscene,'' said Kirk, who dismissed his most recent party change as insignificant. ``The voters of Florida realize that the party I'm involved in is a Kirk party as such, philosophically.'' Kirk generally refrained from political attacks on Martinez, telling reporters he'd unveil his campaign stands later.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Disaster Agency Agrees to Quake Housing Lawsuit Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th, `The lawsuit...,' to UPDATE with comment from Legal Aid Society.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. disaster relief officials agreed in a court settlement Friday to provide tens of millions of dollars to replace residential hotel rooms and other cheap housing destroyed in the San Francisco earthquake. The settlement, which could cost the Federal Emergency Management Agency up to $50 million, came in a civil lawsuit filed Jan. 19 in U.S. District Court to obtain assistance for low-income people who were displaced by the Oct. 17 quake. It is the first time FEMA has provided money to renovate residential hotels damaged in a disaster, said Lorrie Jean, deputy director and general counsel for FEMA. ``We've done this because we're basically learning how to respond to the unique needs of presidentially declared emergencies in urban areas,'' Ms. Jean told reporters. The lawsuit was filed by at least four public interest agencies, including the Legal Aid Society of Alameda County. The agencies said at least 5,000 people were left homeless because their hotel rooms were damaged by the quake. Stephen E. Ronfeldt of the Legal Aid Society said the agencies agreed to settle the lawsuit because they were happy with how much FEMA was willing to bend its policies to help poor people affected by the quake. The settlement was tentatively approved by U.S. District Judge Eugene Lynch, who set a March 16 hearing for final approval. It requires FEMA funds to cover about 1,800 hotel units and other inexpensive housing affected, and calls for FEMA to provide money for short-term housing assistance while replacement units are found. Under the settlement, housing units can be replaced by rehabilitation or through rent vouchers to owners of renovated apartment buildings. Construction of new units is not allowed. Tens of thousands of other people also could be affected by the settlement because it calls for FEMA reimbursement checks to go to individuals who were sharing housing with non-relatives. The agency had previously decided to issue one check per shared housing unit that was damaged in the quake.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Could Use Steel Mills to Build Maglev Trains, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Business, labor and government leaders said Friday they hope to establish Pittsburgh as a major equipment supplier for a levitated train system that could transport passengers at up to 300 mph. The magnetic levitation train _ nicknamed ``maglev'' _ could create jobs well into the 21st century by using the city's idled steel mills to build the new technology, according to a report released by members of Maglev Inc., ``What we want to do in the Pittsburgh area is become a technological and manufacturing base for magnetic levitation in the United States,'' said advertising executive James Roddey, former chairman of Port Authority Transit of Allegheny County and acting president of Maglev Inc. Maglev was formed to develop a 19-mile demonstration project linking downtown Pittsburgh to Greater Pittsburgh International Airport. The train, which has no wheels, hovers on a magnetic cushion over an elevated guideway. Car sides wrap around a guide rail. Maglev appears to be the best high-speed ground transportation based on cost, environmental impact, speed, comfort and readiness, Roddey said. The group believes magnetic levitation eventually will become the transportation method of choice for trips ranging from 150 to 300 miles in the United States, Roddey said. Electromagnetic train technology was devised in the United States in 1968 but perfected in Germany. The group has just completed a preliminary study of the feasibility of the the future of magnetic levitation in Pittsburgh and now is trying to raise $2.1 million for a more detailed study, Roddey said. ``We're now in the next phase to determine whether or not it's financially possible or whether or not we can become a manufacturing center,'' he said. The 12 members of Maglev Inc. have agreed to invest $900,000 and staffing for the study, which will take 2{ years to finish. An additional $300,000 will come from the state, Roddey said. The Maglev Promotion Council, a Japanese trading company, has committed about $250,000, he said, and the company is applying for $1.2 million from federal officials. The 19-mile link to the airport could be completed as early as 1996, Roddey said. It would cost $299 million to $648 million to design and build, depending on which route to the airport is selected and whether a single- or double-track system is built. Maglev Inc.'s 12 members are AGE Westinghouse Transportation Systems Inc., Allegheny County, the city of Pittsburgh, USX Corp., Carnegie Mellon University, Duquesne Light Co., the Michael Baker Corp., the law firm of Reed Smith Shaw & McClay, the Tri-State Conference on Steel, United Steelworkers of America, Union Switch & Signal and Transrapid International. Maglev Inc. officials said they are close to reaching an agreement for the exclusive maglev manufacturing rights in North America with Transrapid, a German consortium that has worked on the train's technology. The study estimates the project would generate $96 billion in economic activity in the region if Maglev Inc. is awarded manufacturing rights.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Return Girl to Respirator, Downgrade Condition
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl who underwent the world's first heart-liver transplant was placed back on a respirator Friday when fluid collected in her lungs following a second liver transplant. Stormie Jones, who received her second transplanted liver Tuesday, was in critical condition Friday, a deterioration from her previous condition of critical but stable, said Children's Hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon. ``We're not talking about a very serious setback here,'' Ms. McMahon said. ``Complications like this are not uncommon with transplant patients.'' The girl from the Fort Worth, Texas, suburb White Settlement likely will breathe with the aid of the respirator for several days, the spokeswoman said. Stormie, who suffers from a rare condition that makes her cholesterol level 10 times the normal level, got her first transplant in 1984. The donor heart remains healthy but a second liver transplant was needed because of liver damage from hepatitis.

DOC.HEAD: Dangerous Ether Had Already Been Removed from Elementary School
DOC.TEXT: Officials who closed two elementary schools for fear that potentially explosive ether was stored in the basements said Friday they later discovered the chemical had been removed in 1974. Students were sent home Tuesday so explosives experts could remove crates containing Cold War-era ``packaged disaster hospitals,'' which, according to their labels, included ether. The crates, dating from about 30 years ago, were meant for use in a national emergency. Experts, however, found that the crates no longer contained ether, said Roger Winner, a member of the Gasport Fire Department Board of Commissioners and a former state Emergency Management officer. ``The crates were opened. The ether had been removed,'' Winner said. ``There were other ... mechanical items _ part of the operating room equipment _ that were in these crates.'' Some kinds of ether under certain conditions can have the explosive potential of nitroglycerin. Officials said the ether apparently was removed in 1974, when a directive to Niagara County emergency officials warned of the potential danger. Nonetheless, officials Friday defended the decision to send home 500 students from Gasport Elementary School and 470 students from another elementary school in the nearby community of Middleport. ``It was not blown out of proportion,'' said Margaret Chong, the on-scene representative of the federal Environmental Protection Agency. ``There was no indication at the time that there was nothing in the box. No labeling, no information at all.''

More than a decade after it became the first spacecraft to visit Saturn, Pioneer 11 flew beyond Neptune's orbit and out of the solar system, according to NASA and the company that built the probe. ``Pioneer 11 is following in the historic footsteps of Pioneer 10, one of the spacecraft we are proudest of,'' TRW Inc. spokeswoman Montye Male said Friday as the probe passed the milestone 2.8 billion miles from Earth. ``We wish it a fond farewell.'' Neptune is now the outermost planet. Pluto currently is closer to the sun in an elongated, elliptical orbit, part of which extends beyond Neptune's path. By crossing Neptune's orbit, Pioneer 11 became the fourth spacecraft to leave the solar system, said Peter Waller, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center in Mountain View.

Jesse Jackson, facing signs city voters are wary that he will run for mayor in the wake of Mayor Marion Barry's drug arrest, has told supporters he won't seek Barry's job, associates say. ``He's not going to run for mayor of Washington. We talked about it yesterday,'' Joel Ferguson, who managed Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign in Michigan, told a Lansing, Mich., television station Friday. Jackson, a two-time Democratic presidential contender, was en route to Chicago on Friday evening. There was no answer at his Chicago home. Jackson's political plans have been the subject of speculation since he moved to the nation's capital in April. That speculation intensified with Barry's arrest last month on a cocaine possession charge.

A man convicted of killing 27 people in the nation's worst drunken-driving accident was sentenced to 16 years in prison, but one crash survivor said he should have been sent to jail for life. ``Sixteen years does not take the place of the friends I lost,'' said Tammy Darnell, breaking down in tears after Larry Mahoney was sentenced on Friday. Mahoney was quiet during the sentencing, but many of his relatives burst into tears. His 7-year-old daughter, Shawna, a victim of spina bifida, began wailing after the sentence was read. Mahoney, 36, can be eligible for parole in eight years.

An Army deserter who believes he ``threw 30 years of my life away'' by fleeing to East Germany in 1959 said the changes in the United States have left him slack-jawed with amazement. Arnold Kephart, 53, who fled to East Germany fearing punishment after wrecking an Army truck, said adjustment to U.S. society has made him feel a bit like a latter-day Rip van Winkle. ``The first time I saw one of those,'' Kephart said, pointing to a microwave oven, ``I thought it was a TV. Then someone came along, opened it up, and put food in. I couldn't believe he was putting food in the TV.'' In an interview Friday at the home of his brother-in-law, Arlo Dunbar, Kephart said he regretted his decision to enter East Germany only a few weeks after settling in Schmalkalind, he town where he lived for 30 years.

DOC.HEAD: adv26
DOC.NOTE: For Release Monday, Feb. 26
DOC.HEAD: IBM Stock Price Climbs as Computer Giant's Prospects Brighten
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: IBM's stock has climbed since December, and analysts say the world's largest computer maker is beginning to see the benefits of a cost-cutting program and stock buyback. The stock, which was down to about $94 a share in late December, moved back into triple digits in recent weeks and was trading around $103 late last week. Many analysts consider International Business Machines Corp. shares a strong investment and say the company is bouncing back from a multiyear slump. Rick Martin, who follows IBM for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., recently upgraded his recommendation for IBM stock from ``hold'' to ``buy.'' Martin said his recommendation was based in part on the new line of computer workstations IBM unveiled earlier this month. The machines, aimed at the engineering and scientific markets, won rave reviews from experts for their performance and relatively low prices. Analysts say they are an important introduction in a segment of the computer business in which IBM never has done well. ``We have postulated that IBM has only two ways out of its malaise: It could either accept low growth and make massive cutbacks in expenses or it could get more aggressive in products and pricing,'' Martin wrote in a recent commentary. He said the workstation announcement was a clear sign the company has chosen the latter path. ``We think the new-found aggressiveness will improve investor psychology in the near term and should lead to substantial earnings improvements for the long term,'' he wrote. John Jones, an analyst for Montgomery Securities in San Franciso, said IBM also is benefiting from a share repurchase program announced last fall. IBM said it would buy back up to $5 billion worth of its shares during an unspecified time period. Share repurchase programs usually boost a company's stock price by reducing the supply of shares. Jones said in an interview that IBM's restructuring, which involves the elimination of 10,000 jobs and consolidation of plants, also has aided the company's performance. IBM reported that its profit slipped 35 percent last year to $3.76 billion, or $6.47 a share, from $5.81 billion, $9.80 a share, in 1988. Revenue grew 5.1 percent to $62.7 billion from $59.7 billion. ``The reality is that 1989, when you adjust for non-recurring events, actually wasn't that bad a year for IBM,'' Jones said. Among the one-time charges against earnings was a pretax charge of $2.4 billion for the restructuring in the fourth quarter. He said IBM's revenue and profit overseas, where the company does more than half its business, increased markedly last year, but the impact to the bottom line was masked by an unfavorable dollar exchange rate. He said the improved performance overseas in local-currency terms ``says to the astute investor that the efforts IBM has been making for the last four years are starting to show.'' In addition, Jones said, IBM's domestic revenue grew for the first time in four years, though it only was a 2 percent increase. Jones said IBM's share price is about where it was after the October 1987 market crash. ``It is a battered stock that doesn't look like it's got a lot of downside risk,'' he said. Among the positive factors, Jones said, is that growth in the technology industry this year should exceed the economy as a whole, despite recent reports of retrenchment in the computer field. An economic downturn could hurt IBM, he said, but ``it will have less of an impact if IBM has aggressively priced new technology in the marketplace.'' Stewart Crane, an analyst with Gruntal & Co., said IBM should outperform the technology industry as a whole. But, he added, despite improvements, ``They're not working on all six cylinders.'' ``It's a general consensus that IBM (stock) is cheap enough on basic earnings power and probably won't have any major negative surprises,'' he said. He said IBM's profit margins are being hurt by its decision to reduce the price of some of its products. As for growth in IBM's stock price this year, Jones predicts the blue-chip issue could hit $120 to $130 a share, while Martin puts it at the high end of that range. Jones predicts IBM's earnings per share should be about $10 this year; Matin puts the figure at $9.30. Crane said the going estimate on Wall Street is about $9.50 a share.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Feb. 26
$adv02
For Release Friday AMs, March 2, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Novel Took Five Years to Reach Screen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Film opens nationally on March 2.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Tom Clancy's high-tech novel ``The Hunt for Red October'' enthralled millions of readers with its suspense-filled drama of a renegade Soviet submarine. Surefire movie material, right? Yet the saga took five years to reach the screen. At least part of the reason, observes producer Mace Neufeld, is that studio executives don't read books. The Paramount Pictures release, starring Sean Connery, Alec Baldwin and a mammoth sub named Red October after the Russian Revolution, reaches the nation's theaters Friday. Neufeld optioned the Clancy book after reading the galley proofs in 1985. Even though the book was a huge best seller, the producer's efforts to find a studio failed. ``The cost factor was one reason,'' he said. ``In Hollywood, because of time constraints, very few people in a position to say yes to a project like this read the book. They generally read the reader's report. ``This book doesn't condense well into two or three pages. I read some of the reports from the other studios, and the story was too complicated to understand. Fortunately, I was able to get a major executive at Paramount to read the book, and he said: `I think this can make a great movie. Let's see if we can develop it.' '' Larry Ferguson and Donald Stewart worked on the script, and Neufeld sought the cooperation of the U.S. Navy _ ``without that, there could be no movie.'' At first the submariners were reluctant, pointing to their reputation as ``the silent service.'' But many of the admirals were fans of the Clancy book, Neufeld said, and they concluded a film would be a good way of ``showing taxpayers where their money was going.'' It helped that Paramount had glamorized the Navy's jet fighters in ``Top Gun.'' Neufeld would admit only that ``The Hunt for Red October'' cost ``in excess of $30 million'' _ some estimates are as high as $50 million. Much of the budget went to the Navy, which carries a list of charges for equipment and personnel used in movies. The first actor signed for the large, all-male cast was Alec Baldwin. ``The picture was first mentioned to me in December of 1988,'' the Long Island-born actor recalled in an interview. ``But it was not mentioned as the lead role. I figured they would get `Mr. Big' again.'' That had happened to Baldwin again and again. He had played supporting roles in such films as ``Beetlejuice,'' ``Married to the Mob,'' ``Working Girl,'' ``Talk Radio'' and ``She's Having a Baby.'' ``For some of the films I actually read for the lead roles,'' he says. ``It didn't work out that I got the roles. ``I had been offered some leads in films that were less desirable to me, and I turned them down. I was lucky to be working with Mike Nichols, Woody Allen, Jonathan Demme and John Hughes. So I took the best that was offered to me at that time.'' Baldwin was joined by a strong cast including Scott Glenn, James Earl Jones, Sam Neill, Tim Curry, Richard Jordan and Courtney B. Vance. The key role of the Soviet sub commander, Marko Ramius, went to the German actor Klaus Maria Brandauer. John McTiernan (``Die Hard'') was chosen as director. He was two weeks into filming when disaster struck: Brandauer could not report because of another commitment. The filmmakers sent a distress signal _ and a copy of the script by fax _ to Sean Connery. ``I had reservations about it,'' admits Connery. ``I thought this kind of Cold War intrigue might be dated because of recent events. It turned out that the studio had failed to fax the first page of the script, which explained that it took place before Gorbachev.'' Connery arrived in Los Angeles on a Friday and was supposed to start shooting on Monday. He requested a day's rehearsal, then jumped into his role as the stolid Soviet captain. He managed with remarkable ease, despite speaking his early dialogue in Russian. ``It wasn't hard,'' he said. ``They were all one-liners.'' He also had to deal with the immensely complicated submarine hardware. ``I can't even program my video recorder.'' Another hazard: the submarine sets. Because filming aboard actual subs was impractical, studio wizards constructed two 50-foot-square platforms to house mockups of the Red October and the USS Dallas. They stood on top of two hydraulic gimbals that could simulate the subs' movements. ``It was very claustrophobic,'' Connery recalls. ``There were 62 people in a very confined space, 45 feet above the stage floor. It got very hot on the sets, and I'm also prone to seasickness. The set would tilt to 45 degrees. Very disturbing.'' He was a navy man himself. ``I enlisted at the age of 16 and rose to the august position of able-bodied seaman. I enlisted for 12 years, but I was released after three because of ulcers _ which tells you something.'' Although he appears throughout the film, Connery's work was telescoped from seven weeks to four. The production continued for months on locations from Port Angeles, Wash., to the waters off Los Angeles. That was the site of opening shots of the Red October surfacing. ``We had built a replica over 400 feet long,'' says producer Neufeld. ``Taking it out on the ocean was a scary moment for all of us. We weren't sure it would work. Happily it did.'' Paramount is taking no chances that the launch of ``The Hunt for Red October'' will go unnoticed. The biggest movie hype since ``Batman'' was launched with an ad on the Super Bowl telecast. Billboards in major cities have carried the teaser line, ``The hunt is on.'' That was followed by a poster with the film's title and a stern portrait of Sean Connery. Millions of dollars have been poured into two-page ads in national magazines and commercials on national TV. A gala premiere in Washington was aimed to attract political attention. And the entire campaign is keyed in flame-colored red and black.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, March 2
$Adv03
$Adv04
For Release Weekend Editions, March 3-4, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: The Audi V8 Quattro
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Audi V8 Quattro is as close to a swagger as the folks at Audi get. This $47,450 power machine is quietly packaged in decidedly Audi styling _ the luxury Eurosedan look that's relatively unassuming. But take this new flagship of the Audi fleet out on the highway and revel with Audi in a new appreciation for what a luxury Eurosedan can be. The Audi V8 Quattro test car's 3.6-liter, 32-valve V-8 engine impressively dominated, going from 0 to 60 mph in 8.7 seconds, and is capable of producing 240 horsepower. Coupled with four-speed electronically controlled automatic transmission, it delivered smooth performance, especially in the economy driving mode. Drivers can change the shift points with a knob on the center console, depending on whether they want to watch fuel consumption (economy mode) or want maximum power (sport setting). I preferred the sport setting, though it made this nearly 4,000-pound car so quick I nearly took off the corner bumpers of a couple of cars I was trying to pass. And road handling? The Audi V8's suspension was masterful, making the vehicle feel as safe and in control at, let's just say, frightfully high speeds, as it did at the highway speed limit of 65 mph. And with full-time four-wheel-drive, this car can handle just about anything. It tackled snow with gusto, leaving other cars in a swirl of white. It tracked capably through icy slush, too. It was especially impressive, considering this is Audi's first merging of a powerful 32-valve V-8 engine, an automatic transmission and permanent all-wheel-drive technology. Of course, it's also the most expensive car the West German carmaker has marketed in the States. The previous top-priced Audi was the 200 Quattro wagon at $38,000. But wait. There's more to the Audi V8 Quattro. A microcomputer not only monitors the engine systems and maintains optimum performance but memorizes malfunctions for easier diagnosis at the shop. The test car's antilock brakes (ABS) came with a turnoff button on the dashboard for those driving conditions, such as loose gravel, where ABS can sometimes hinder a driver's ability to stop by preventing gravel from building up at the wheels. The Audi Bose sound system was superb, and the electronically controlled front seats _ leather, of course _ were roomy and comfortable. The front center armrest, which housed a cellular phone that was standard equipment, not optional, could be adjusted to various heights. Other thoughtful touches included heated seats in both the front and rear that worked wonderfully fast, a heated door lock on the driver door so you can't be frozen out of the car, and a dual windshield washer system.
