The system lets you use a special washer fluid that's particularly effective for salt and grime first, and then follow up with the regular fluid for picture-perfect vision no matter what the road throws up at you. The headlights received a washing, too, each time the regular washer fluid was activated. The front floor mats had fasteners to keep them in place, carpeting was all-wool throughout, and the shoulder belt height was adjustable so the belt wouldn't chafe against a short person's neck. There also was a reddish light that shone down on the driver floor area as an added safety feature when the headlights were on, wood grain tastefully swathed across the doors and dashboard, and a spot in the center of the instrument cluster that showed what radio station was tuned in so the driver never had to look below at the radio. That feature took some getting used to. My eyes caught the flickering of something changing in the instrument cluster, and at first, I thought it must have been a warning light that came on and went out. On examination, I realized it was just the changing radio station. I also noted the car can guzzle down the fuel _ I averaged under 17 mpg in combined city-highway driving, with the EPA rating the Audi V8 at 14 mpg in the city and 18 mpg on the highway. A gas guzzler tax of $1,050, by the way, is added on to the $47,450 base price for the Audi V8 Quattro because of the vehicle's poor fuel economy. Additionally, the person sitting in the rear middle seat would find the seatback a bit hard. That's where the rear center armrest is, and it just doesn't make for a very comfortable long-term resting spot. On the other hand, the rear legroom was good, and both the rear window controls and rear cigarette lighter could be disabled with the touch of a button on the driver door so children in back can't get hurt. Audi lists some impressive competitors for the V8 Quattro _ the Mercedes-Benz 420SEL, which starts around $63,000, the BMW 735i, around $53,000, and the Jaguar XJ6 Vanden Plas, around $48,000. Audi didn't mention Japanese luxury models, such as the Lexus LS400, which starts at $35,000, but they're bound to be a factor, too. Still, sales of the Audi V8 Quattro totaled more than 800 in calendar 1989, and the company projects about 1,500 sales in 1990. They're looking for mostly male buyers between 35 and 49, with household income of $150,000. They will be predominantly college graduates in professional jobs, Audi said. Because the Audi V8 Quattro is a new vehicle, Consumer Reports magazine does not list owner trouble reports.
DOC.NOTE: End Advance for Weekend Editions, March 3-4

For release weekend editions Feb. 24-25
DOC.HEAD: Bonuses At Dying Drexel Show How Wall Street's Skewed Pay System Works
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s disclosure that it paid more than $200 million in bonuses before collapsing has angered creditors and reinforced a popular notion that the junk bond giant was a glutton to the end. But compensation experts say the magnitude and timing of the Drexel bonuses, which came to light this past week, don't necessarily show a last-minute money orgy by a company that came to symbolize the greedy excesses of the past decade. Many said these bonuses, an alien dream to most American workers but a standard practice on Wall Street, graphically illustrate the nature of the skewed pay system in the feast-or-famine securities business, where the best talent has come to expect annual rewards of six figures and often more. ``What I think has happened to many firms is they've built these bonuses into their cost structure,'' said Richard Furniss, a vice president and compensation consultant at Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby in Manhattan. ``That's why you get a situation like Drexel, which feels perfectly justified to pay the bonuses,'' he said. ``It's an extreme result of the compensation system.'' Drexel pioneered the $200 billion junk bond market, financed the 1980s takeover decade and became known as the brashest, most arrogant and profitable firm on Wall Street. It collapsed with startling speed Feb. 13, the result of a slump in junk bonds, a criminal plea bargain on fraud charges, a cash shortage and a stunning loss of confidence by banks, lenders and customers. Drexel's parent filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection with debts totaling nearly $3 billion. In those circumstances, the disclosure that Drexel paid yearend bonuses in the hundreds of millions of dollars only a few months before seemed even more stunning. It raised questions about whether management knew how severe the firm's problems were or whether the money was paid deliberately to keep creditors from getting any. Some Drexel critics even theorized that if the company hadn't paid the bonuses it might have survived. Drexel denied initial reports that the bonuses totaled as much as $350 million and said the payments were predetermined by a formula devised a year ago. On Friday it issued a more detailed response, saying the bonuses totaled only $260 million, about 25 percent of it paid in company stock that's now almost worthless. Nonetheless, the propriety of the bonuses is expected to become an issue in bankruptcy court and in congressional scrutiny of the Drexel collapse. Historically, bonuses have represented the overwhelming portion of a Wall Street professional's annual compensation. Many investment firms are structured as partnerships, in which employees draw a living allowance during most of the year, calculate their pool of profit toward yearend and divvy it up. Those profit pools began to multiply in the late 1970s and grew even more dramatically in the 1980s, fueled by enormous expansion in the financial markets and the role investment banks played in corporate takeovers. ``Wall Street compensation packages are a result of the industry's incredibly accelerated growth rate during the boom years, when they were really engaged in a bidding war for a scarce commodity, talent,'' said Pearl Meyer, head of Pearl Meyer & Partners, a New York compensation consulting firm. ``The firms became extremely profitable. Compensation spiraled year after year,'' she said. ``Some tried to keep it down but weren't successful because everyone was recruiting.'' In those circumstances, an investment banker who historically brought in millions of dollars in business would simply jump ship if an employer tried to limit the bonus. Even in the midst of the slump that has gripped the securities industry for more than two years, the bonus often has remained entrenched. Many firms have laid off thousands of workers and exited marginally profitable businesses to cut their costs instead. Vincent C. Perro, a principal at Sibson & Co., a New York management consulting firm, said a third alternative that some Wall Street firms are trying is to base bonuses more on an individual's contribution. ``Given the reduced ability to pay, firms are differentiating between strong, average and weak performers more sharply in the past,'' he said. Others said they expected this disparity to grow and were advising clients to restructure their their bonus systems so that stars get rewarded and laggards don't. ``You examine individual performance more closely so you know where the money is made and you know who's making it,'' said Furniss. Elsewhere in business this past week: _The auto industry showed more signs of weakness. Major automakers said mid-February sales fell 12.1 percent. The Big Three proceeded with previously announced layoff plans that will idle thousands of workers. Jaguar PLC, the troubled British automaker dogged by quality control problems, issued a major recall in the midst of its acquisition by Ford Motor Co. In Europe, Volvo and Renault said they would invest in each other to make them more competitive. _Despite one of the worst weeks ever for the Tokyo stock market, stocks in the United States suffered only slightly. The divergent behavior conflicted with the widespread notion that the economically mighty Japanese have become the dominant force in influencing markets elsewhere. _In one of the few big takeovers so far this year, Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. dropped its resistance to a $3.7 billion acquisition by rival Georgia Pacific Corp.. The merger will create the largest U.S. forest products company. _The federal government blasted smoking but sanctioned a fat substitute. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, intensifying a campaign against tobacco companies, urged athletes to shun their ``blood money'' sponsorships. Meanwhile, the Food and Drug Administration approved the first fat substitute, a concoction of egg whites and milk called Simplesse, made by Monsanto Co. subsidiary NutraSweet Co.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions Feb. 24-25
$adv27
For Release AMs Tues., Feb 27
DOC.HEAD: Peace Dividend of Another Sort
DOC.TEXT: There may indeed be a peace dividend in the future, but it might not be the one that's getting most of the attention. Most of the dividend talk so far has centered around the possibility of the the country having to spend less for defense in a more peaceful world, allowing deficits to be cut or money allocated to various social needs. More recent thinking takes another perspective on the peace dividend, one that envisions the United States, and in fact the entire world, benefitting from a marked increase in trade and economic development. The latter thesis is beginning to sound more likely for many reasons, most compelling of them being that it probably has begun already. Even before the Socialist wall crumbled, American companies were preparing for a relaxation of business restrictions throughout Eastern Europe. Now that matters have been facilitated, a rush is on to develop markets there. Western money markets already reflect an eagerness to begin the financing job, which Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan last week called ``the most important financial issue of the decade.'' Greenspan's comments were timely, since Eastern Europe's great need for investment capital, representing a brand new demand on the world's lendable funds, already have pushed up U.S. and world interest rates. In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Greenspan indicated that the higher rates might be temporary, and many financial analysts continue to believe that interest costs in general will resume falling later this year. His comments were also significant because until now the usual explanation for high interest rates, often shared by the Fed, was the existence of federal budget deficits. Those deficits now fall to second place. If the United States is able to take advantage of the big demands likely to be made by the emerging market economies of Europe, it would help, at least in the short term, to reduce the nagging U.S. balance of payments deficit. The expansion of market economies, especially if it eventually includes China, would also provide relief from intense competition for severely stressed domestic goods producers, now pressured by imports from Europe and Asia. The possibilities for trade expansion are heightened also by events beyond Eastern Europe. The Japanese are expected to relax restrictions to entry into their markets. And the planned economic unification of Western Europe might spur growth in that area, further enhancing possibilities for U.S. companies. The original notion of a peace dividend was that savings would come mainly from a reduction in defense spending, with estimates ranging from a few billion dollars to as much as $150 billion a year. Such a decline would open up various options to American policymakers, including tax cuts, elimination of the big budget deficits and attacks on various social problems, including drugs, poor housing and health care. If the budget deficit shrinks, and if the Federal Reserve could fine tune the money supply, it becomes conceivable in such a scenario that interest rates and inflation would decline, giving a big boost to the standard of living. In the past, however, such apparent opportunities have a mysterious way of disappearing when the money is counted. Somehow, planned savings get spent, sometimes unwisely, the only explanation being that ``that's politics.'' The peace dividend that arises from investment and industrial development is very real, and it probably is under way right now.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Tues., Feb. 27

$adv 25
For Release Weekend Editions Feb. 24-25
DOC.HEAD: Relationship Between Japanese, U.S. Stock Markets Murky
DOC.TEXT: Events this week on Wall Street once again demonstrated the link between the Japanese and American stock markets _ or did they? Twice this past week the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged. Each time, the drop echoed in New York. But the severity of the decline on Wall Street didn't come close to the fall in Tokyo. On Wednesday, when the Nikkei index fell 3.15 percent for its third-worst decline ever, stocks in New York mimicked the slide at the opening bell and the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 30 points. But the market soon recovered, and by the close, the Dow was down a modest 13.29. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 2.61 percent for its fifth-worst drop in history. Again, the New York market opened lower _ but the Dow was down only about 11 points. The market seesawed before the Dow finished down 10.58. The behavior of the two markets cast doubt on what widely had been assumed to be the inextricable link between the U.S. and Japanese exchanges. That relationship was demonstrated powerfully last Oct. 13, when the Dow plunged 190 points but the Tokyo stock market's strength in the following session helped restore investor confidence on Wall Street. At the time, many had feared the Tokyo market would plunge and drag down New York even further, particularly if Japanese investors were forced to sell their U.S. stocks to raise cash for obligations at home. Many American securities holders worried about that prospect again this past week. Walter Murphy, a senior market specialist with Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc., said the New York and Tokyo markets react to domestic issues as much as to events abroad. ``You're looking at two markets that are acting under their own reasons for being,'' he said. For example, he said, when the yen is down in relation to the dollar, it's bad news for the Tokyo market but good news in New York because a weaker yen helps improve U.S. trade competitiveness. However, he did not dispute that there was a link among the world markets. ``If you look at markets over time, there is and has been a good global relationship. Bull markets in one part of the world are going to be bull markets in the other part of the world,'' he said. But, he added, ``To say there is a day-to-day correlation is not only inaccurate but probably dangerous.'' Ralph E. Blair, a partner in the trading department of Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco, said: ``There certainly is a concern about what goes on over there. But considering all the bad (economic) news, the (U.S.) market is acting pretty well.'' Blair said one factor that made it easier for the U.S. markets to take the Japanese plunge in stride this week was that the decline was fairly orderly as far as market drops go. In addition, analysts have been saying for months that the Tokyo market _ the world's largest and richest _ was overpriced and ripe for a ``correction.'' They said its share prices were way out of line with corporate earnings. Some experts say the Tokyo market operates in a world of its own. European stocks historically have moved more in tandem with New York than with Tokyo. That also may account for a lessening of the impact of a drop in Japan. The reaction in New York also may have been another demonstration of Wall Street's stiff upper lip so far this year in the face of gloomy economic news. The market has shrugged off concern about higher interest rates, recession forecasts and the demise of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. For the week, which was shortened a day by the Presidents Day holiday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 71.40 to 2,564.19. The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 4.40 to 179.35; the NASDAQ composite index of over-the-counter trading lost 9.49 to 419.52, and the American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 7.77 to 351.10. Volume on the Big Board averaged 159.84 million shares a day, compared with 148.57 the week before.

DOC.HEAD: SEC: Philip Morris Can't Block Shareholder Anti-Tobacco Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to the ``growing significance of the social and public policy issues'' involving tobacco products, federal securities regulators say Philip Morris Cos. cannot block shareholder anti-smoking resolutions. The Securities and Exchange Commission informed Philip Morris on Thursday that it was reversing its stance allowing the company to reject such proposals as interference with its ordinary course of business. Companies seeking to exclude attempts to put issues up for a vote at annual shareholders meetings must seek SEC approval, in the form of a staff letter saying the agency will take ``no action'' against the company for barring such a proposal. ``While prior staff letters have permitted'' exclusion of shareholder proposals limiting involvement in tobacco products on the grounds of ordinary business interference, ``the staff believes that many of these positions should be reversed,'' SEC Special Counsel John C. Brousseau wrote Philip Morris. He added: ``those prior letters failed to reflect adequately the growing significance of the social and public policy issues attendant to operations involving the manufacture and distribution of tobacco related products.'' His letter concerned a resolution proposed for the annual meeting on April 26 by two Roman Catholic religious orders, the Province of St. Joseph of the Capuchin Order and the Adrian Dominican Sisters. The proposal calls for amending the articles of incorporation to bar Philip Morris after Dec. 31, 1991 from conducting ``any business in tobacco or tobacco products.'' Also allowed by the SEC was a proposal by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America to create a review committee to study the impact of Philip Morris advertising on smoking by minors.
